answer: The author concludes the story with this because gardens simply cannot thrive when there is snow covering the ground. The cold and snow create an inhospitable environment for plant growth. The narrator includes that in the paragraph because it all makes perfect sense and it flows together seamlessly. The details fit well within the context of the narrative. The author concludes the story with that passage to clearly show the great importance of the inspiration Saeng gets from the hibiscus plant. Similarly, Saeng is initially bitter about her new country and the driving test, but she is in the process of adapting, and will surely be inspired by the beautiful state of the hibiscus in the spring to try her test again. In conclusion, the author ended the story in that way to strongly stress the significance in the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus plant, which is a key element in the story's theme.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph of “Winter Hibiscus” because it effectively takes us back to the key things that happened in the story. The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the author wanted to tell about when Saeng will take the test again. The author specified the time with the season of spring. The story ended with the author saying, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is quite upset about spending @NUM1 on a plant that she had felt was different from the plant at home. She had high hopes for it, thinking it would bring a piece of home with her. I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph helps bring the story to a proper closing. The author would conclude the story with that paragraph because she failed the test before, and that failure left a mark on her. However, she is a determined person and wants to pass it. In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, it concludes the story with a heartening ending. In the story, the girl buys a Hibiscus that reminds her strongly of home. She goes home and tells her mother that she failed her test but bought the plant. While she was carefully planting it in the soil, she saw geese flying in the sky and was immediately reminded of home. America, which once seemed so foreign, was now starting to feel more like home, and she was much happier. In the text, she says, "many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, almost familiar to her now." She is willing to give the test another try and is confident that she is sure to pass it. America is now starting to feel a little more like home, and this new sense of belonging gives the story a warm and satisfying conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the story initially began with Saeng failing the test. After the failure, she went out and bought a plant as a means to comfort herself, and then she confessed the test result to her mom. The plant was closely related to her through the memories of her homeland. When she failed that test, she felt extremely depressed and sad. She shed tears to express her pain and decided to buy a plant to lift her spirits. As she told her mom about the failure, she felt the pain all over again. However, her mother made her favorite food and assisted her in planting the plant. She was aware that it wasn't exactly like the old plant from her homeland, but it was the thought and the memories attached to it. She knew that she couldn't simply give up. So, when the right time arrived, she was going to attempt the test once more. This conclusion relates to the story as it helps the readers better understand the narrative and shows that she wasn't going to quit easily. Her mother was very understanding, and when she goes to retake the test, she will be well - prepared. That is how it relates back to the story and wraps up the overall theme of perseverance.

I think he concluded the story with this paragraph because there are certain recurring things in the story and the report. Just like the geese, they leave and then come back, only to leave again. This cycle of departure and return is symbolic. When we talk about taking the test again, it might be similar to the geese's pattern. It could imply that facing challenges is a repetitive process, and one has to keep trying. The conclusion with this paragraph helps to emphasize this idea of continuous effort and the cyclical nature of events in the story. So, that is what I think taking the test again means in the context of the story's conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when everything in her life starts coming back to normal, when the familiar routines and the comforting elements return, she will take the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show a strong sense of determination that Saeng possesses. The story says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This quote clearly states that Saeng is starting to understand that things at home can be similar to things in her new country. The author uses the term “familiar” to express that Saeng is gradually starting to accept the fact that some things may be different, but she will eventually get used to them. The author concludes the story this way because Saeng failed the test, the hibiscus provides her with comfort, and she feels a strong similarity to the geese. In “Winter Hibiscus,” by Minfong Ho, the main character, Saeng, undergoes many obstacles as she tries to adapt to her new country, which is very different from her home. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wanted to show that just because Saeng failed that test, it doesn't mean she's giving up. Winter Hibiscus" is a story about a young girl named Saeng, who made the journey from Vietnam to the @ORGANIZATION1. After experiencing the disappointment of failing her driver's test, she decides to walk home. Along the way, she stumbles upon a hibiscus. As she stands there, "She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair…" Intrigued by this discovery, she ventures to a flower shop to check if the hibiscus can be purchased. Despite the plant being rare and valuable, and thus quite expensive, she pays a significant amount of money for it. This hibiscus is of great importance to her because she used to have hibiscus plants in Vietnam, which bring back cherished memories. She brings the plant home and tells her mom that it reminds her of Vietnam. The mom acknowledges that it also reminds her of their homeland but is not pleased with how much Saeng paid for it. Nevertheless, Saeng plants it in her garden. As "When the hibiscus was lowered in the ground, a flock of geese flew by." This sight seems to symbolize a new beginning. When the hibiscus returns in the spring, all the flowers start to bud and bloom, and everything takes on a fresh start. Saeng sees this as a sign and decides that she will take her driver's test again, believing that in this season of renewal, she will have a new chance to pass the test and move forward in her life.

I think that the author included that part because she is comparing herself to a flower. Just like a flower goes through a cycle of growth and dormancy, she believes that when she experiences growth again, similar to a flower blooming, she will be ready to prove herself and pass that test. She is conveying the message that there is always a second chance in life. She wants to share with everyone that it's okay to have misses or make mistakes. For instance, "they said there were many of things that she had thought of strangely, season up season." This shows that life has its ups and downs, and just like the changing seasons, there will be opportunities for growth and redemption. So, she is using the metaphor of a flower to express her hope and determination to overcome her past failure and achieve success.

The author concludes the story like that because she wants every person to understand how deeply she feels about the hibiscus. She regarded the hibiscus as a truly wonderful plant. In her description, she mentioned that it was "smooth and cool" toward the end of the first page. When she first encountered the plant back in Vietnam, she had the perception that it simply grew wildly in its natural environment. However, when she saw it in the United States, growing in a pot, she was quite surprised. To further emphasize her affection for the hibiscus, she described the smell of the hibiscus as a "sweet scent." @CAPS1, this is precisely why she concludes the story in this manner; it is all because of the profound emotions and attachment she felt towards the plant, which she wanted to convey to the readers.

The author concludes the story with that statement because it vividly shows Saeng's passion for gardening. She is so eager to engage in gardening that she is determined to attempt to grow the hibiscus during this season. This eagerness is palpable, as it demonstrates her anticipation and hope for a successful gardening experience. Her enthusiasm for gardening is not just a passing interest but a deep - seated passion that drives her to face challenges, such as taking the test, in the hope of seeing her plants flourish. It is this unwavering passion that the author wants to highlight by concluding the story in this way, showing Saeng's dedication to her gardening dreams.

The author concludes the story with this specific ending to convey that when all aspects of life are restored to a normal and beautiful state, that is precisely when Saeng will take the test. Saeng has a deep - seated fondness for working in the garden during the spring season, enjoying the fresh air and the blooming flowers. Moreover, it implies that Saeng has a strong belief that she can achieve better academic results in school during the springtime, perhaps due to the pleasant weather and the rejuvenating atmosphere.

Change and disappointment are indeed heavy burdens that are enough to overcome. There are some people who have an intense, almost arid fear of change. I think the author intended to vividly express Saeng's state of mind when she took a solemn vow. The author also aimed to convey the exact way Saeng felt at that moment. For shadowing, future reference, and continuous behavior, all these are valid reasons why that is the last paragraph. They are relevant for shadowing because the text is telling you something that Saeng says she is going to do in the future. She clearly outlines what she plans to do in the future, thus making a reference to her future actions. She is also maintaining the behavior from before. As she says she will do something again next year, it shows a pattern of continuous behavior. She said, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” So, shadowing, future reference, and continuous behaviors are very good reasons to believe that what she says is significant, and these three aspects best describe what she said and her future plans.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with the paragraph for a few reasons. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the main character Saeng and her mother moved from their beloved homeland to this new place, where everything was strikingly different. Overall, the author of this story concludes with this paragraph because it contains the theme of the passage through an uplifting message, highlighting Saeng's resilience and hope for a better future in her new home.

Therefore, the author concludes this story with this paragraph to clearly demonstrate how she will successfully adapt to the change in her environment.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph because she can hardly wait until spring as her plant will bud and it will vividly remind her of her homeland again. She is extremely eager to take the test in spring because she would have been able to stay and she @MONTH1 hopes to pass the test in the spring since she did not pass it the first time she took the test. Maybe she concluded the story with this paragraph because she @MONTH1 truly likes the spring and she can hardly contain her excitement for it to come. By ending on this note, it emphasizes her anticipation and the hope she has for a better outcome in the spring.

I believe there is a meaningful reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. I think that the author will feel more comfortable and fully ready to take the test. I was able to come to this conclusion because by patiently waiting for winter to be over to take the test again, she is giving herself sufficient time to thoroughly prepare. Also, she is eagerly waiting for the hibiscus plant to bud. Something I was able to extract from the fact that she wants to wait for the hibiscus is the presence of comfort. The whole story revolves around how Saeng was able to comfort herself by fondly reminiscing on her past experiences in Vietnam. When she feels that an important part of her life is returning, she can become truly comfortable and focused. I think the author would conclude the story with this paragraph because the author wants to strongly stress the importance of this flower in how Saeng lives her life, as it serves as a symbol of hope and comfort.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to clearly show she has hope. She firmly believes that she can pass the test when everything returns to normal, specifically in the spring. In the spring, the geese will gracefully return and the hibiscus will be beautifully budding. This makes her feel more at home because it was always like this before she moved. Also, she genuinely likes the geese and the hibiscus and these things might make her feel more at ease and comfortable. This is precisely why the author concludes the story with this paragraph to powerfully show that she has hope, and it leaves the reader with a sense of optimism for her future.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph because he/she wanted to draw a comparison between Saeng's life and that of the plant. For instance, in the story, Saeng had just failed her driving test. Right after this set - back, she saw a plant that instantly reminded her of her homeland. As she carried the plant from the flower shop to her house, she constantly compared her homeland to the flower, clearly showing how deeply she related to it. So, the concluding paragraph indicates that just as the hibiscus is budding and entering a new phase, Saeng will also embark on a new journey and go for her driver's license once again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly show Saeng's determination to adapt to the significant change in her life. In the story, Saeng fails her driver's test and is truly struggling to adjust to her new life in @LOCATION1. However, when she notices that the hibiscus and geese are familiar sights, she becomes firmly determined to adapt as well. Saeng buys a hibiscus because it strongly reminds her of home. This purchase not only comforts her but also makes her miss her old home even more. The hibiscus has the remarkable ability to survive in both @LOCATION2 and @LOCATION1, which helps Saeng realize that she too can thrive in this new environment. The author includes the geese because they play a crucial role in helping Saeng understand that she is becoming more familiar with things in the United States. Saeng remarks that she now easily recognizes the “V” shape of the geese. Realizing that she is becoming more accustomed to @LOCATION1 and that she is capable of surviving here gives her the determination to retake and pass her driving test. The author includes these elements to effectively summarize the story's theme of adapting to change.

I think that the author deliberately put that sentence in the text to establish a more personal connection with the character. By doing so, the readers can more easily relate to that person on a deeper emotional level. This way, the story becomes more engaging and relatable, allowing the audience to better understand the character's experiences and feelings.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize the importance of new beginnings and to strongly accentuate the theme in the story. The central theme is that one must have the courage to overcome hardships and actively seek new beginnings. Springtime is a well - known symbol of a new beginning. So, the arrival of spring will offer her an opportunity to start afresh on the driver's test. Also, the author uses the paragraph to highlight the symbolic qualities of everyday things. Just as the hibiscus brought back memories of her home life, the geese will serve as a reminder of the hope and renewal that springtime represents. This all ties together to reinforce the story's message about new beginnings.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus", the author Minfong Ho concludes the story with that paragraph because it is a powerful way of suggesting that Saeng is going to put aside what happened in the past when she failed her test and is going to perform better the next time. It's as if the author is saying that Saeng will be reborn again, much like the hibiscus when spring arrives. Throughout the story, Saeng had to make adjustments, just as the hibiscus had to adapt to its new surroundings. The hibiscus served as a great source of inspiration for Saeng, motivating her to do well in her new environment. So, after learning so much from the hibiscus, it marks a brand - new beginning for Saeng.

Itís kind of like a central theme for the story. The hibiscuses, with their vibrant colors and unique shapes, inspire her to want to actively engage in various things. I guess they bring vivid memories of her home country, with its familiar landscapes and warm - hearted people, and make her eager to bravely try new things. This is significant to the story because it clearly shows you how incredibly important the hibiscus was to Saeng, serving as a powerful symbol of her connection to the past and her motivation for the future.

I think the author chose to end the story this way to vividly show that the girl is deeply remembering her past and is truly at ease. With the flower in her presence, she attains a profound sense of peace. The writer wants to effectively convey that no matter what kind of environment or lifestyle you are accustomed to, you can surely find something, like this flower, that can bring you genuine happiness and a strong sense of focus, guiding you through life's ups and downs.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph @CAPS1 as it clearly shows that she is determined to pass that test. She has set her mind firmly on it and is not going to give up even a little bit until she finally passes it. This determination is a key aspect of the character's development in the story, highlighting her perseverance and will - power.

The reason why I feel the author ended the story with this paragraph is because she is skillfully showing how the character has matured and how the character has grown within her difficult circumstances. This clearly shows that just because you failed once doesnít mean you are going to fail again. Also, itís perfectly okay to feel out of place at times. There is always going to be a time in life where a new beginning is going to start. So it is entirely your choice to take that chance bravely or be stuck in your own old ways. But ultimately, the decision is always up to you, and this ending encourages us to be brave and embrace new beginnings.

In the short story ìWinter Hibiscusî by ìMinfong Hoî she ends the story by saying, ìwhen they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. ìI - I failed the testî. As many kids do, Saeng failed her driving test and she is extremely upset about it. Nobody wants to fail at something, and it is almost a deeply humiliating experience to have failed at a test, especially knowing that others have already successfully passed. With the quote in the introduction paragraph, or the one in the question, it was written as a clear sign of symbolism. When the geese return back north, it is to vividly show that they are ready to ìstart overî again or to ìtry againî. When the hibiscus is budding it is trying to ìstart lifeî again. Saeng seeing these objects doing things over and over again empowers her strongly to want to succeed and try again. She realizes it is just a natural part of life and that in order to succeed you have to fail. Minfong concludes with that quote because she understands that no matter what the obstacle, you must press forward with determination and keep trying in order to succeed. She realizes success can only come from hard work and unwavering commitment, and that that is what makes a truly great, strong individual, capable of overcoming life's challenges.

The reason why the author concludes the paragraph with that sentence is because he wants to let the reader know that the situation is not over. He wants the reader to understand that @ORGANIZATION1 will not forget the events and circumstances. And also that all these events will happen again, creating a sense of cyclicality and persistence in the narrative.

The author concludes the ending as “I will take that test again” meaning that the difficulties she is going through now are going to happen again, but next time she will be prepared. Saeng has a very difficult time moving to another country and getting comfortable in the new place. Her mother supports her as she goes through the winter. The hibiscus that she bought is a symbol that represents more than itself. In this text of “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the hibiscus she bought when she was in a worst time accompanied her through the winter. At the last paragraph of the story, she expresses “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding”. She is thinking of the future and how she, Saeng, vowed silently to herself in the spring. She can't wait until winter is over and is just waiting for the spring to come, looking forward to a new start.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to tell us what she does once she gets back in the spring. That means when she gets back, she will then be taking care of the plants with dedication. When she gets back, she wants the snow to melt and for everything to return to life. That is what the author is clearly telling me from the story, showing a connection between the character's actions and the changing of seasons.

I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph to ensure the reader that she will stay again. Also, the author concludes the story this way to show the reader that no matter where you go in life, there will always be something or someone there to assure you of everything. The author also wanted the reader to feel a sense of similarity to the character, meaning no matter how out of place you feel, there is always something you can relate to, creating an empathetic bond between the reader and the story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph so that we will buy his coming book, or so that we get more excited about what is to come. By ending the story in this way, the author aims to leave the readers with a sense of anticipation and eagerness to explore more of his literary works, effectively creating a hook for future engagement.

In this story, the author decides to end the story with this paragraph: "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This is because she wants to take the test when everything is ideal. For example, she wants everything she likes in her environment, such as the blooming flowers, the flying geese, and the pleasant weather. Another reason why I say the author ends the story with that paragraph is that she wants to be in an environment like the one in her home country. For instance, there was no snow and it was like springtime all year around. This is why I say that the author ended the story with that paragraph, as it reflects Saeng's longing for a familiar and comforting setting for the test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that she is deeply comforted by the memories of her homeland and truly appreciates the beauty of tropical plants. She firmly believes that since it is winter and the hibiscus is not budding, she cannot pass the test until it is. "Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of before had, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost become familiar to her now." This clearly shows how much she really does believe in the beauty of her homeland and the tropical plants. She is thinking back to other times when things were strange during the winter and better in the spring and other seasons when the plants are budding. So, she believes that she will actually pass the driver's test when she feels comfortable, when the plants have budded and the environment is more like that of her homeland.

The geese flying south for the winter and the hibiscus budding are normal and familiar things to Saeng. The author wanted to conclude the story with this to clearly show that Saeng felt comfort in things that she was accustomed to. Saeng specifically wanted to have the geese and hibiscus there to feel more at ease and comfortable while taking her driving test. Saeng still longs for home and does not quite feel like she fits in the U.S. The hibiscus gives her that comforting feeling as if she is home again, in Vietnam. Saeng still feels homesick because she wants things to be exactly how they were. The plants in the greenhouse along with the disappointment of failing her driving test bring her to the emotional state that she was in. In the second - to - last paragraph, the author talks about the feeling of repetition Saeng has when seeing the V - formation of the geese. Saeng feels that in the winter she will not have the same comfort feeling as when she can see the hibiscus and the geese flying overhead. It says that when Saeng arrived in the new place, she had nothing that was familiar to her. Now she gets that feeling of familiarity from the geese and plants. The author concluding by saying Saeng will take her driving test when the winter ends is a good closing because it gives you some insight as to what Saeng is going to do and how she is waiting for a more comforting time to face the test again.

I think the author concludes with the sentence "Then they come back, Saeng vowed to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again" because it was winter and the school was closed. When the geese come back, it will be spring, and the school will likely reopen. So, it will be an appropriate time to go back to school and also take the test. Saeng wants to take the test in a more favorable and familiar environment. The presence of the geese and the budding hibiscus will give her the comfort and confidence she needs. This is why the author's conclusion makes sense as it ties in Saeng's longing for a better testing situation with the natural cycle of the seasons.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes his story with an odd ending. "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus budding. then I will take that test again." Beyond the literal meaning, the author is showing how Saeng is gradually adapting to the new country. By failing her driver's test, she also faced a setback in adapting and accepting the new country. However, by vowing to try again, it also shows that she is willing to give the country another chance. "She found she was still too shaky to say the words at home." This clearly shows that she still didn't consider this country her home. She was still deeply stuck on her past and the memories of her homeland. The author's ending implies that Saeng is on a journey of adaptation, and waiting for the spring to take the test again is a symbol of her hope for a better outcome and a more comfortable integration into the new environment.

The author concludes this story in the paragraph to clearly show that Saeng won't stop her pursuit, just because she failed that one time at the beginning. It also vividly shows that she is not going to let certain difficulties and setbacks keep her down, and will continue to strive forward.

The last sentence of a story is usually the most meaningful part. I firmly believe the author ended the story this way for many well - thought - out reasons. For example, I think the author did this specifically to leave the reader with a strong and lasting sense of determination. The story quotes, “I will take that test again.” By the deliberate use of the word “will”, the author powerfully shows the girl's unwavering determination. She didn't say she would try to, she said she will, without a single doubt. I also think the author ended this way to strongly emphasize the theme of new beginnings. The story quotes, “when they come back... in the spring... I will take that test again.” This clearly shows that in spring, the new beginning of life, she will take the test. This is precisely why I believe the author ended the story this way.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” made a very good choice to conclude the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This paragraph subtly hints to the reader that Saeng intends to skillfully combine her new and old lives. Her old life is vividly represented by the hibiscus; she is accustomed to the constants from back home. The geese symbolize her new life; they have gradually become “almost familiar to her now”. The significant obstacle she faces is passing the driving test. The author implies that in the spring, when the old and new parts of Saeng's life are well - combined, Saeng will be fully able to overcome her “obstacle”, and all will be in a harmonious and positive state. With the geese on the ground, Saeng's life will have truly come full circle.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it's very important when she says “when geese return and this hibiscus is budding” and then she says she will take that test again. This is to clearly tell the reader exactly when she will take that test again. That's the exact reason why it's included in the story.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it strongly emphasizes that Saeng is whole - heartedly willing to retake the test when the right time comes back. I also think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the story the second - last paragraph says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of the season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This sentence clearly shows me that Saeng is gradually getting used to the new place. Also, it shows how she is changing her mind about the plant and the fact that even though it's not the same as what she's used to, it can still hold special meaning. Therefore, I think the author made an excellent choice in ending the story with this paragraph.

The last paragraph states “in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again.” I believe the author has ended with that paragraph to clearly state the fact that when her new home starts to resemble her old home in terms of the natural scenery and the changing seasons, maybe she will feel more confident and more at ease in her new place. This is in contrast to the cold winter, which is the total opposite of the climate and environment where she used to live. The feeling of having elements of her old home in her new home will make her more positive and comfortable. So then, she will take the test feeling like she is at home and is likely to pass it, demonstrating her successful adaptation to the new environment.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author vividly expresses how the girl believes that with her cherished memories and once she gradually changes and fully adapts to the new culture, that's when she will have the courage to retake the test she failed on that particular day. Saeng misses her home so much that she can't initially grasp that there are indeed similarities between her new home and her old one. “She realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” Saeng didn't want to expect the move at first, but as she notices that she won't forget any of her old memories, she starts to embrace new memories. At first, everything was so different, but now she is starting to recall things about her new home, which is a clear sign of comfort to her. “She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again.” With Saeng's complex feelings about the change, the ending paragraph lets the reader know that there is definite hope for her to move on in her new home. She is gradually starting to gain confidence and she knows that when she does, she can take her test and succeed at it. The author effectively shows how good change can be if one is willing to adapt. Everything might not always be as perfect as you know it to be, but your courage will help you create a happy home filled with both new and old memories, as Saeng starts to realize during the last paragraph, highlighting the power of resilience and adaptation.

The author merely states the obvious within this short story. This excerpt mainly means that when spring arrives with its warm weather and blooming flowers, she will return to the greenhouse or the area filled with all the plants. When she gets there, the girl will attempt to find the plant that grows wild in her home country and bring it to her new home, perhaps as a way to connect with her roots and bring a piece of her past into her new life. This action also shows her longing for her homeland and her desire to create a more familiar environment in her new place.

The reason the author concludes the story with that kind of paragraph, I think he's trying to vividly show Saeng as the type of person who never gives up and always keeps growing, just like the resilient hibiscus plant. And because she realizes that most of the things that she once thought were strange before have, through the quiet and continuous repetition of season upon season, become almost familiar to her. Saeng notices that she will still have the next season when the plant has fully grown and the geese fly into a distinctive V again. This indicates that she has accepted the passage of time and the changes in her new environment, and is looking forward to new opportunities and growth, just like the cycle of nature.

Minfong Ho concludes the story with this paragraph because it effectively shows how Saeng feels. In the paragraph, Saeng said "I will take that test again", which means she is contemplating whether she will go through the same difficult experiences again. This shows her determination and her willingness to face challenges. It also reflects her growth and self - awareness as she tries to figure out if she has the strength and ability to overcome the same obstacles in the future. Through this statement, the author allows the reader to understand Saeng's evolving mindset and her journey of adaptation in the new environment.

The author ends the story this way to clearly show that there can always be a heart - warming happy ending. The geese gracefully came back to the familiar place, and the girl was extremely happy because of their return. This happy ending leaves a positive impression on the readers.

The author concluded the story with his paragraph because these are all the precious things that she isn't going to give up on. She is earnestly trying to say that when everything she whole - heartedly believes in succeeds, that's precisely when she is going to take her driving test. Her mother gently says that the flower is never going to give up and it's strong enough to bravely live through the harsh winter. The geese are going to always come back year after year. That is exactly what she is going to do with her test. She is not going to give up on the test; she is going to keep trying patiently until she finally passes.

Saeng feels more comfortable and at ease in the spring because it vividly reminds her of her beloved home. She probably never had the experience of seeing snow or going through a cold winter before. So nothing in this cold time of the year can evoke memories of home for her. In the spring, it does because the geese return in a beautiful formation and the hibiscus grow again, making everything around her feel like it's her home again. Confidence is what she receives when spring comes again, giving her a sense of belonging and strength.

The author concludes the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” with that paragraph because it precisely sums up everything the hibiscus has selflessly given Saeng for strength and courage. Just like the hibiscus, Saeng felt out of place and lost in this new country, and the hibiscus helps her clearly realize the importance in adapting to her new environment for her survival in order to live happily. She can't always be stuck dwelling in the past but has to learn to like where she lives now. Therefore, when the author writes, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it is a direct symbol of Saeng budding or opening her mind to the new ways, like learning to drive, and embracing her new life.

I believe the author of “Winter Hibiscus” used this for the last paragraph because it is subtly saying when she sees that hibiscus, it will bring back sweet memories of home again, which will bring much - needed encouragement for the test. “The geese symbolize Saeng's firm determination to pass the test and adapt to the new country. Saeng explains, “She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V - shape was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.” This quote creates a vivid and powerful image in my mind that clearly lets me know Saeng will really go and take that test when she has encouragement from not only the geese but the hibiscus also, showing her strong will to move forward.

The author concludes with that paragraph because it is, in a subtle yet impactful way, letting you know that everything's going to be alright. Saeng, who has faced the disappointment of a failed drivers test, is going to retry her drivers test again with newfound determination. Everything is back to the way she likes best, with a sense of normalcy and hope restored. It gives you a strong sense of hope, assuring you that everything is going to be alright with her. Also, it indicates that she is going to start making the best out of life, seizing every opportunity that comes her way. I believe it's saying this, and that is why I think the author concludes with that paragraph, leaving the readers with a feeling of optimism.

The Author uses this paragraph to conclude the Story because it clearly shows how Saeng wants to adapt to this new country. She is already beginning to understand it and like it, gradually finding her place in this unfamiliar land. When it says “and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”, it is a powerful metaphor about herself. When the hibiscus begins to bloom and flourish, just as she is starting to bloom and grow into a more confident and capable individual. This is why the Author ended with this passage, as it beautifully encapsulates Saeng's journey of adaptation and growth.

Saeng said that when the tree she bought starts budding she will take the test over. She means that without that plant, she just does not feel mentally and emotionally ready to take the test. She doesn't have the motivation because the plant was with her throughout her whole life, serving as a constant source of comfort and familiarity. She also thinks that she can not do it, without that plant by her side. Saeng means that since she's had a plant like that her whole life, then she subconsciously thinks she needs it for support. But I don't think she really needs it in a practical sense. I guess it just “comforts” her, providing a psychological boost.

The author didn't think that Saeng was ready to take the test until she knew more about it. Saeng had a lot on her mind regarding gardening, as she was deeply passionate about it. Since she didn't have any friends in school, she didn't want to go there as she would have nobody to talk to, which added to her lack of enthusiasm for the test. It's good that Saeng vowed to take the test again because she will never know if she would do good or bad without giving it a try. So, the author realized that Saeng will take the test and pass, as her determination and growing knowledge will likely lead to success.

The author concludes with this paragraph mostly because she wants to emphasize her memories of her homeland by saying that she would take the test again driving the next spring. This is due to the fact that she knows as soon as spring comes back, there will be a flood of memories coming back to her. During spring, animals come out of their hiding places and trees blossom, creating a beautiful and enchanting scenery. It makes it all beautiful for her to take the test again, with the support from her memories of her country, which will give her the strength and motivation to succeed. The author uses this ending to tie together Saeng's past and present, and to leave a lasting impression of hope and connection.

After reading the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author ends the story in a unique way that clearly demonstrates a will to survive. For example, in the text, the author writes and explains how the plant “dok faeng - noi” has adapted to its cold environment, which is different from the ones back at home. This showcases the idea of survival as, in the past, this plant migrated to a place that seemed warm at the time. But when the cold set in, it found ways to change itself and adapt, all driven by the instinct to survive. Another example in the text is the author having Saeng tell herself that in the spring, when the weather is more favorable and the world is full of new beginnings, she will try and take the test again. This demonstrates the will to survive because when Saeng failed the test, she felt a deep sense of melancholy and failure. The fact that she had the courage to prepare for the test in spring shows how, as a human being, she wants to live. And for her to live in a new country, she must adapt by passing that test to become a survivor. In conclusion, the author's unique ending effectively conveys the powerful theme of the will to survive.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly show the story about snows covering the roads. He shows people the importance of carefully watching where they are going on these snow - covered roads. In conclusion, the paragraph would show that he made it through the snow storm, highlighting his perseverance and ability to overcome the challenging situation presented by the snow. This ending not only gives a sense of resolution but also emphasizes the significance of being cautious in difficult circumstances.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng vows to herself that in the spring, when the snow melts, the geese return in a beautiful V - formation, and the hibiscus is budding with delicate flowers, then she will take the test again. The author concludes with this paragraph because the hibiscus brings her a sense of comfort from home and boosts her confidence. “Almost familiar to her now.” This quote from the story shows that things are starting to fall into place and she is starting to feel at ease, making her realize that where she is living now can be similar to where she used to live. When around the hibiscus, it brings back memories of the flowers that they used to have in their old home. Both the mother and the daughter appreciate the flower they found because it is similar to what they had back home. For example, in the story, the mother says, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here.” This shows that they appreciate its similarity to the old hibiscus. In conclusion, the author concludes this story with that paragraph because it helps readers to understand the importance of the girl's memory of where she used to live, and how it provides her with the strength to face new challenges.

The author chooses this end to clearly show that Saeng hasn't given up on how she is living yet. It shows that even though she really loved her hometown deeply, and has many feelings and vivid memories from back then, she faced a tough situation. She had taken the test and failed, and living where she was living then just seemed to bring too much pressure on her. Although she hasn't quite adapted thoroughly, she will try her best to overcome the situations that are brought upon her. It gives the reader hope by ending the story like this, instead of just leaving the reader with the image of her buying a flower after failing a test and simply moving on with her life. For example, when she failed the test, she seemed extremely distressed and very angry. “I - I failed the test,” Saeng said. For a long moment, Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. It angered Saeng how she had to leave her happy past life for one that is different and challenging. When faced with a challenge, extreme emotional situations occur. Saeng just needed hope, and the author chose this ending to convey to the reader that there is a chance of hope. In conclusion, the author's choice of ending effectively instills hope in the reader and shows Saeng's indomitable spirit.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author Minfong Ho ends the story as she does for many cogent reasons. These reasons are likely intertwined with the themes and character development within the story. Perhaps the ending is designed to leave the reader with a sense of hope, or to emphasize the character's growth and resilience. It could also be a way to tie up loose ends and provide a satisfying conclusion to the narrative. Whatever the reasons, the author's choice of ending plays a crucial role in shaping the overall impact of the story. In conclusion, the author's ending is a carefully crafted element that contributes significantly to the story's meaning and resonance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it neatly wraps up the entire narrative and sums it all into one concise thought. It is clearly explaining that she is eagerly looking forward to the spring season when the hibiscus is in full bloom.

The reason why at the end of the story she ended it with "when they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring; when the snows melt & the geese return & this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again" is because she's making the statement that the birds have a place where they live all the time, and the plant can thrive here. In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” by @PERSON1, a teenage girl named Saeng and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. Saeng is walking home after failing her driver's test. The whole story about Saeng buying the hibiscus is in response to her failing the driving test. This setback truly crushed her spirit. The author concludes the story with the sentence, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. After reading the story, “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I believe the quote, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Was put in the story for a reason. ìWinter Hibiscusî, by Minfong Ho, is a poignant story about Saeng's transition to a new place @LOCATION1 and her discovery of her own inner strength. Saeng was full of anticipation when taking the driver's test, but unfortunately, she failed. Disappointed and dejected, she slowly walked home with her head down. On her way, she stopped at a charming florist shop because she spotted a plant that closely resembled the one she had back in her homeland. The sight of this familiar plant immediately transported her back in time, and a flood of memories from her homeland came rushing back. She carefully bought the plant and carried it home with care. Once home, she tenderly planted it in a small pot on her windowsill and vowed to take the driving test again when the geese returned. The plant was like a gentle source of encouragement to her, reminding her that she had the resilience to overcome challenges in this new place.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because the story centered around the protagonist getting accustomed to the cyclical nature of things in the natural world. This conclusion effectively ties up the story's theme of acceptance and adaptation to the repeating cycles of nature, which is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph.

I think the author includes that because she might have faced difficulties and failed in some aspects. The author uses this sentence to conclude the story to vividly show that Saeng's hope is fully restored. Throughout the story, Saeng is deeply sad as she constantly misses her home. I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph to clearly show that Saeng won't give up and will keep trying with determination. In the story “winter hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I believe that the author ended the story with that paragraph because it clearly shows that if the Hibiscus plant has enough inner strength to come back after a tough period and flourish vibrantly, then Saeng, too, has enough strength to bounce back and take the test again. In the story “winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with that paragraph because it seamlessly goes along with the overall theme of the story. In @CAPS1 Ho’s “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with a deeply meaningful paragraph. The author tries to convey a profound message to Saeng. In the story, a young girl named Saeng takes a test, but unfortunately, she has failed. She is determined to retake it next spring. Winter Hibiscus by @CAPS1 Ho explores one's quest for acceptance and adaptation to changes in life. Saeng is the young protagonist in the story who is dealing with her recent move to America from her homeland in Asia. After failing a test, which was quite a setback for her, Saeng spends a considerable amount of money on a flower, perhaps as a way to comfort herself. When she consoles with her mother, Saeng silently vows something to herself. Saeng vows, "when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". @CAPS1 Ho chose to end the story this way because the story represents the quest for adaptation. Single - handedly, Saeng was able to say a vow to herself that showed she had accepted her new foreign home of America, even though she will always remember her homeland with fondness and carry those memories with her as she moves forward.

The author concludes this paragraph in the article because Ron is truly in love with the plant and uses it as a kind of clock to tell her when she can take the test. The reason that the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because Saeng wants to do something good for herself. By making this vow, she is setting a goal and a time frame for herself, showing her self - determination and the ability to make positive choices in the face of challenges, which is an important step in her journey of adaptation and self - growth.

Saeng believes that because she failed the driving test, she won't be able to transition to a new country as she goes searching for her past. The narration states “and if this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This shows that she draws strength from the plant's resilience to face her challenges anew.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This ending is used to show or emphasize that if the hibiscus, a plant reminding her of her home, can thrive, then so can she. In the story, after the author failed her driving test and was walking back home, seeing the flowers reminded her of home and connected her to her past, making her feel less alone. For example, when the author says “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her,” that shows that she misses her home and the flower gave her a way to deeply connect to her memories. Also, when she says “like the geese in the distinctive V against the sky,” that shows that the geese were kind of like her; they were moving to a different place to start a new life. This makes her feel that if they can adapt and change, so will she over time. In conclusion, the ending was to further emphasize her complex feelings towards her hometown and the new town she lives in, highlighting her hope for a better future.

The author ends the story like this to illustrate the concepts of adapting, changing, or starting everything all over again. For example, the geese fly away when it gets cold, but they always come back, giving their home another chance. The hibiscus is another fine example; it buds in a specific season, usually spring, always but doesn't die in winter. It always returns. Saeng has obviously realized this and vowed to try her driver's test again because she believes it might work this time. The author was trying to spread the message of “don't give up.” By using these natural examples, the author encourages readers to persevere through difficulties.

Determination, help, strength – all are reasons why I believe the author concludes the story with the paragraph. First, determination is a key factor why Saeng will go back and take the test again. Mingfong Ho concludes “Winter Hibiscus” with the paragraph, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This ending paragraph shows that Saeng will not give up in her struggle to adapt in this new place. The author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. The author probably ended with this to clearly show the feeling that Saeng will surely return and help out again. From the story, it can be inferred that Saeng must really like to plant. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends the story with Saeng's thoughts. The thought of trying the test when the hibiscus starts budding skillfully ties the story together. In *Winter Hibiscus* by Minfong Ho, the last paragraph is a heartfelt vow by the main character, Saeng. Saeng silently pledges to retake her driver’s test when spring arrives, when the gentle warmth of the season melts the lingering snows, the geese return in their graceful flight, and her hibiscus plant begins to show delicate buds. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it infuses a sense of hope into the otherwise sad narrative. It strongly suggests that Saeng will be okay and will gradually move past her deep - seated longing for the country of her birth. “And in the warm, moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” Saeng was utterly sad and miserable. Why the author concludes the story with Saeng's silent vow - in the spring, when the snows gradually melt and the geese return in their familiar V - formation, and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take that test again - is to leave a sense of suspense. This is precisely why the author ended the story with that thought - provoking paragraph, leaving the readers to ponder Saeng's future and her journey of self - improvement.

The author concludes the story with this well - crafted paragraph. For example, it gives the story a truly good and happily - ever - after - like ending. The author ends the story with this paragraph because he wants the reader to genuinely feel like the protagonist, Saeng, is going to accomplish something significant because of the symbolic presence of the hibiscus and the geese. Minfong Ho concluded “Winter Hibiscus” with that paragraph to vividly show hope and renewal for the character Saeng. Spring, a well - known symbol, represents birth and renewal, offering a second chance for Saeng. She had previously failed what seems to be a crucial test, perhaps her citizenship test. This failure motivated her to try and recall her past, a past she deeply misses. The winter hibiscus seems to be a metaphor for herself. As the text illustrates: “it’s - it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled, still too shaky to say the words at home, fearing she might burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” her mother said quietly. “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. In the short story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, a young girl named Saeng fondly recalls her life before she moved to @LOCATION1. She deeply misses her homeland and all the cherished aspects of her previous life before arriving here. Towards the end of the story, the author includes a paragraph where Saeng vows to take her driver's test again when winter ends, when the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding. The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a specific reason. The author wants to illustrate that Saeng is as strong as the winter hibiscus, capable of surviving the harsh winter. She will be fully prepared when the tiring days of winter pass and the beautiful days of spring arrive. Saeng's mother states, “...it's strong enough to make it through the cold months... That's what matters.” Just like the winter hibiscus, Saeng is resilient and strong enough to endure the difficult winter months.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to arouse the reader's curiosity and make them yearn for more. When an author ends a chapter of a story or an episode of a show, using a cliff - hanger is often a smart strategy to keep the audience engaged. In many stories I have read, this technique is frequently employed. In my @CAPS1, the @PERSON1 book, it consistently ends with a cliff - hanger. For instance, at the end of the third book, one of the soldiers is killed, but the identity of the killer remains unknown until the next book. This keeps the readers eager to continue the story and find out what happens next.

The author concludes this story in this way to convey that the girl is not going to give up on her attempt to fit into this new country. By ending the story like this, it implies that the journey is not over. Even though she failed the test this time, the author suggests that the next time will be different. The author makes it clear that the little girl cares deeply about the test and is determined to prove to others that she can pass it. The flowers remind her of her home, and with this connection, she believes she can retake the test and do it right. This shows her unwavering spirit and determination to succeed in the new environment.

I think the author included that in the paragraph because Saeng disliked the cold weather. So, she decided to wait until the snow melts and the geese return to test the plants again. This indicates her preference for more favorable conditions. I also think she added it to show that Saeng would come back to visit her mother. Perhaps the arrival of spring, with its warmer weather and the return of the geese, would be the perfect time for her to make this visit, as it aligns with her comfort and the change in the season.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng failed the driving test, which was a setback for her. In the spring, when the weather becomes more pleasant and she has had more time to practice, she will take the test over, hoping for a better outcome.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it provides a proper closure to both Saeng and the story's arc. Saeng was deeply upset about the fact that she failed her driving test. However, towards the end of the story, she has a realization. She understands that things happen in life, and sometimes we have absolutely no control over what occurs. But when something knocks you down, you've also got to pick yourself up again. When seeing the geese flying in the sky and the beautiful hibiscus in bloom, she realizes that everyone and everything has to adapt to something new all the time. Saeng might have failed her driving test because they drive differently in Vietnam. So, she will have to adapt to the way we drive here, along with all our rules and laws. This is precisely why the author concludes the paragraph in that way.

Saeng was taking a crucial driving test, and unfortunately, she didn't quite pass it. She was extremely afraid to tell her mother the bad news because she knew her mother had high hopes for her. But she knew that she had to tell her anyway. When she finally broke the news, her mother got upset because Saeng didn't pass the test. Saeng is well - aware that right after winter's over, when the days start getting warmer and the world comes back to life, she'll be taking that same test again. She sincerely hopes she will pass it this time and finally get her driver's license.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author includes the phrase, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” because she wanted to make the story end with Saeng finding the positive views on her new home and positive outlooks in the future and have her look forward to it. Throughout the short story, Saeng happens to have a rather sad disposition about her new home. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because at the beginning of the story, Saeng went to take a driving test but didn't pass. I think the author of “Winter Hibiscus” said “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” to conclude the story for many reasons. The author of the Winter Hibiscus concludes the story with the paragraph to show the clear connection between the hibiscus and Saeng. In the short story “Winter Hibiscus”, the author ends with the main character Saeng saying that she will take the test “when the snow melts and the geese return.” I believe that the Hibiscus and the driver’s test are relevant like the blooming of a flower. She realizes that she needs to take the test and start driving to gain more independence. I think it is a good thing when people vow things to themselves as it shows self - determination and a clear goal.

He is referring to the lifestyle of Saeng and the various activities they engage in. For example, they might have regular gardening routines or community gatherings. Additionally, he is talking about what the area is like in terms of weather. Whether it is often sunny, rainy, or has distinct seasonal changes all play a part in shaping their daily lives.

The author decided to finish the story with that specific phrase deliberately to show that she will patiently wait for her next year and meticulously do all this over again. She will be eagerly waiting for it, with a steadfast determination, and do all this over again. She will be waiting for it and prove with unwavering resolve that she can do it one more time and that she is now accustomed to living there.

The author concludes this story in such a way to vividly show a new beginning in the spring. Just like how delicate flowers bloom and bud gracefully in spring, she will transform into a new and better person. The author concludes the story with this particular paragraph to clearly show that Saeng will bravely try the test again and obtain a fresh new start. Also, I firmly think that it's showing the reader that if you fail something the first time, don't be afraid to go back with courage and try it again. I also believe that the hibiscus symbolizes her because she failed the test in the cold winter and doesn't like the situation she's in. But in the warm spring when the hibiscus has budding buds on it, she's going to have a fresh start on the test and the flower will have a new and suitable environment to thrive in, just as she will find a new path forward.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because it artfully leaves you to interpret and carefully decide. It doesn't straightforwardly come out and tell you what the test was specifically for or even if she passed it successfully, that's for you to thoughtfully decide. It also leaves you curiously wondering what is going to happen until then. The ending to the story can be anything you imaginatively want it to be, it is up for your unique interpretation. To different people, it could indeed mean different and meaningful things, adding a layer of depth to the story.

The author ended the story with that paragraph because that paragraph precisely says when she is going to courageously try to take the test and make positive changes in her ever - changing life. For example, she is deeply sad in the story because she failed the test and desperately wants to go home. If she passes in the beautiful spring, she might actively try to make changes and happily live here. This is exactly why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, hinting at the possibility of a new chapter in her life.

The author concludes the story with this well - crafted paragraph to vividly show that Saeng is finally comfortable with her new “home.” After the passage mostly serves as a deep reflection of Saeng’s old life, it ends in this manner to clearly signify that she has become fully accustomed to her new way of life. For instance, it says “in the spring, and the geese return…” This simple yet powerful description shows that she is now used to the geese and the natural beauty of her new world. The author also deftly uses that paragraph at the end to convey a strong sense of release. Saeng had so many precious memories locked inside her old life that she initially couldn't grasp new ones in her new home. The author's use of this paragraph is an excellent way to close out the story because it allows the reader to vividly feel the relaxed scene of the birds flying away; it's as if Saeng is escaping her pain and finally becoming a real part of her new world. This ending leaves a lasting impression on the reader, highlighting Saeng's journey of adaptation and acceptance.

This last paragraph reveals something truly special to the reader. Saeng was given new hope through her mother's understanding and the hibiscus plant. Initially, she felt hopeless, miserable, and out - of - place upon seeing the hibiscus that so vividly reminded her of her homeland. When she came home, however, seeing the roots of the plant firmly buried in the ground gave her a new sense of determination. The flower represents her. It adapted to be able to survive in cold weather, which in Saeng's case symbolizes hard times. The roots are her past and although they are buried deep in the ground, they are not forgotten. The actual flower represents a brand - new life for Saeng in a new country. The author, Minfong Ho, skillfully gave personification or humanizing qualities to non - living things in the story. This is precisely why the author used the last paragraph and structured it in the way she did, adding depth and emotional resonance to the narrative.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph in order to clearly show Saeng's determination. It is also cleverly relating the drivers test to the hibiscus plant. It is suggesting that when everything else in nature starts coming to life, she will also accomplish something significant. She needs the motivation of her surroundings to push her forward. Throughout the story, Saeng is deeply affected by her surroundings. For example, when she's in the greenhouse, it takes her back to her childhood in a very vivid way. “It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery.... Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.” This connection between her and the environment emphasizes how important her surroundings are in shaping her journey and her ability to achieve her goals.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng finds great comfort in the plant after she failed her test. The plant serves as a powerful reminder of home and connects her with her past experiences. Even though she failed the test the first time, she firmly believes that if she studies hard and tries again, she can pass. This situation connects to the Hibiscus because in the winter, the plant appears to die, but then come spring, it is beautiful and blossoms again. Saeng feels a strong connection with the plant's rebirth and feels that she can also start over again and do well on the test. That is why the author includes the paragraph where Saeng vows to take the test again when the spring comes and the hibiscus blossoms. This inclusion highlights Saeng's resilience and hope for a better future.

The main reason why the author concludes the story saying, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" is quite significant. The author ended it like that because Saeng is basically saying that the right time will come for her to take that test. She firmly believes that she will pass it with self - belief. This ending shows Saeng's patience and her understanding that time and nature play important roles in her ability to succeed. It leaves the reader with a sense of optimism about Saeng's future and her ability to overcome challenges.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as a poignant way to convey that in due season, she will retake the test that she previously failed. She holds the firm belief that the hibiscus, a symbol of hope and resilience, will assist her in overcoming the obstacles that once hindered her. I believe that she purchased the plant right after she failed the test, perhaps seeking solace and a sign of better times. She hopes that with the blossoming of the plant, it will serve as a natural timetable, indicating to her when she is truly ready to try again and face the test with newfound confidence.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it serves as a meaningful and comprehensive summary of the events that unfolded in the story. Everything that happened to Saeng while she was at the florist is neatly summed up into something that resembles a form of vengeance, a determination to overcome her setbacks. The whole reason that Saeng was initially sad was that she failed her driving test. In the final paragraph, she makes a solemn vow to take the test again when the hibiscus begins to bud. The hibiscus that Saeng bought will start budding in the spring, a time when the snows gradually melt and nature comes back to life. The last paragraph of the story provides room for Saeng to deal with her nostalgia over the long winter season. Finally, the geese that fly south make Saeng feel a pang of sadness, but they also light a spark within her. She tells herself that she will take the driving test again when the geese return, when the hibiscus buds, and when the snows completely melt, marking a new beginning and a chance for redemption.

In the last paragraph, they are clearly trying to express what the future holds. When the harsh winter is finally over, the gentle spring will arrive, which means the hibiscus will come back to life, blooming in all its glory. It will be like a piece of home, a familiar and comforting sight. Also, the geese will return from their long - distance migration. Because of these signs of new life and renewal, she will take the quiz again. To her, it's like starting all over, wiping the slate clean and approaching the challenge with fresh hope. She sincerely hopes that this time, she will pass the quiz. Also, she has a deep love for the hibiscus. Since it will be back, maybe she will perform so much better, drawing strength and inspiration from its resilience. Overall, a new and promising time is coming, filled with the possibility of success.

I think the author of “Winter Hibiscus” finished with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because it is vividly showing us the importance of the plant and how it will act as a guiding light to help her pass. It also symbolizes that when the plant bravely buds and fights all the harsh obstacles to survive the cold winter, then she will have the strength and determination to beat the obstacles and pass her driving test. For example, in the story it says "When the snows melt and then geese return", the author is subtly relating this to Saeng and her struggle to pass her test, just like these natural elements struggling to survive the winter. It also says "Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly disappearing into the distance". This quote is a clear indication that she will rise to her challenge with courage and overcome it. All in all, this quote "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again" is significant because it is showing the similar and arduous struggles between the flower, Saeng, and the geese to overcome their challenges and finish what they started, highlighting the power of perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is rich in meaning. The author is subtly saying that when these animals and living creatures get their chance to thrive and fulfill their natural cycles, she too, will get her chance to succeed. For example, the geese will get to return to their familiar habitats after their long migration, the hibiscus will get its chance to bud and bloom after enduring the cold winter, and she will get her chance to take her driver's test. I know this because Saeng’s mother starts talking about how great the plant will be in the spring, painting a picture of its future beauty. She even says, “But it's strong enough to make it through the cold months”. This indicates that the mom is gently trying to tell her daughter that she will get a second chance, just like the hibiscus. That is why the story ends with that sentence, leaving the reader with a sense of hope and the promise of a new beginning.

Why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because it's telling about the seasons and how they change in a cyclical manner. They start off with a new season, and then there's something different. Each season brings its own unique characteristics. I think that's why the title of this story was called Winter Hibiscus. After spring comes winter. When it was spring, they had all the nice, beautiful flowers that smelled good. And when spring is gone and winter arrives, all the plants have died out and they're not going to be the same as they used to be. This seasonal change reflects the story's themes and gives it a sense of natural progression.

In “Winter Hibiscus,” by @CAPS1 Ho, Saeng does not give up; she keeps trying persistently. The author chose to end the story with the final paragraph for several reasons. Saeng states that she will retake her driving test in the spring. The author concludes the sentence at the end to state that when the plants start over - growing and the geese come back, she will try again. The author wrote the paragraph because she went back inside the house to get a dinner. The author concludes the story with this paragraph. By doing so, the author shows that Saeng is not giving up and that she has found a hobby to look forward to. The author ended the story with that specific quote because it shows the grasp in understanding the beauty and marvels of nature. Saeng spent a significant amount of money to buy a distinct flower called dok faeng - nol. Saeng was taking a driver's test to get a license but was failing it. During her test, she chanced upon that plant. Ashamed that she failed the test, she still mustered the courage to show her mother the flower she found, which was different from the one at home. Her mother, being understanding, was pleased with the flowers and understood that Saeng failed her test. Her mother said about the flower, “Its flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That's what matters”. This was a figurative speech suggesting that there's hope for Saeng to pass her test again when she has learned more and is ready to try again. And with the geese flying away for the winter and coming back in the spring, it clearly signifies a fresh new start at success, which is what Saeng is aiming for.

The author concludes this way because currently, when it is cold and unpleasant outside, it is not a suitable time to take the test.
