It is actually a very powerful last statement. Even though she failed her driver's test, she has realized that she will just have to keep being strong and be patient. Soon the geese will come back and the snow will melt, and she will “return” to take her test with a determined mindset to pass. Saeng bought the hibiscus to feel as if she were back in Vietnam, and it filled that void in her heart where she missed her homeland. “I paid nineteen dollars for it,” she says. She says it in a tone that shows she is disappointed in failing the test, and also highlights that something which is free back in Vietnam was so expensive in the United States. A hibiscus flower is tropical, and when it blooms in the spring, it symbolizes her readiness to give the test a second try. The author concludes the story with this ending because it vividly shows that if the plant manages to come back and bloom, then she will resolutely go back and take the test, making a determined effort to pass this time. This parallel gives her a strong sense of confidence that she can pass this test if the plant can endure the tough winter they are currently going through. As a result, this well - thought - out ending is why the author chose to conclude the story in such a way, leaving a powerful and inspiring message.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story by stating that she will retake the driver's test because not only will she have another go at the driver's test, but she will also gradually become more at ease in her life. It was a wise choice that the author concluded the story with this paragraph. Saeng had a deep affection for the hibiscus. The author concludes the story with this because she is suggesting that she is going to grow and develop along with the changing seasons. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author finishes the story with this last paragraph: “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author finishes the story with that paragraph because in the beginning, Saeng had bought a hibiscus plant as it had strongly reminded her of her hometown. The author concludes the paragraph like this because it clearly shows that she, during @MONTH1, is not going to give up. The story “Winter Hibiscus” is written by Minfong Ho. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with an interesting paragraph. The paragraph says “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author ended the story with that paragraph because she was not in her comfort zone. The author concludes the story with this paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt & the geese return & this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This ending is crafted so that the audience has something meaningful to think about. The author concludes the story in this manner to vividly show that she will be alright and will steadfastly remain determined. The author concluded the story with this particular sentence because she is clearly letting people know that she genuinely enjoys the beauty and tranquility of nature far more than the structured environment of school. This final statement effectively conveys her preference for the natural world.

The author concludes this paragraph in the story at this point because that's when she begins growing plants once again. She yearns to start over anew, perhaps leaving behind past troubles and embracing a fresh beginning.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it clearly explains that Saeng will make another attempt once spring arrives. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because of several causes. Saeng silently vowed to herself, which indicates that she has already calmed down. The author concludes the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to vividly show that she will make another attempt with a brand - new start. By saying she will start once the flower has bloomed and the geese have returned, she clearly means she will try again with a new and fresh start.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly show Saeng's unwavering determination despite her deep - seated sadness. She profoundly misses Vietnam, the land of her roots, but she firmly decides to take the test again next year. The author's careful choice of words in the concluding paragraph effectively conveys a palpable sense of hope and something tangible to look forward to. The author concluded the story with that particular paragraph because it seemed to be a truly important thought for "Saeng". This thought was basically the main cause of all the events in the story and the central subject around which the narrative revolved. She might also possibly have concluded the story with that particular paragraph because that was her last and most poignant memory of her previous life and lifestyle before their present place of living. The author concludes the story with “In the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because Saeng fails the test due to an unwise decision. She spends her money on a big mac, leaving her without enough funds to buy the type of flower her mother sent for. So, since Saeng failed the test, she is determined to take the test again with the aim of making her mother happy and proving her capabilities.

I believe that the author ended the story with that sentence because it provides a much - needed uplifting feeling after the story was filled with so much sadness. Saeng deeply missed her homeland, was drowning in sorrow, used the flowers as a source of relief, was heartbroken about her driving test, and truly adored the plant. So, the last sentence seems to fit in perfectly as a comforting zone, making the reader feel a bit more at ease and less burdened by the story's sadness.
