The author concludes the story with these final lines to create a strong tone of hope that effectively develops a theme. Final lines have a great impact on the reader because they are the last thing the reader reads, lingering in their minds. In this story, Saeng refers to the time “when the snow melts”. Here, the snow is symbolic of the deep sorrow she has been facing ever since she left home. At one point in the story, “Saeng broke down and wept!”. The spring is a well - known time for archetypal rebirth. So, as “the snow will melt”, her sorrow will gradually go away. This creates a tone of hope for happy times in the future. Next, Saeng refers to the time of the hibiscus budding. The hibiscus represents a comforting and intimate connection to her old country. She referred to the plant as “yet another old friend”. If the hibiscus blooms, then her new life will also flourish because she will be comforted to the point where she feels a strong sense of security. This creates a tone of hope for future comfort. The times ahead she speaks of are followed by a firm promise to take the test again despite her failure the first time. The author is using the power of hope to show that we can overcome difficulties. She is showing great optimism toward the spring and is willing to bravely face a challenge. Therefore, the author conveys a life lesson of courage through these final lines.

The author of ìWinter Hibiscusî ends the story with this paragraph because it poignantly reveals the deep - seated importance of the Winter Hibiscus. In the story, Saeng makes the difficult move from Vietnam to a new place and constantly feels a strong sense of homesickness that gnaws at her. She takes her drivers test and fails, which leaves her extremely upset and dejected. As she is in this low state, when she sees the familiar Winter Hibiscus plant, it immediately transports her back to her home in Vietnam. The Winter Hibiscus vividly reminds Saeng of the fond memories she shared with her grandmother and simple yet precious things such as her fine - toothed buffalo - horn comb and the hibiscus hedge that would always leave soft red petals floating in her well water. When seeing the familiar plant, ìSaeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.î This clearly shows how deeply important the hibiscus was to her. The author ended the story with that paragraph to show how the winter hibiscus serves as a great comfort to Saeng and will surely encourage her to prepare better and do better on her next driverís test.

After reading ìWinter Hibiscus, I can clearly tell that Saeng is a determined person with a deep - seated love for nature. It is also evident that she is extremely determined to pass the driving test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because at the beginning of the story, Saeng takes her driving test and unfortunately fails. Disheartened, she decides to walk home. As she is slowly making her way home, she unexpectedly comes across a familiar plant. This encounter immediately takes her back to her childhood world filled with warmth and nostalgia. Had she not failed the test, she would have driven back and never walked home, which means she would have never come across the plant. The author didnít want us to forget the reason she walked home, as it was this failure that led to this significant encounter. It would have never happened if she had passed the test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that next spring, Saeng will have another chance to succeed. The author skillfully shows that Saeng will relate to the blooms of the hibiscus plant and draw inspiration from them to take the test again. The author does this to leave a cliff - hanger, which effectively shows that there is more to Saengís life that is yet to unfold. In the story, Saeng is trying hard to get used to the changes in her life, and it is evident that she is having a tough time. Her mother tries her best to cheer her up, but just like the inevitable arrival of winter, Saeng has to face her setbacks. However, just as the hibiscus will bloom again in spring, Saeng will have next spring to take the driver's test again and prove herself.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph "When they come back,Ö then I will take the test again" because Saeng, much like the hibiscus, needs time to grow and develop. Saeng didn't perform well on the driving test, but she shows great resilience by saying she will try again after the snow melts and the spring arrives. After moving to a new place, Saeng often feels alone and frequently has the urge to go back home. However, deep in her heart, she believes that given time, she can face the challenges ahead. The hibiscus reminds Saeng of the flowers back in her home country, and this connection helps her realize that she has to let go of her past attachments and bravely live in the present moment, ready to embrace new opportunities.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it effectively shows Saeng being mature about the situation and being extremely confident, knowing full well that she can take the test again. When it says ìSaeng vowed silently to herself,î it implies that she has carefully thought about everything that has happened. The phrase is almost like she is making a firm decision to start over. This shows that Saeng is not letting the failure define her but is instead using it as a motivation to improve and do better in the future. By ending the story with this, the author emphasizes Saeng's growth and her positive attitude towards facing challenges.

The author concludes the story with a sentence about retaking her test when the geese are back and the hibiscus is budding because they each symbolically represent something else. The geese represent change as they change their environment in the winter, much like Saeng changes her environment by going to the plant place. The hibiscus reminds her of home since there are similar plants at her home. The hibiscus budding represents a new life, just as the one Saeng has to live in a new home. Overall, the sentence that the author ends with is used to show Saeng's life as compared to the geese and hibiscus, highlighting the themes of change and new beginnings.

Saeng was happy when the snow was gradually disappearing because she couldn't wait for spring to fully come back. She was eager to see the animals running around by her garden and to watch the beautiful geese flying in after their long and hard hibernation. So Saeng was excited to see everything grow back, as she believed that this would guarantee her to pass the test this time, marking a new and successful start in this season.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was eagerly waiting for the winter time to be completely over. After the winter time, Saeng is going to take a test again and she can plant the flower. Saeng really likes this hibiscus and she doesn't want it to die during the winter time. This conclusion ties in with Saeng's hopes and the cycle of seasons, showing her anticipation for a new start.

The author concluded this story with this paragraph because she wanted to show how the flower gave the little girl strength. The girl was in a new place and back at home where she is from there were a lot of beautiful flowers that she loved to look at. Being in a new place that didn't have these flowers really got her down and made her upset. She missed her home so she was hurting, and the only thing that sort of comforted her a little bit were the flowers. For example, the girl says, “It’s - it's not a real one...I mean, not like the kind we had at...”, here she stops because she is so upset that she can't say home. The flower she has right now isn't real but when the real one blossoms in the spring, seeing the flower will comfort her and give her the confidence to retake the test, helping her to face the new environment with more courage.

The author's conclusion explains her feelings. The author's conclusion says to me "when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test" again. What it means is that she is a new woman. For example, taking the test means that she will undergo a change. Also, what it means is that she is ready to take on new things. For instance, the test to her is a symbol of getting ready to take on a new challenge. That's what I got from the conclusion, which clearly shows the character's growth and readiness for change.

The author ends with this paragraph to vividly show that Saeng had hope. It clearly demonstrates that there is still a glimmer of hope in her situation. The ending paragraph subtly makes you kind of create your own unique ending for Saeng. I like to imagine Saeng with a big, flourishing garden next to her home, and she successfully passes the test with confidence. This imagined ending reflects the hope that the author implies through the paragraph, suggesting a positive future for Saeng.

I believe that the author concluded the story with this paragraph for several well - thought - out reasons. This final paragraph neatly draws together and unites all the elements of the concluding idea. It specifically tells us that in the spring, a season when everything is coming back to life, Saeng will find the inner strength to take the test again. These central ideas expressed in the last paragraph clearly show how Saeng and her mother have adapted to their new environment, and that new beginnings are started in the spring, as well as new possibilities arising. In the text it says, “I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. It’s flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.” This means and represents that even though life is very different here, away from Saeng's home in Vietnam, they will adapt and survive in their own resilient way, just like the winter hibiscus.

The author concludes the story the way she does because it clearly shows that Saeng needs to fully heal from the disappointment of failing the test before she can take it again. Saeng already has the self - awareness that she can heal. She realizes that she has gradually gotten used to where she now lives. Things in her new land, like the gentle sound of geese flying overhead, are now “familiar to her”. The narrator of the story says, “...she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become … almost familiar to her now.” Things in Saeng's new home had been so strange to her at first, but she has healed and grown accustomed to them. Saeng has also healed from the pain of leaving her original home of Vietnam. She was deeply sad to leave her home, “A work so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her,” but with time, she had healed. Saeng remembers the flowers that she had known in Vietnam as “old friends”, showing that it no longer hurts her to remember them. When Saeng heals from failing her driving test, just like she had healed when moving from Vietnam to the United States, she can re - visit the test, without the pain of past failure clouding her mind.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it clearly shows the character, Saeng, was going to adapt to their new home and stay strong. I believe, when Saeng’s mother says, “It's flowers aren’t as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus,” I think Saeng’s mother is also sort of thinking about Saeng. It's almost as if she's saying that the move here has left some emotional scars on Saeng, but she will be strong and survive the change. Just like anyone who has failed a test, she will study more intently and try harder to pass it next time. Saeng isn't going to give up easily and she'll keep holding on firmly to make it through. Saeng knows it's hard to adjust to the changes in life, but with a little courage and hard work, it will be a manageable challenge. If she believes in herself whole - heartedly, she'll be able to get situated in this new place and build a fulfilling life.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself. In the spring, when the thick snow melts away and the geese return from their migration, and this winter hibiscus is starting to bud, then I will take that test again. There are many reasons for this vow. One is that when winter comes and brings all the heavy snow, it destroys her garden. So that's why she wants it to be spring again, so she can start growing things anew in her garden. She has to take a test on the things that she is growing to make sure it is safe for someone to eat it. That's why I think the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” is so significant. It represents Saeng's hope for a new start and her determination to overcome the setbacks of winter and prove herself through the test once the favorable season arrives.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concluded the story with an interesting paragraph. It was, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the gentle snow melts and the geese gracefully return and this beautiful hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” (@NUM1). This shows that the young girl is gradually adapting to her new country and sincerely hopes to do better in the spring. The reason the author ended the story with this paragraph is because it clearly shows that the girl has successfully adapted to her new country and is firmly determined to get stronger as time goes on. She is saying when the hibiscus returns in all its splendor, she will be fully ready to take the test again and not fail it, which reflects her growth and resilience.

The Hibiscus is budding means that the delicate flower was steadily growing. That is a flower with lots of vivid and bright colors that can light up any space, and nothing else can beat it in terms of its charm. The reason another flower can’t beat it is because that flower represents so many wonderful things, such as hope and beauty, and it is one of the most naturally - born and exquisite flowers around, a true marvel of nature.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because that was precisely how he wanted the story to end. He deliberately wanted to end the story with her quietly talking to herself, creating an intimate and thought - provoking moment that leaves a lasting impression on the readers, allowing them to feel the character's innermost thoughts and emotions.

People have to adapt to different cultures if they move to a new place. They could do this in a variety of ways, including making new friends in the local community and gradually adjusting to the unique features of the area. However, when adjusting to a new area, you should still fondly remember your past home as well. This is what Minfong Ho is trying to display in the ending paragraph of the story, “Winter Hibiscus”. In the story, a teenage girl named Saeng moved from Vietnam to the @LOCATION2. She has various precious remembrances of her past home while visiting a plant store. She carefully buys a plant that was common in Vietnam and lovingly plants it in her garden. The last paragraph of the story says “In the spring, when the soft snow melts and the geese return in formation and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that driving test again”. This shows Saeng’s strong desire to fit in with this new culture, by taking the driving test, as well as remember her past, by keeping the flower. This last paragraph effectively summarizes Saeng’s complex emotion for her old country as well as her unwavering determination to succeed here.

Because she was earnestly promising herself that when the warm spring comes back with its pleasant breeze and blooming nature, then she will bravely take the driver's test again. This self - promise shows her determination to overcome the previous setback and move forward in her new life.

The author concludes with this paragraph to vividly show her unwavering determination. When she says, “...when the snows melt and the geese return and his hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Saeng is clearly explaining how the geese have the strong determination to fly back and that the hibiscus has the firm determination to bud again. So, she wonders why she shouldn't have the determination and confidence to take the test again. Saeng said, “I - I failed the test.” It seems as if failing the driving test made her feel like she was going to fail in the new country. But after she witnessed the geese's and hibiscus's determination through harsh conditions, she became firmly determined to try the test again, believing that she could overcome this setback.

The author concludes this story with that paragraph to clearly explain how she already took the test and it is now winter. She plans to retake the test again when all of the flowers and plants come back to life and start anew. Saeng wants to take the test again to show her mother that she can pass it successfully. She bought a plant called dorl Faeng - noi for nineteen dollars, hoping to help her mother not be disappointed. However, mother was disappointed that she spent that much money on a plant, but Saeng still held onto her hope of passing the test to prove herself.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it clearly shows that when she sees the things from her home and living environment, it will greatly comfort her in what she does. The author seems like she needs things from her homeland that can help her make the best of things and bring back good memories of her earlier life. I think that whenever I want to do a good job, it helps to think of the good things that mean a lot to me so that I will be happy and eager to do well. The author is smart to want to see those things for her to retake her test because if she sees her plant doing well and sees the memory of the geese again, it will be like a sign of good luck for her, giving her the confidence to face the test.

The author chooses to end the story with such a paragraph as this in order to show that Saeng has received a new burst of hope from her memories and the newly familiar things in her new home. The combination of the failed driver’s test and being away from her original home caused Saeng to feel a great deal of loss. While Saeng is in the flower shop, “aware of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” Through the rest of the story, Saeng is shown to still be down, and the reader is left unsure if she will be alright. Then her recovery begins with the presence of familiar things. “The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered,”, “The winter hibiscus was in the ground now”, and, “overhead a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and – yes – familiar to Saeng now.” This realization that the geese are familiar to her gives way to a new realization and a new wave of hope. She recognizes the fact that she is now coming to be familiar with many of the things about her new home that she had initially thought to be strange. This is what the final paragraph explains to the reader. It summarizes Saeng’s newfound hope that she will learn to not just live in her new home, but to truly thrive in it, making a new and fulfilling life for herself.

The author concludes the story with this statement because it shows that to her the hibiscus symbolizes overcoming obstacles. It symbolizes this because she says “...and the geese return and this is budding, I will take that test again” (Ho @NUM1). This clearly shows that even though she failed it this time, when the hibiscus gets bigger, she will retake the test. It represents her ability to overcome obstacles. Also, I believe that this symbolizes overcoming obstacles because it “gives her strength from her old country”. This shows that it symbolizes overcoming obstacles because it will help her overcome this test. It will do this by giving her strength or comforting her. From this, you can tell that the author ends the story with this statement to emphasize the power of the hibiscus as a symbol of her ability to face and overcome challenges in her new life.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it clearly indicates that Saeng is confident and is genuinely willing to go back and take the test. Saeng feels good about herself, having found the inner strength and motivation, and whole - heartedly wants to do this to prove herself.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was taking a crucial test. In the story, there are some specific quotes to support my response. “I - I failed the test,” Saeng said. This clearly shows that she was taking a test about gardening, a subject that was very important in their life. Another reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the story was centered around spring, gardening, and the significance of life to them. The paragraph vividly talks about spring, and the beautiful flowers that bloom. The daughter and mother live off of the plants by carefully planting vegetables, and delicious fruits, making gardening a way of life for them.

The last paragraph of the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho is extremely important to the story. The last paragraph leaves a definite and clear - cut ending so the reader knows exactly what is going to happen in the future. This paragraph is a very significant ending to the story because it represents powerful symbols in the story. The author concludes that the hibiscus is of great importance to her. Along with the hibiscus, it also shows that the geese flying and the slow melting of the snow represent a fresh start and a brand - new beginning. These symbols are important to her in that they give her a well - deserved chance to start over, and she clearly sees that hope in the winter hibiscus, making it a powerful and meaningful conclusion.

Saeng was very distraught knowing that she didn't pass the test. To her, it felt as though it was a huge let - down or a deep disappointment. This setback, however, only made her more determined. This sentence shows the strong ambition and unwavering determination that Saeng has so that she will be able to pass this test and achieve her goals.

The author concludes the story with “when they come back …” to show how Saeng has changed significantly throughout the plot of the story. In the beginning, she refers to her new home as “walking into another world.” As a teenager, she had to move from Vietnam, where traditions are so much different than in the United States. However, there is one plant that is similar, the winter Hibiscus. The plant serves as a strong connection between her previous life and home to the life and home she lives now. It was extremely hard for her to adapt to the situation of moving, but the plant created familiar scents and the “familiar fragrance” which “filled her lungs.” It was even difficult for Saeng to say the words “at home” without bursting into tears. Once the winter Hibiscus was in the ground, it gradually changed Saeng and she finally realized that she needed to appreciate what she had. In conclusion, the author ended the story with that paragraph because it clearly showed how much the plant resembled Saeng and how her mindset on life was completely altered.

I feel that the author concludes the story with this phrase as a way of subtly showing how Saeng is gradually adopting to her new home, yet still deeply valueing her old one. The gist of the sentence is quite clear: Saeng will take her test again in the spring, which vividly shows her remarkable perseverance. However, the sentence also interestingly shows how Saeng is coming to know her new land. She says, “when the snows melt and the geese return”; this is important because the geese and the snow are characteristic elements of her now home, and she now whole - heartedly accepts them. However, Saeng also says, “when this hibiscus is budding,” and this clearly shows how Saeng is still constantly thinking of her old home, because the plant is her precious connection to the cherished memories of Vietnam. Therefore, I feel that the author is effectively showing how Saeng is growing up and living with changes in her life by ending the story with this meaningful statement.

I think that the author is trying to convey today is that when it is winter, the hibiscus is bravely trying to withstand the cold. While most plants simply wither and die at the onset of winter, the hibiscus must face the harsh cold head - on, showing its tenacious nature. This resilience of the hibiscus may be a symbol of something deeper, perhaps representing a similar spirit in the face of adversity.

I think the author includes this because she doesn't want to leave her audience in a state of uncertainty, guessing about what would happen next. Then “I will take the test again.” This quote clearly indicates that she might have failed the test related to the plant, but she is resolute and will never give up. She firmly believes that when spring comes, she is going to try again with renewed determination. I feel as though the author added this to give a better understanding of how it feels to leave your homeland and come to a place you don't know or understand, such as the flower situation in the story. When she thought about the plants and how they smelt, it brought back the old feelings that she had about her homeland and how close she was with her grandmother. She was so accustomed to plants being free and growing in the open rather than seeing them confined in pots and not having the space to grow. By seeing all this, it got Saeng to break down and cry. In conclusion, I feel as though the author added the paragraph in the end for better understanding and also to let you know that Saeng may be in a new place with a new culture, but she will never give up on that test until she feels that she has passed it successfully.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” purposely had that last paragraph in there. Honestly, the story is much better with it too. In the last paragraph when it says “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This statement holds great significance. When the author writes about all those things in nature that will happen, it powerfully symbolizes re - birth and a fresh start, a brand - new chance, and that is precisely what Saeng needs with her drivers license test. The author put it very powerfully, incorporating those symbols to show hope for the girl to make it through her tough time. Finally, the story has a strong sense of roundness and comes to a satisfying end with that last paragraph, making the story feel complete and well - crafted.

The reason I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph was because it is a good learning story from which you can learn something valuable. The author did that so you can get a more in - depth understanding of the story. It said “Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam.” So from reading that, it clearly tells me that it is informing you what happened right before the story took place. This way, you can get a better grasp of the context. To me, it is neatly wrapping it all up for you. That's why I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph, providing a clear and comprehensive ending to the narrative.

I believe the author of “Winter Hibiscus” ends the story like she did because Saeng, having failed the test initially, agrees to take the test again. She wants to take the test when the snow melts, the geese return and the hibiscus is budding. In other words, when the vibrant season of spring has come, she will be ready to face the test with renewed determination. Saeng states in the story “it’s the flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” I think Saeng is using this resilient plant as a guiding light since she just moved from Vietnam, a place far different from her current environment. She plans to persevere and make it, using the plant as a powerful symbol of hope and strength. She will try again for her driver's license at the start of spring, aiming to overcome this challenge.

The author used "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because it is resembling that her mother, much like nature in spring, is refreshing, waking, and restoring itself. And Saeng said she would retake the driving test when that rejuvenating time arrives. She was really sad she failed the test. “I – I failed the test,” she uttered, and her tone clearly showed that she seemed to be a mix of embarrassment and deep sadness. So that last paragraph in the story does a good job of describing what Saeng is going to do. She is going to look on the bright side of things and restore herself, gathering the courage and skills to come back and pass the test, just as nature recovers from the cold of winter.

I, the narrator, appreciate this paragraph in the story because hibiscus is a valuable plant, and having a garden is your own personal decision. Just like her mother, who has a penchant for growing hot peppers, you can choose what to cultivate. A garden is a way to experience diversity, like the different types of foods you can plant and the various plants in the world. There are, for example, roses, lilies, and other plants like that. Each plant in the garden adds its own unique touch, whether it's the color, the smell, or the taste. It's a small world of nature that you can create and nurture, making the garden a special and meaningful place.

The author ends the story with that paragraph because she is trying to overcome an obstacle. Failing the driver's test was a significant setback for Saeng, but she is not one to give up easily. So she plans to take it again. She plans to use the hibiscus as motivation, because the winter for the hibiscus, with its harsh conditions, is like overcoming an obstacle. Just as the hibiscus endures the cold and emerges stronger, Saeng will face her challenges head - on. She will draw inspiration from the plant's resilience and work hard to pass the test on her next attempt, showing that setbacks are just temporary and can be overcome with determination.

Why I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because I think it's showing how much passing the driving test actually means to her. It's not just about getting a license; it represents a step towards independence and achievement. By showing that she cares deeply about this goal, Saeng demonstrates her commitment and determination. And because she cares so much, she will take the test again. She won't let a single failure stop her from reaching her objective. This conclusion emphasizes her strong will and the importance of perseverance in the face of difficulties.

She ends the story with that paragraph because she sincerely wants to let everyone know that she feels most at ease and comfortable in the spring. It also clearly states that she can hardly wait for the geese to return and the hibiscus to start budding as it is truly her favorite time of the year, a time filled with new beginnings and fresh hope.

Saeng is not comfortable in her surroundings as the place is so different from where she used to live, and she has not fully adapted to the changes from the place she moved. She spots the hibiscus and decides to go buy it, because it vividly reminds her of her home in @LOCATION2. When she brings it home, her mother seems shocked at first by the relatively high price Saeng had paid, but is then more understanding and sympathetic when she realizes Saeng misses @LOCATION2. Saeng says she is going to retake her test in the spring. She is also subtly implying that she is going to change her negative attitude about living in @LOCATION1 and try to embrace the new environment.

I think the author concludes that in the story because he is specifically saying that when the geese are coming back, it symbolizes the arrival of a new and promising season, which might bring positive changes and new opportunities in the story.

The author concludes that because she wants to vividly show that Saeng was not giving up easily. I say this because she moved to a completely unfamiliar place where she didn't like the environment and knew no one. The author is trying to tell us that no matter what difficulties we face, we shouldn't give up and should always have faith. At the end, Saeng has strong faith in herself that she can pass the test next time. By @MONTH1, she might have realized that just because you're in a place you don't want to be, it doesn't mean you can't move forward and make the best of the situation.

The author concludes the story like that to effectively give the reader the clear idea that you can't just quit if you fail. When Saeng firmly said that when spring comes around she will return and take the test again, that strongly shows that she will not give up easily and that life will surely go on with new hopes and possibilities. That's precisely why I think the author chose to conclude the story in such a meaningful way.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph to clearly show that she does not want to give up on fighting her homesickness. The first time she bought that particular plant, it vividly brought back warm memories of her old home and it clearly showed how much she deeply missed it there. By firmly saying she'll do the test again, it shows that she doesn't want to let this feeling of homesickness defeat her in her new home and her new life. This determination in the face of homesickness is a powerful message within the story.

The author concludes Saeng's vow in the story to effectively show that Saeng can and does have the real ability to overcome obstacles. Saeng genuinely feels like she is a failure due to her recent setbacks. Her hibiscus beautifully represents courage to overcome her significant obstacle which is her driving test that she unfortunately failed. The geese symbolically represent survival and the spirit to never give up, encouraging her to keep trying her hardest to achieve success. This combination of symbols emphasizes Saeng's potential for growth.

The author concludes the story with this because the girl in the story is almost exactly like the flower itself. Just as the flower will surely blossom in its own time, Saeng will bravely take the test again. Both are set to receive a fresh start on things, a new beginning full of hope. Finishing the story this way left the reader feeling positively uplifted. It was a short ending but one with a profound and deep - seated meaning. “...and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think the last sentence is truly inspirational and it makes you want to start out fresh, just as Saeng plans to do. This ending leaves a lasting impression on the reader.

The author ends the story with “When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” for many good and valid reasons. Some reasons are, that she will steadily keep moving on and gradually adapt to her new life in Canada. She is going to make changes to her way of life and sincerely try to fit in with her new culture. She is also going to have to relive the painful memory of her grandmother again and wants to handle it better. “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eye now swept over her.” She wants to be able to handle the loss more gracefully. The author wants to strongly emphasize that the story is not yet over and there is still more growth and change to come for Saeng.

There are many reasons the narrator could have ended with this paragraph. One reason is that it's the start of the cold winter season, so the hibiscus won't return until the warm spring arrives. Also, it's the end of the story, so it's a very good way to end it because it aligns with the natural cycle of the hibiscus and the ending of the narrative. The last paragraph also neatly summarizes up the story and it's short and sweet. Which makes it a truly great ending to the story. It's not like most endings to a story, so it's delightfully unique. Because most stories aren't about nature and its connection to the characters' lives. In conclusion, there are many well - thought - out reasons the narrator could have chosen to end the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with his paragraph to show how people can regain their determination. In the beginning of the story, Saeng is disheartened after failing her driving test. When she sees the Hibiscus, she is filled with vivid memories of the past and begins to weep. Her mother's kindness causes Saeng to draw strength from the flower, which, as her mother says, is "strong enough to make it through the cold months here." Realizing that the Hibiscus will bud in the spring, Saeng renews her determination to pass the test, ready to face the challenge with newfound resolve.

The author ends with this response because he is trying to say that Saeng will repeat her actions but this time be more helpful in the garden for her mother. She will try harder with her school work and focus less on gardening, aiming to strike a better balance in her life and make progress in both areas.

Saeng's personality in this story shows determination and confidence. I think she feels that she could handle more experienced tasks on different plants. I also think this is a perfect hobby experience for someone who loves plants. I feel that by @MONTH1, Saeng may have accomplished her goals of planting. I think she @MONTH1 might want to pursue her career in gardening. When she stated that when the plants come back around, she would take the test again. I think she means that she is willing to explore more plants. I think she @MONTH1 may have got this experience of planting from her mother. To me, this @MONTH1 may have been a family tradition. Saeng will probably have kids and teach them about different types of flowers, continuing this cherished family legacy.

The author ended the story with the paragraph in order to show that Saeng is looking forward to her life with a positive outlook. It shows that she is not going to be depressed by the change in her life anymore. The hibiscus is used as a device for this story's plot. When changes happen with the hibiscus, changes happen in the story. At first, Saeng is without the hibiscus and feels hopeless. When she sees it, she remembers her past and is sad. Once she plants it, things start to look up. She begins to accept the change when the last paragraph says, "when they come back... and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." It clearly shows that Saeng is looking at her future positively, and with this positive change, the hibiscus is now beginning to bloom. The author concludes the story in a symbolic way that effectively helps express the story's themes, leaving a lasting impression on the reader.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph "Saeng vowed silently to herself" because Saeng wants to act in proper time and season. During the "winter season", the land or soil was so cold that plants were not able to grow properly. "Hibiscus costs nineteen dollars", and she Saeng failed the test. "There was a frail, wiry beauty to her Saeng mother that touched Saeng deeply." Her mother shines when she works on the plants. These all are the descriptions that conclude events in the past which Saeng wants to correct and shine like her mother and also to pass the test, setting a new course for herself.

At the end of the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng says, “when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” When she says this, she is referring to her driver's test. She says she will take the test again because she is reminded that her family didn't give up. They moved to @LOCATION1 for a fresh start. “A plant she had forgotten drew her back to her childhood world.” She sees these flowers after failing the test, which reminds her that she has never given up before. So, she won't give up now either. The flowers symbolize resilience and the hope of a new beginning, just as she hopes to pass the test and start afresh.

The author is trying to convey a sense of hope for Saeng in her new country. After noting that she failed her test, which is probably a citizenship test, the author wants to conclude the story with something that reassures the reader. It is obvious that this test was important because Saeng could not even look her mother in the eye out of feelings of disappointment and guilt. This was probably why she bought the flower for her mother as a way to express her unspoken emotions and her determination to do better. The ending reassures the reader so that you don't wonder how it will work out for Saeng. It gives the impression that despite the setback, there is still a positive future ahead for her.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to tell us that she will try and find that flower to bring back memories of her old home. To show us that they will be coming back again, it will survive even though it's not from where she originally wanted it to be from. In the story, it says, “I failed the test,” meaning Saeng had bought the hibiscus that wasn't real or what she thought it was not what she wanted it to be. This disappointment with the flower mirrors her disappointment with failing the test. In the last paragraph, she says she will take that test again. Saying she will find the winter hibiscus that is how it used to be in the homeland. She's hoping they survive and hoping she finds a flower like it because in that last paragraph it says, “Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” meaning she hopes and prays she will find one like her old homeland, and with that renewed hope, she will succeed in the test.

The author was trying to end the story quickly, which is why he ended it with this one. By choosing this particular ending, the author likely aimed to leave a concise and impactful impression on the reader. Perhaps the story had reached a point where a quick conclusion was fitting to maintain the overall tone and message. It might also have been a way to avoid over - elaborating and to let the reader draw their own conclusions based on the events leading up to the end. In this way, the abruptness of the ending can be seen as a deliberate literary choice.

When spring comes and all the snow melts, then she is going to plant new seeds. The author concludes that because she didn't do well on the test the first time. But next year, she is going to work with her plants, nurturing them with care and patience. This process of working with the plants will not only be a way to connect with nature but also a means of building her confidence and determination. Then she will take the test again so she can pass it. The author put that in the conclusion because he doesn't want people to think that she just worries about the plants. Instead, the plants are a symbol of her growth and her ability to overcome challenges, just as she hopes to overcome the hurdle of passing the test.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus", it revolves around a girl named Saeng, along with her mother and grandmother. Flowers hold great beauty in their eyes, and they spend the whole day planting them. They are also engaged in activities like picking them and arranging them. As the text mentions, “Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye”. This shows a certain tension or unease in their relationship at that moment.

The author concludes the story with the saying because it clearly shows that the protagonist has confidence in herself. Despite not passing the test, she realizes that she can take it again and knows deep down that she can pass it. Initially, she was quite upset about the test result. However, when her mother talked to her, her mother's kind words made her feel good and confident enough to retake the test. She firmly believes she can pass this time. That's precisely why I think the author concludes the story with that saying at the end, as it perfectly captures the character's growth in confidence.

This paragraph means that when winter finally comes to an end and the geese return from the south, and her favorite plant that used to be in her old country makes its reappearance, she will once again attempt what she was trying to do before. This time, she has more self - assurance. She believes that with the change of season and the return of familiar elements, she can face the challenge with a newfound determination. This is what I think this paragraph truly means.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it effectively sums everything up and resolves the conflict of her failing her driver's test. When Saeng said, “… I will take that test again”, it clearly demonstrated that she is determined to pass the test and is willing to try once more. Since the conflict has been successfully solved at this point, to keep the story going, one would typically have to introduce a new conflict. However, the author decides to end it here. This excerpt from the last paragraph also draws a parallel between Saeng's difficulty in getting her driver's license and the hardships that geese face. Just as geese encounter challenges during their journey, Saeng has faced hardships in obtaining her license. But like the geese, she is ready to go back and face those hardships again with courage.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author ends the story in a well - mannered and carefully crafted way. The author chose to end with that paragraph to show that Saeng was not going to give up, even though she was far away from home. At the beginning of the story, she was in a downward spiral. She had failed a test, and the sight of the hibiscus made her feel nostalgic. When she got home, her mother greeted her with kind words, acting almost like an anti - depressant. Her mother made food without peppers and bitter melons, which was a small but significant gesture. This kind of loving act made Saeng see the good in life, causing her not to give up and be confident that she will pass the test in the future.

Well in the story, Saeng fails her driving test. When she is walking home dejectedly, she sees a familiar plant by the roadside. Intrigued, she then goes to a florist and finds out the plant is called a hibiscus. She then buys the plant with the little money she has because it vividly reminds her of her homeland and the carefree days of her childhood. It also reminds her of her beloved grandmother who she left behind so now she feels deeply connected to the plant. Also, as she stands there with the plant in her hand, she sees geese fly over head heading south for the winter. So she says “When they come back,” so she means when the geese fly north for @DATE1. And when “the snow melts,” so when it becomes warmer and the beautiful season of spring starts. When “this hibiscus is budding,” so when spring comes and the plant starts to bloom she will “take that test again.” So she says she will take the driving test that she failed when spring comes. She gives herself the winter to practice diligently and get ready for the test. She vows to herself that come spring she will be ready to take the test and this time she will pass.

She said this to show the determination it takes to make it in life. No matter how many times you fail, you need to gather your strength and get back up and try again. She displays her courage in this very way. It takes a great deal of inner strength for someone to face failure and then have the resolve to get back up and try again on the same thing. She isn't willing to simply accept failure as her fate. Instead, she's trying to redeem her failure, so she firmly says she'll try again. That is why she ended the story that way, leaving a powerful message of perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph. I think the author did this so that people who read the story will have a clear idea of what she is going to do next spring. They might even be inspired to create another story in their minds. By ending the story this way, the readers will know that she will take the test in the spring, which gives a sense of anticipation and closure to the narrative. It allows the readers to envision her future steps and feel more connected to the character's journey.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with that paragraph because when the cold winter hits, the plant she likes will gradually disappear. The flower gave her good luck, so she said “when the snow melts in the spring and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The flower was very important to her. She said, “that rich, sweet scent that was familiar too.” She was talking about how the flower's smell compares to her grandmother's shell; it was the same comforting and nostalgic aroma that brought back warm memories. This connection to the flower and the promise related to it make the ending of the story meaningful.

The author concludes the story like this because she is going to come back and do the same thing next year. It seems that whatever action or event was described in the story is part of a recurring cycle for her. By ending the story in this way, the author suggests that there is a continuity to her experiences. It leaves the readers with the thought that the character's journey will continue, and they can look forward to what might happen in the next iteration of this annual event. It gives a sense of the character's perseverance and the ongoing nature of her life's path.

The author concludes the story with that because she wants to retake the test. She deeply desires to prove herself and improve her result. Because she wants to pass the test for her mother, who has always supported and believed in her. So she carefully selected and brought home the flower to sincerely apologize to her mother for her previous failure.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because everything in the story will repeat, just like the regular cycle of season changes. You will not be able to plant nor grow in the winter, as it is a harsh and unforgiving time. For example, she talked about how the plants are nothing like her home, with its familiar landscapes and climates. But she has to adapt to the fact she’s not home, and adjust to her new and somewhat alien environment. I say this because if she doesn't, she will just be an unhappy person constantly worrying about where she came from, unable to move forward in her new life.

The author concludes the response by saying that when spring comes and the hibiscus is budding she will take the test again. This is because I think she feels a glimmer of hope and unwavering faith. I say this because the girl just moved away from her home and feels horribly lonesome and depressed, as the new place lacks the warmth and familiarity of her old home. She is nostalgic for her past and when she sees the plant it gives her a sense of comfort like she is home again. When she says “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think she says this because she is upset because she failed her test and the plant gives her a sense of comfort which gives her faith and hope that she will pass the test in spring, marking a new beginning in her life.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself. In the spring, when the snow gradually melts and the geese gracefully return and this hibiscus is gently budding, then I will take that test again, determined to achieve a better outcome.

In “@CAPS1 Hibiscus” by @PERSON1, the author chose the last paragraph because it perfectly matched the tone, the hope, and the representation of the essay. The tone of the story is more of a depressed and full - of - sorrow mood because she failed the driver's test so she is very upset. Her memories of her old country start to get to her when she sees the winter hibiscus. “And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” She misses Vietnam very much and seeing this plant in this store gives her like vivid flashbacks. The winter starts to give her the feeling that all hope is lost. “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” To her, the strange things are starting to feel the same year by year, with no new hope, no new anything, just the same old thing day by day. This plant really starts to tear her apart just purely from the representation. “She found that she was still too shaky to say the word at home, lest she burst into tears again.” She can't say home because home isn't hers in the United States but in Vietnam. This winter hibiscus gives Saeng an explosion of immense emotions all having to do with her past. So the last paragraph is more about how when her hope returns in spring she will just try again. Tone, hope, and representation all support the last paragraph so that's why it fits when it does, making the conclusion a perfect wrap - up for the story.

This was a truly captivating story that vividly showed all the hardships this young girl has endured. The author concluded it in a highly engaging way. When the story ended, I couldn't help but think about how beautifully it wrapped up. I firmly believe the author did an excellent job. She managed to depict all the struggles that Saeng had gone through, as if they were the frigid winter. Then, as the author stated, “as the snow melts away; …”, I think this vividly shows that even though Saeng's problems seem endless and harsh, one day they will disappear, and things will turn beautiful again, just like a flower budding in the springtime. Moreover, she did a great job because throughout the story, I could deeply feel her pain. I felt as if I was right there with her due to her use of descriptive words like “exploding, shock, intense” and others to describe how sudden everything was. Then, when she ended it, it was as if she was showing us Saeng's hope for a better future, even though things aren't the way they were back home! The author's skillful storytelling truly made this a memorable experience.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph - “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This is because she deeply feels that when the hibiscus blooms, she too can bloom by successfully passing the test. Also, Saeng is closely relating herself to the hibiscus. “Its flower isn't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through in here, this winter hibiscus.” Her mother is gently trying to tell her that she can be strong as well. She too can persevere through the cold and difficult months. “Like the geese she lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.” Just like the geese, Saeng is gradually realizing to be proud of herself and understand that there will be other chances. One shouldn't always doubt themselves because there will be other opportunities. One shouldn't be afraid to try again and keep moving forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she means she will return after winter to carefully take care of it. The author strategically places this in the ending paragraph because he is clearly showing how much she cares about this plant as she takes meticulous care of it since it vividly reminds her of her hometown. So, that is the definite reason she takes such good and attentive care of it so that she will always have something with her to fondly remind her of her home. This connection to the plant adds a poignant touch to the story's conclusion.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph about the geese because it clearly shows how Saeng, just like the geese, will successfully adapt to her new environment. It demonstrates that she will do whatever is necessary in order to survive, much like the geese have to do. She will bravely take the test again and will not easily give up. The paragraph shows how she sincerely wants to adapt to the new country. For example, the narration states, “… she noticed the tear - stains on her daughter's cheeks and her puffy eyes” [No]. This example clearly shows how Saeng is not yet accustomed to being in the new country and that she does not like it at present. However, she will gradually get used to it and do her very best to do so, as clearly shown in the closing paragraph. Also, the narration states, “… she admitted to herself, she much preferred it to a Big Mac” [Ho]. This proves how even though she might not like things at times, Saeng is willing to bravely try them to get used to the new country. The narration states, “… she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become familiar to her now”. Saeng is steadily getting more and more used to her surroundings and is adapting to them, just like the geese adapt, which is the exact reason the author ended the story with the paragraph about geese.

The reason why the author wrote the conclusion paragraph was to clearly show that Saeng is eagerly looking forward to a brighter future. Saeng is earnestly hoping to see the geese once more that bring back fond memories of her homeland and that she wants to successfully pass the driving test. In this story, I truly feel as though Saeng is a very sentimental person. She holds on to the memories associated with the geese and her homeland tightly. That is why I firmly think that is the reason the author wrote the conclusion paragraph. It not only gives a sense of hope for Saeng but also a glimpse into her emotional depth and longing for a better life.

He concludes this paragraph in the story because it has a pleasant and harmonious sound, and it aims to show the readers that no matter what hardships or setbacks you encounter in life, you should just keep on doing what you think is best for you. Just like the flower that perseveres, it keeps coming back for more after going through all that tough and challenging situation. This is a powerful message that encourages us to stay true to ourselves and our paths.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for a specific reason. The hibiscus, with its vibrant colors and unique appearance, reminds her vividly of Vietnam, a place filled with memories and emotions. The geese, flying in formation across the sky, remind her of her current home, a place where she has found a new sense of belonging. These two things, the hibiscus and the geese, serve as sources of strength and inspiration for her. Therefore, she will take the test when they return, confident in her abilities. She firmly believes that she can pass the test when the flower and the geese are present in her life, as they symbolize hope and resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it clearly shows that Saeng is starting to take responsibility for her school work now. Previously, in the story, she made it very obvious that she cared more about the garden, spending a lot of time nurturing the plants and enjoying the beauty of nature, than about her school tasks. However, this change in her attitude indicates a positive development in her character, suggesting that she is maturing and understanding the importance of balancing her interests and responsibilities.

Saeng was talking about testing the plants, carefully observing to see if the geese liked where she had planted them. I know this because she specifically mentioned geese in the last paragraph, and it was described that the geese seemed to give an affirmative response, as if they said “yes,” when she planted the hibiscus. This interaction between Saeng, the plants, and the geese shows her thoughtfulness and her connection with nature, and it also implies that she is making decisions based on the well - being of the environment around her.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the story was mostly centered around the hibiscus. Saeng was saying that when it’s spring and this beautiful hibiscus is budding, with its delicate petals starting to unfurl, then she will take the test again. The hibiscus, with its rich cultural and emotional significance, reminded her of her homeland in the past, a place full of warmth, traditions, and cherished memories. This connection to her roots gives her the courage and motivation to face the test once more.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because at the end, the text is talking of a new beginning. This new start is significant as it shows a shift in the character's situation. Also, what it’s going to be at the new beginning is clear when she says that she is going to take the test again, indicating a fresh attempt and a chance for improvement.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she has a better state of mind as she found a flower that vividly reminds her of her homeland. This connection to her roots gives her a sense of comfort. She is afraid that her parents are going to be mad at her for not passing the test, so, as a way to ease her guilt, she buys a flower that she sees and which serves as a reminder of home. When she gets home and tells her mom how much she paid for the flower and how she didn’t pass, her mother is upset for only a second. Then, she shows understanding of what her daughter is going through. By the end of the story, she has more confidence that she will succeed next time, as the support from her mother has bolstered her spirit.

Minfong Ho ended the story with a phrase dialogue because it was directly about the main topic of the story. Saeng was tasked to buy a plant and bring it home. However, when she did so, her mother did not approve. The narrative states "You what?" Her mother stared at her incredulously" (Ho). When her mother said this, it clearly showed that she was displeased with Saeng's action. The narrative also states, "I - I failed the test" (Ho). Saeng was not proud to displease her parents in any way, as she held their approval in high regard. By saying, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" (Ho), the author is just showing Saeng's love and her strong desire to grow for her parents; it shows her growing maturity as she takes responsibility for her failure and plans for a better future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to tell the reader that Saeng is going to take the test again. The author wants to convey this because since she failed the test, she now knows what she did wrong and she is going to correct those mistakes. For example, when Saeng said, “then I will take that test again,” it reveals her determination. Saeng feels sorry that she failed a simple test, so she wants to retake the test when the snow melts, seeing this time as a fresh start and an opportunity to prove herself.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the plant wasn't budding and the geese were going away, and on top of that, she failed the test. All these factors combined made her sad. The lack of a budding plant symbolized her current lack of progress, and the departing geese added to the sense of loss. But when the snow melts, the geese return, and the plant starts budding, she will be happy again. This change in the environment represents a new beginning and a positive shift in her emotional state. She will take the test again and she will pass because she is happy, as a positive mindset will likely lead to better performance.

The author concludes the story this way for many reasons. One reason is to vividly show that Saeng is not going to give up and will keep trying her best to pass her test. Another aspect is to demonstrate that even though your life has undergone changes, that doesn't mean that you have to give up your goals. These are some of the ways that the author concludes the story like he does, effectively conveying important messages through the narrative.

I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph because they specifically wanted to show that she is deeply committed to her nature, especially to the hibiscus. She thought that the hibiscus was truly special because of the intimate actions she did with it. Like when they said “she reached out and gently touched a petal. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the centre”. This tactile description emphasizes her connection. And that’s why I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph, to highlight this profound bond.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because Saeng feels that the moment when the hibiscus is budding will be the right time to retake her driving test. She believes this time will bring positive energy and a fresh start. And another reason would be because the author wants to clearly show her unwavering determination to achieve success in the test. This conclusion effectively portrays Saeng's mindset and the author's intention.

She vowed this paragraph because she earnestly wanted to make her mother proud by passing the test after she had unfortunately failed it. But she patiently waits for the plant to go through its growth cycle and start budding. The hibiscus bud is like a symbol of a new start. If it can make it through the harsh winter, it gives her hope that just as the tropical plant was able to survive a difficult season, she can also survive and pass the test the next spring, fulfilling her vow.

Why I think the author concludes the last paragraph in the story is because it's kind of like a clear moral to the story. She's trying to say that when the time is right, she will bravely try it again and again until she gets it right. Without this last paragraph, you wouldn't be able to fully understand the inspiring message of the story, which is about perseverance and waiting for the opportune moment.

Saeng is a very helpful young lady to her mom as she frequently makes things for her. The author crafted that ending sentence to make the story more interesting for the readers and to keep them hooked until the end.
The author concludes the story with that sentence because she wanted to clearly explain to you that she will repeat this action again when the hibiscus is back in its blooming season.
I guess she says this because she only feels comfortable taking the test when she is surrounded by the beautiful flowers, lush plants, and vibrant greens.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it specifically mentions that when the snows melt, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again. This means that when she grows older and gains more confidence, she will blossom and be able to take the test when she is truly ready, just like the hibiscus will be ready to start budding again.

The author ends the story off with that paragraph because when dealing with flowers and nature, there are distinct seasons. For example, in winter, the flowers don't bloom. The paragraph is saying that in the spring, when the winter is over, she tells herself that she will eagerly look forward to seeing all the plants that nature has to offer.

I believe he deliberately used this as the ending to firmly ensure that she was not only physically but also mentally strong, and she would whole - heartedly do whatever it took to persevere through all the challenges that came her way.
The author includes this specific sentence in the particular paragraph because it clearly marks the start of a brand - new beginning, setting the tone for what is to follow.

In the story, the author concludes with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think she did that to strongly say that you shouldn't give up easily. In the story, Saeng goes to the store and gently “touched a petal” of the hibiscus plant. She carefully buys the plant in an attempt to get a vivid reminder of her old home. In this way, it seems Saeng is reluctantly willing to give up some of her memories of her past. When she brings home the plant, her mom helps her plant it in the garden. I think Saeng is earnestly trying to make her new home feel as cozy and familiar as her old one.

The author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with Saeng vowing to take the test in the spring when the geese return gracefully, the snow melts slowly, and the hibiscus is budding beautifully. This is done to clearly symbolize the many valuable things that Saeng learnt. For example, she learnt that she has to actively adjust to the changes in her life and become well - acquainted with the new things around her. The geese and snow she admits are the things that were “strange before [and] had become familiar to her now”. The hibiscus also represents something meaningful and has a valid reason for being included in the last paragraph. It represents the ability to bravely overcome obstacles, the strong connection to the past, and the much - needed comfort when she feels lost. The last paragraph symbolizes many profound things, and if you look into it deeply, you will truly learn what Saeng learnt.

The author ends the story with Saeng vowing to herself about the relationship between passing the driving test and the significance of the hibiscus flower. The flower is closely linked to the way things used to be for her in Vietnam. For example, hibiscus in @LOCATION3 was known as “Madagascar periwinkle” in Vietnam. It also symbolizes how the flower can smoothly adapt to its new surrounding when taken from a different country, just as Saeng is adjusting to life in @LOCATION3. The reason she said when spring comes she will take the test again clearly symbolizes the connection of the flower to the way she lives now. For instance, it shows her ability and determination that when that flower buds, she will courageously overcome obstacles. Another aspect is the connection to her past experiences. And it was a great sense of comforting to her after she failed her driving test. The author skillfully linked the flower’s significance to the ending of the story, showing the hope and unwavering dedication of Saeng and the obstacles she has passed to reach where she is today.

The reason why I believe the author concluded the story like that is because she is always going to start over. For instance, in the story, she said, “I failed the test.” From that moment, she thought she was going to give up. However, her resilient nature implies she won't stay down. So, that is why I believe the author ended the story with that line, suggesting a fresh start ahead.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because the author is trying to convey that Saeng is going to start all over again, much like the hibiscus would rejuvenate itself. Even though one may go through bad times in life, one should simply step back and do it over again until the situation becomes better. The author also concluded the story with that paragraph because the paragraph essentially restarts the narrative, mirroring what Saeng was about to do. This shows the cyclical nature of life and Saeng's determination to move forward.

She means that when she returns, she is going to repeat the same thing once more and see if she will perform better or not. This indicates her willingness to learn from past experiences and improve herself. By giving it another try, she hopes to achieve a more favorable outcome.

Saeng vowed silently to herself, "In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because her mind wandered off the track from thinking about a flower. She says, "One of the blossoms had fallen off," then carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. This action distracted her mind. Her reaction to failing was to be silent for a long moment and not say a word. She never got mad. All her mother did was brush the fragments of green off Saeng's hands. Her mother was mainly preoccupied with the plants as the day went on. Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the 'winter hibiscus' into it. Seeing her mother's actions sparked a reaction of ideas, so she tried to etch an image of geese in her mind. She decided to retake the driving test again as she was getting used to her new environment. The intro says "Saeng, a teenage girl and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam," yet it never elaborates on her family. This lack of detail leaves room for speculation about their role in her journey.

The author included this paragraph to vividly show how much the girl missed Vietnam. When the girl saw the hibiscus, it instantly brought back a flood of memories of Vietnam. The sight of the hibiscus provided her with a sense of comfort in a foreign land. So, the paragraph serves to highlight how the United States is different from Vietnam. Since the United States has changing seasons, it allows the girl to gradually get used to her new home. The plant will always be there as a reminder, but she has to look for the positive aspects that the United States offers. The author states, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This quote clearly shows how the girl was adapting to the United States. It also shows that while she will always remember Vietnam, she can find elements in the United States that remind her of home. In conclusion, the paragraph is used to show how much the girl missed Vietnam, but how she is gradually finding comfort and a sense of belonging within the United States.
These basically say that he will be around again, just like how geese always return season - after - season, making their predictable journey back to the familiar places.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. One being that she is still uncomfortable about talking about her old home, as shown by “She was still too shy to say the words ‘at home’” [HO]. The snow melting, the geese returning, and the hibiscus budding are all elements that remind her of her home. We know this because Saeng says “Just as she had known it would feel… Back home it just grew wild, just out from the cracks in the brick walls or between tiled roofs” [HO]. So, with these reminders of her home, she is given both comfort and confidence. The author therefore concluded with this paragraph because since the geese, hibiscus, and the snow melting remind her of her home, that is when she will take the test again, when she is confident and strong, ready to face the challenge anew.

By adding this paragraph to the end of the story, it shows that a resolution was made and that the theme of overcoming obstacles is present in the story. When Saeng failed the test, she was extremely miserable and heart - broken. However, after buying the hibiscus, she had found hope and motivation. In the end, she decides that she will take the test again, “in the spring, when the snow melts, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding”. This hope at the end of the story helps put the reader at ease when they wonder what might happen next. It helps move the story to a satisfying conclusion. This is why most endings are meaningful like this. Readers are able to obtain the message from the story through paragraphs like this. In this case, the author’s message was to never give up and that people find motivation in simple things. It is important to know what an author is trying to tell the reader through paragraphs, not only as a reader trying to understand the purpose of a story, but also as a writer trying to express their ideas clearly to an audience, so that the intended message is effectively conveyed.

I think that the author uses this quote, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” @CAPS1 It symbolizes that spring brings new life and hope. “But where did the home thought come from? The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that the hibiscus is a symbol for Saeng. In the springtime, the hibiscus grows just like Saeng. The author concludes the story in this manner to vividly show that Saeng does not give up easily and is firmly determined to pass the test. In this story, the reason that the author concludes things in this particular way is to pick a tone that makes the character feel comfortable to take the test again. The author concluded this part of the story because she believes that this is the right time for Saeng to retake the test. The Author concludes the story with this paragraph to clearly show the hope and the profound meaning of the hibiscus to Saeng. The author concludes the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” with a strong paragraph consisting of one sentence stating that Saeng will take the test when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, envisioning the upcoming spring. In many stories, the narrator skillfully uses a dramatic yet conclusive statement to end the story. An example of one such impactful occurrence is in the short - story “Winter Hibiscus”. In the story, at the end of the last paragraph, the author wrote that “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the soft snows melt away and the geese return in a long - flying formation and this hibiscus is budding with promise, then I will take that test again” (last paragraph). The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wants to gently remind the reader and concisely summarize the story. He concludes this story in such a way so that you don't feel as if she was defeated. Instead, she is now more aware of the situation or firmly believes she can complete the task. The author concluded the story with this because, just like the flower that will come back anew after a dormant period, so will she. The author uses this paragraph as a symbol of realization and a new beginning for Saeng. She spent so much time longing for and missing the past that she didn't know how to fully enjoy the present. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the character Saeng had many obstacles to overcome.
