The author ends the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the passage “When they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She is saying how she is going to try to take the test again because she failed the first time. The author concludes this story, “Winter Hibiscus,” with that paragraph as a sign of reassurance. Saeng had had a tough few years adapting to the United States from Vietnam. The author brought out the paragraph "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again", to portray the theme of the story. The author concludes the story with the paragraph, "When they come back," Saeng vowed silently to herself, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She buys the flower right after she failed the driver's test. In the short story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes with a paragraph explaining when the character, Saeng, will take her driving test again. In the winter Hibiscus, the author chose to end the story with a hopeful paragraph which stated, “when they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this Hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reasons for the decision to end on an optimistic note are as follows. The author concludes the story with this paragraph (when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again) because it clearly explains what she is going to do when winter is over. I know the reason why the author concludes the story the way he does, and it is indeed a good reason. The author ends the story with that paragraph because it clearly shows how Saeng won't give up easily. Saeng deeply wants to make her mother proud, so she is determined to do whatever it takes. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it means that when the shovel - like plants grow again in the spring, when the snow gradually melts and the geese return from their migration, and this hibiscus is budding, she will take the test again. In the story, the test was whether she could overcome her homesickness. When she went to the greenhouse, all of the plants and flowers there brought back vivid memories of her homeland. I think the author adds the last paragraph because the story could use a small, yet significant part about Saeng. This part would reveal what she is planning to do next. I think the author concluded the story with these lines because Saeng feels more confident. First, when Saeng first saw the hibiscus, she was deeply sad. I think Minfong Ho concluded her story “Winter Hibiscus” the way she did to clearly show the avid determination of Saeng, the main character. At the end of the essay “Winter Hibiscus” by @CAPS1 Ho, it ends in a positive manner. “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason why I think that the author decided to put that there was to vividly show how Saeng felt about her country. Saeng promises herself that “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The hibiscus is metaphorical to Saeng for her childhood. Evidently, she grew up in Vietnam and moved to the @LOCATION2. She deeply misses her homeland, and all the flowers vividly remind her of her homeland. She is so overwhelmed by all the memories that she breaks down and cries. Change is indeed a difficult thing to overcome or adjust to, especially moving to a foreign country. She knows that she will eventually adjust to the major change for she realized, “that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become… almost familiar to her now.” She promises herself that she will retake the driver's test when the hibiscus blossoms because like Saeng, a flower changes also. When the hibiscus finally overcomes the cold, dreary winter months and blooms, Saeng will know she is ready to take the test again for that flower can also symbolize her going through changes. The geese in the story also symbolize changes; they have to migrate south in the winter to avoid the cold but return home when it's warm enough. Like Saeng, she will avoid the test in the winter but in the spring when she feels comfortable and ready.
So she is saying that she will take the test next year as she feels more prepared then.

The author concludes the story at the end because I think the author ends the story this way because he wants to kind of convey that he will be ready next year to sprout again. He will be ready to face the test and not cry and break down when he sees the plant, instead thinking of childhood memories. He will be fully ready to move forward.

Saeng buys a beautiful winter hibiscus to plant in the garden, which will also remind her of her beloved homeland. She has unfortunately failed some sort of test and is quite upset over it. Her mother, feeling bad for her, doesn't get upset that the hibiscus cost @MONEY1. After carefully planting the hibiscus, Saeng says to herself, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again.” The author uses this paragraph to make you think about whether or not Saeng will fail or pass the test again. It also makes you wonder about what kind of test since the author says “hibiscus is budding” and “the geese return”. It must be a test that you can only take once a year because she clearly says that “In the spring” she will take the test again.

The author concluded this paragraph in this story because I think that he is trying to tell the reader a meaningful message. The author is trying to say that if a plant can make it through the cold, harsh winter then she can surely pass her driver’s test. That is the main reason why I think the author included that paragraph.

The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author ends with this promise or commitment because it clearly shows hope and strong determination. Saeng vowing to herself “I will take that test again” shows her firm determination and unwillingness to accept failure. That is enough to bring hope to someone who has failed and desperately wants another chance. This paragraph also sums up and displays Saeng’s good character. It shows Saeng’s strength because even though she failed the first time, she was going to bravely put herself through the pain of trying again to succeed. To fail and try again shows great inner strength. The author also ends with this paragraph because “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding” brings everything back full circle. It holds the promise of Spring and better things to come with it. There are many valid reasons why the author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.”

The author added it in at the end not only to make the story have a happy, hopeful ending, but to show the reader that Saeng slowly adjusted to the changes in life. The paragraph above explains that Saeng realized that "the many things that seemed strange before had become,... almost familiar to her now." This realization shows her growing adaptability. So the author lastly concludes that even though she failed the test this time, just as the geese will return in the spring, then she can take the test again. By using this analogy, the author effectively gets the point of the story across, and it's a "cheerful" way to end it as it leaves the reader with a sense of optimism.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with, "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.", to show that the hibiscus plant has given Saeng hope. It has helped her get through some rough and difficult times. In the story, Saeng has just failed her @CAPS1 test and had to walk home. She was extremely upset, her head hung low as she trudged along. On her way home, Saeng saw a familiar flower. Intrigued, she walked into a flower store to see if they sold the hibiscus that she had seen. The employee, noticing her interest, kindly pointed her towards the flower. The hibiscus brought back many warm and vivid memories of her hometown in Vietnam. Saeng carefully planted her flowers in the vegetable garden. That flower had given her a glimmer of hope, a reason to keep going. She is now ready to try the @CAPS1 test again, with newfound determination.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because the season is over. For example, it is starting in the winter and the hibiscuses are dying, their once - vibrant petals now withering away. Also, she is leaving and won't come back till she can plant flowers again in the spring. The spring represents a time of renewal and new beginnings. And she will come back again when she takes the test over again. This cycle of leaving and returning, like the changing of the seasons, gives the story a sense of continuity. In conclusion, that is why the author ends the story with this paragraph as it ties together the themes of time, change, and the promise of a fresh start.

The reason the author of “Winter hibiscus” ends the story with the last paragraph is to give hope to the end. It gives a certain lift of joy at the end of a moderately depressing story. The character has what seems to be a new - found confidence and a new joy of the plant that reminds her of her homeland comforting her and motivating her. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows how sometimes you have to wait till the time is just right for you to try again. Emotions, symbolism, and the realization of certain themes are all reasons the author concluded the story that way. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng is fond of beautiful flowers that once grew in her homeland. Her favorite flower was the winter hibiscus, which had beautiful red petals as soft as velvet. I think he did because he wanted to show how he deeply loved everything in life. He aimed to convey that every aspect of life, no matter how small or seemingly insignificant, holds value and beauty. The reason why the author of the story ended the story like that is because after all the hard time that the plant went through, it will still face challenges at the end of the winter. Explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. It all makes a little sense to conclude the story with this. Here's why I think it does. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author decided to end it with the sentence “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. In the last paragraph of the story, Saeng vows to herself that she will take the driving test again in the spring. The story “Winter Hibiscus” is about a young girl who has a strong passion for gardening and tends to prioritize it over schoolwork. The author has a well - thought - out reason for concluding the story in this way. The main character of the story, Saeng, moves from Vietnam to the United States and unfortunately fails her driver's test. Saeng has not yet fully adapted to the life in the United States. When she sees a familiar hibiscus plant, she buys it as a keepsake of her memories of Vietnam. The author is trying to convey that since Saeng planted the hibiscus during the cold winter, when it blooms beautifully in the warm spring, she will be mentally and emotionally ready to attempt and pass her driver's test because she will have gradually adapted to the life in the United States. The theme of the story would be that if you are moving away from the place where you grew up, it is a good idea to bring things that remind you of that place so that you can still hold on to a little bit of that culture. Therefore, the author begins and ends the story with the same subject, creating a sense of circularity and connection.

The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with a sentence about retaking the driver's test in the spring, to effectively express the themes of adapting to circumstances and the determination to succeed. The main character in the story, Saeng, is a Vietnamese immigrant. Since the United States is not her homeland, there are still numerous aspects of life here that she is not yet accustomed to, and the story vividly shows her struggle to adapt. For instance, when she sees the flower “Madagascar penwinhle,” she thinks “how strange to see it in a pot” because “Back home it just grows wild.” The last sentence of the story is symbolic when it says “and the geese return.” The geese adapt to circumstances by flying south for the winter, just as Saeng is trying to adapt to her new life in the United States, and Saeng realizes that their patterns are becoming more and more familiar to her. The very last line says “I will take that test again.” This simple yet powerful statement summarizes the determination Saeng has throughout the entire story. Not only is she determined to succeed in her driver's test, but also in other aspects of her new life. For example, when trying to plant the hibiscus, Saeng observes that “the soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting her shovel into it.” Despite this great difficulty, though, she “Dug out a hole” and is confident that it's strong enough to survive the cold months, just like Saeng believes she will be strong enough to overcome obstacles if she keeps trying. The last sentence in the story is highly significant. It expresses important themes and offers valuable insight into Saeng's resilient and determined character.

The author @PERSON1 concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with that paragraph to show that Saeng is starting over. I say the only reason why the author included that last paragraph was to clearly show that she was not going to give up easily. She was still determined to take the test again. The young girl Saeng, from the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, has left her homeland of Vietnam and moved to the United States. The young girl was full of hope as she aimed to get her driver's license, but unfortunately, she failed. The hibiscus she sees provides her with comfort, vividly reminding her of Vietnam. When she decides to purchase it, her mother is initially concerned about the price. However, she soon sees how homesick her daughter is and becomes understanding. After carefully planting the hibiscus, she watches the geese flying in the sky and realizes that every year they change their habitat, following the rhythm of nature. The geese, along with the hibiscus, inspire Saeng. She promises herself that “in the spring when the snow melts away, the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.”

The author uses this paragraph because it works perfectly as an end. With this, Saeng tells @LOCATION1 that once all the snow has completely disappeared, she will take the test again. If one reads between the lines, it says more than just this simple statement. She truly has a deep affection for the hibiscus. When the hibiscus comes back to life in the spring, with its leaves turning green and flowers blooming, she will gain new energy to take the test again. From her experience with the hibiscus, we can clearly see that this plant really influences her. This is because this plant reminds her so much of her old home, with its familiar shape and fragrance. Also, we can understand that everything and everybody should get a second chance. In her case, it is the test she wants to retake. Also, in the spring, after living in @LOCATION1 for a couple of months, she will gradually adjust herself to this new situation. At the moment, she is just homesick, even though her new home is @LOCATION1 now. So the hibiscus is very good for her; it is something she can firmly hold onto from her old home, a precious link to her past.

The author, Minfong Ho, finishes the story in this manner to vividly show the overcoming of obstacles. The story clearly depicts the numerous difficulties Saeng encounters when leaving her old home and coming to her new one. On the day described, she fails a driver's test, doesn't have lunch with her friend, and spends all her money on a plant from her old home. Also, this paragraph effectively shows how the Hibiscus symbolizes her. The plant is not in its native home, facing many challenges such as the cold, its small pot, and even its general surroundings. In every aspect, the plant is in the same circumstances as the main character, and the last paragraph is used to firmly link them, emphasizing the shared struggles and resilience.

The reason why the author used this paragraph is because he was suggesting that the snow will go away in spring time, indicating a change from the cold and harsh conditions to a more pleasant and hopeful state. This idea likely ties into the overall theme of the story, perhaps symbolizing the end of difficulties and the start of a better period. In conclusion, the use of this paragraph serves to convey this important seasonal and symbolic message.

The last paragraph means only one thing. That one thing is to be like a Hibiscus, resilient and perseverant, to take the test again in the journey of life. Just as the Hibiscus endures various conditions and will come back in the spring, we too should have the courage to face setbacks and try again. So, as you can see, the last paragraph has a very profound and inspiring meaning to it, encouraging us to keep going despite difficulties.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph because this clearly shows that Saeng is willing to change, and she wants to achieve this change by the time spring comes. By change, Saeng wants to feel comfortable in @LOCATION1 and be able to remember things from where she used to live without having to break down and cry. Also, the author uses the geese as an example because they need to leave home every year and they manage to deal with it, suggesting that Saeng can deal with her situation as well. This comparison emphasizes the idea of adaptability and resilience, wrapping up the story with a positive message about Saeng's potential for growth.

The reason why the author ends the story with that statement is because when you fail at something, you truly need time to dust yourself off and try again. She concluded the paragraph with that particular paragraph to clearly show that she is truly serious about her gardening. Moreover, she stated that she won't start gardening until the geese come back, indicating a unique connection to nature's cycle.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus”, the author concludes the story with the lines “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason that the author concludes the story with these lines is because she is re - establishing the symbolism of the plant. In the text, it clearly stated that the plant buds in the spring, once it has sufficient time to grow and adapt to the new environment. Just as the plant needed that time to adjust, so did the main character Saeng. She had just moved from Vietnam and unfortunately failed her driver's test. Saeng is extremely unsure of her new culture. For instance, it is mentioned that she likes bitter melon, as it says, “But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac.” She appears to think that she is misunderstood and no one likes her, but just as the plant will gradually adapt to this new life, so will she, and taking the test in spring symbolizes her new - found readiness.

The author concludes the story by saying she will take the test again in the spring and vow silently until then because the spring vividly reminded Saeng of home. She had just failed her driving test before this incident and desperately needed hope. So, by waiting till spring when the hibiscus will bloom again, it will give Saeng a strong sense of home, which in turn will provide her with the hope and confidence to do well on the driving test. In this way, the spring and the blooming hibiscus become symbols of her renewed spirit and potential success.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author's reasoning for saying this is because the presence of memories from Saeng's homeland provides her with a great deal of comfort. These memories are so powerful that they will enable her to pass her test with ease as she will not be nervous. “It was like walking into another world,” said Saeng, when she entered the florist shop after failing her driver's test. It was almost as if she completely forgot about failing and was solely focused on the plants and flowers. The flowers transport her to a happy and peaceful place and make her feel at home. The author may have concluded the story like that because of the title and the beginning of the story. The title might have set a certain tone or theme, and the conclusion aligns with it. Or perhaps he simply wanted to conclude it in this way according to his creative vision. I really do not know why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. Possibly because she started to talk about certain themes or elements earlier in the story that she wanted to tie up neatly with this conclusion, but it's not entirely clear to me from my current understanding.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's determination. Saeng has been through a lot, such as leaving her homeland and adjusting to a new environment, and she deeply misses what it's like at home. She feels different and out of place in this new world, but she is still strong. Life goes on, and this paragraph shows that Saeng will move with it. The paragraph says, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Spring will come, as nothing can stop the passage of time. The snow will melt because the weather gradually changes. The geese will fly home and the hibiscus will bloom in spring. Saeng takes a positive look at things and decides to join them. Sure she failed once but she is strong and willing to try again. If at first you don't succeed, try, try again. Saeng will always have her memories of home but she is willing to adapt to her new surroundings. The concluding paragraph shows Saeng's determination to succeed and survive in the new world.

The author concludes the story saying that because she wants to show us that Saeng is confident in herself and will not hesitate to take the test again. The author concludes with this paragraph, to give a sense of hope and growth. The flower represents Saeng's homeland, and it makes her feel comforted. The author concludes this story with hope in this sentence. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author is elaborating on how there will be a fresh new start. The author concludes the story with that because as winter approaches, everything seems to fade away. In the story called "Winter Hibiscus", the author concludes the story with this paragraph: "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The reason why the author included this at the end of the story was that when things seem to go haywire and everything appears to be buried underground metaphorically, everyone has the natural inclination to wait patiently until it resurfaces. When one fails, it feels like everything is in a downward spiral, but if you persevere and wait for a while, everything will gradually start to improve, just like flowers blooming and all the other natural phenomena that you can think of. So, that is why the author put that at the end of the story, to convey to people that it is perfectly okay for people to fail. As long as you pick yourself up and keep trying until you reach your goal, there is hope. So, that is what the author was trying to communicate, and that's why Minfong Ho put that at the end of the story so that people can read it and draw valuable lessons from what it says.

The author concludes the story with that last paragraph to carefully set the final mood. The author concludes the story with this paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, Then I will take that test again.” I believe the author concluded the story like this because it clearly shows that the hibiscus represented to Saeng a brand - new beginning and an opportunity to restart what she had failed. The author ends the story with the given paragraph to effectively get across a profound message. The author concludes the story with this paragraph, because it effectively expresses the profound meaning of the story. The author chooses to end the story in a very deep, well - connected way. It is ended on a note of rebirth and second chances. The author concludes the story with that paragraph for one main reason: to leave a lasting impression on the reader. The author is showing that Saeng has a deep - seated desire to keep on with her mother's gardening. I believe that the author ended the story with this paragraph to vividly show the remarkable persistence of the main character. The author concludes the story with the paragraph because she wants to do it right next time. What it's saying is that she can try every year to get it right in order to impress her mother. In the story “Winter Hibiscus”, the author @CAPS1 most likely ends the story with this quote because he wants to show that Saeng thinks of the Hibiscus as more than just flowers. The author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. For example, it shows a strong sense of hope when she says “this hibiscus is budding”. The author concludes the story with that particular paragraph for a number of well - thought - out reasons. The last paragraph states that “when they come back ... The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show that she loved those flowers deeply. They meant a whole lot to her. When she failed her driving test, she was extremely sad. The author concluded this sentence because he was letting everyone know that Saeng would return to the hibiscus and take good care of it still. In the story "Winter Hibiscus", by Minfong Ho, a young teenager named Saeng moves from Vietnam to the United States. She later decides to take a driver's test, but unfortunately does not succeed in passing it. However, she does find comfort from her memories of her homeland. The last paragraph states "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. These reasons being that Saeng was extremely upset about failing her test and was reminded of her homeland and the numerous changes she's had to adapt to during this move. The hibiscus plant gives Saeng a glimmer of hope to continue her journey even when things get very tough. The winter is this plant's time of trouble and sadness, just as Saeng's time of trouble and sadness is failing this test and not being at her real home. The end of winter gives both the plant and Saeng a chance to start over and a renewed hope. If Saeng continues to find comfort from her past, she will find it easier to get through hardships.

The author concludes the story with that particular paragraph to make the readers start wondering. It is a way to show that the protagonist, Saeng, is not going to give up on what she wants to do. By ending the story in this manner, the author leaves an open - ended thought in the readers' minds about Saeng's future attempts and her determination to achieve her goal.

The author Minfong Ho ends the story talking about the test that Saeng failed and her vowing to take it again. In the story, the test was symbolizing a small step towards moving on, a gentle start to her new life rather than living in the past. But Saeng couldn't achieve this on her first try. She spent all her money to buy the flower because it held precious memories of her old life for her. As the story progresses, I think she gradually realizes that she can have both, her old and new life in harmony. I believe the author ends the story that way because Saeng truly wants to try again. She has the desire to please her mom as well as herself. She wants to be able to move on and start her new life whole - heartedly.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng realizes that she needs more time. She is still adjusting to the new environment and the challenges that come with it. If she takes a break and focuses on what she needs to improve, then by the time @MONTH1 arrives, she will be able to pass the test. This shows that she is self - aware and willing to take the necessary steps to achieve her goal.

The author concludes the story this way because he can now expand on this story by creating a sequel about Saeng's success. Saeng is having difficulties adapting to her new lifestyle because the familiar plants and the previous luxuries that she had in her homeland are no longer present. In the story, Saeng's determination is clearly shown when her mother finds out that she spent @NUM1 dollars to buy a similar plant. The mother responds by saying that their whole garden in the new place is worth less than @NUM1 dollars, yet Saeng's resolve remains unshaken.

This sentence concludes the passage, clearly demonstrating that when the hibiscus begins to bud and a new season commences, Saeng will transform into a new person and will be well - prepared to take the test. In this very sentence, the cold snow, the fleeing geese, and the potted hibiscus all serve as symbols representing Saeng and her current circumstances. They are either cold, on the verge of leaving, or restricted, mirroring exactly how Saeng feels. However, when a new season arrives, the geese will return, and the hibiscus will no longer be confined to a pot. At that time, Saeng will also mature and be capable of taking the test. This sentence is strategically placed at the end to illustrate the significant growth potential Saeng has, as she has the hibiscus growing alongside her, which will surely inspire her progress.

The author ends the story with the provided sentence because, as she was trying to convey, when winter is over and the harshest times have passed, there will come a time again to resume gardening. The plant represents her hope and effort, and just as the plant needs the right season to thrive, she too needs the appropriate time to take and pass the test. This ending emphasizes the cyclical nature of life and the importance of waiting for the right moment.

The author has concluded the story with a paragraph about Saeng taking the test again at another time. The author concludes the story with this paragraph. The reason is that when the hibiscus starts budding, it will offer her a powerful source of inspiration to attempt and pass the test once more. The author concludes the story with a paragraph about taking the test again to show that the narrator might be initially upset about being in a new place, but she will persevere and keep trying. When she moved to America, she was immediately captivated by all the beautiful flowers that were in full bloom during the spring. Among them, she saw a blossom that caught her attention. The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to clearly show that Saeng is not just going to give up easily. She is determined to overcome the problem that stands in her way. This is a great way to end this story because the entire story is centered around the theme of overcoming problems. If Saeng just gave up, it would completely ruin the positive and inspiring tone of the story. But just like she was able to move away from her home - land with courage, she will eventually pass the test. The mother was also able to overcome some significant obstacles. She obviously misses the old plants, and you can tell by the way she immediately knew what her gift was. Everything in the story is about to change. The cold winter will gradually change to the warm spring, the thick snow will melt and slowly vanish, the geese will return from their long journey, the hibiscus will start to bud, and Saeng will also change and mature as well. Saeng is just like the hibiscus plant. As the plant seems out of place on the side of the road, Saeng is out of place in the new country, and she must adapt, just like the hibiscus plant has to adapt to its new environment. The plant looks different in the United States than in Vietnam because it has matured and grown in this new setting. That is what Saeng must do; she must mature and grow in this new country. For example, Saeng carefully observed how different the plant looked in the shop window compared to how it did in her home country. In that moment, she was also observing herself and how different she appeared as well. The reason for putting the paragraph at the very end was to show that she had matured already. Putting it at the end effectively shows that she has grown. Putting it at the beginning would not give the same powerful and impactful effect. The hibiscus plant was able to sustain the harsh winter's change, and Saeng is able to do that as well. She made the silent vow to take that test again when she has matured just as the things around her have, marking a new beginning in her life.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph shown for several important reasons. First, the author needs to conclude the story in a way that leaves no lingering questions in the readers' minds as to what happens next. This is effectively achieved by incorporating the geese, hibiscus, and her driver's test into the last paragraph, tying up all the loose ends. Lastly, it adds depth to the character. By saying that she will "take that test again", she is shown as being realistic and not over - confident. These are some of the significant ways that the last paragraph enhances the story, providing a well - rounded and satisfying conclusion.

The author chose to end the story with this paragraph because it clearly shows that Saeng is gradually starting to adjust to her new home and that she possesses a tenacious spirit and will not give up easily. The author concluded the story with the paragraph because it shows that Saeng was not fully prepared for this test, mainly because she was not yet accustomed to the new place. The author concludes the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". In the story “Winter Hibiscus” which was written by Minfong Ho, certain elements keep the readers engaged. The author ends the story by saying “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” She chooses to end like this to clearly show the change of the mood throughout the story. I think the author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with this paragraph for these reasons. The first reason is to show that the girl won't give up easily. The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show people that the story or the people in the story have a deep appreciation for nature. The author wrote that last paragraph to give hope to Saeng and the reader. After seeing the hibiscus flower, Saeng is vividly reminded of her old country and feels a deep sadness. The author concludes with this paragraph because it fits seamlessly along with a great deal of the story and sums it up quite well. In the story, the hibiscus holds a profound significance for Saeng. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it clearly conveys that she can't work in the garden during winter, but phrases like “when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding” are all distinct signs of spring. The author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph because it powerfully symbolizes Saeng's firm decision to try again. I think that the author concludes the story with that paragraph because no matter what she said or did, she had to get the flower because it reminds her of where she used to live and what it was like there. Throughout this story, we are given background information on a girl who desperately misses her true home. When we are first introduced to young Saeng, she is in a florist's shop simply looking at flowers. We soon learn that she is not only looking at flowers but also looking at pieces of her home and past. She then purchases a hibiscus, which is a flower native to her Vietnam. After discovering that she has just failed a test, it becomes more apparent that buying the flower is a way to cope with her new situation in @LOCATION1 and feel comforted by her past. The author is able to conclude the story with that statement because it speaks of moving forward without clinging to the past. In the spring, Saeng will have a new home and find strength in her past experiences. That is what I feel the final paragraph suggests.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because, Saeng is firmly determined to pass the test. She clearly knows that when spring arrives and the hibiscus starts budding, she will retake the test. I think she wants to retake the test because the sight of the hibiscus vividly makes her think about her homeland. It gives her a strong sense of comfort and makes her feel more confident. She firmly believes she can pass it next time. The hibiscus makes her heart filled with happiness and a bit overwhelmed. With this new - found motivation, she wholeheartedly wants to retake the test. She's absolutely sure she will do better next time, as the hibiscus has become a symbol of hope for her.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because, it clearly shows that if that type of flower could bloom in different places and smoothly go through natural changes, then so can she. To me, the flower is a powerful symbol to the author that strongly encourages her to keep trying. No matter if you have to start all over and painstakingly do it again. It's just that this time you will clearly know and would have thoroughly learned from the past mistakes. Just as a flower beautifully blooms one spring, it sadly dies in the winter and then cheerfully comes again in the spring. That's exactly the same as Saeng failing that test that year; she can bravely go back next time and take it again, armed with the lessons from the past.

Guess that she is saying that when winter is completely gone she will be well - prepared for that winter test again. I guess this because they were clearly not prepared for the winter to suddenly come as they were busy planting. As in the reading she says, "As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, laboriously digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel." That's the obvious reason why I believed that they were not prepared for the winter. So, she's likely waiting for the right time to be fully ready for the test.

The author concluded the story in this manner so that the audience would deeply feel sympathy and understanding for the things that Saeng and her family were going through in this extremely hard time. It makes the reader truly feel sympathy for Saeng because all she can constantly think of to make herself feel better is her beloved home town and how she was unfortunately taken away from it. This connection to her hometown shows her longing and pain, and the author's conclusion helps the readers empathize with her difficult situation.

He concludes the story because he wants another chance to retake the test. Maybe he didn't perform well the first time, and ending the story this way gives him the hope of a new attempt. He believes that with another opportunity, he can do better and achieve a more satisfactory result. This conclusion leaves the door open for him to prove himself in the test.

The author concluded "Winter Hibiscus" with this particular paragraph to strongly emphasize a new life and fresh chances for the main character. The future - setting of the paragraph, which is spring, vividly symbolizes rebirth and another start from the cold, harsh winter. The author takes this symbolism to heart, including more small events that enhance this symbolized meaning. The author has used a structured choice to convey her thoughts. When recreating the theme of rebirth, the author uses words like "the geese return" and "take the test again" which add to the importance at home. Also, the literal action of the "hibiscus is budding" clearly represents rebirth. In winter, the plant is dormant and less colorful, but in the spring, the plant shows rebirth through the vibrant color in its buds. By ending with this paragraph, the author effectively conveys the theme of rebirth, leaving a lasting impression on the readers.

In the story “winter hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, it tells the tale of a young girl who has just moved to a new country and is having a tough time adapting to the new land and its people. However, I think the author put that specific quote at the end to lead the readers to believe that one should never give up, that there is always a new beginning and that they will make it through. I believe this because Saeng thinks to herself, “almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she thought were strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her.” This shows that she has finally found comfort and is feeling confident, much like the geese that go to adapt in a new area and then will come back. Just as the winter hibiscus never gives up and keeps living in the new weather conditions every season, Saeng too will persevere in her new environment.

She concludes the things at the end of her paragraph. Specifically, she says a whole thing which implies that she will look forward to it when the winter is finally done. She will be in a position to retake the test again in the spring. This act of retaking the test is what she was essentially writing about in that part of the text, showing her hope for a better outcome in the future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it clearly shows that she is trying to adapt to her new surroundings. The hibiscus plant, with its unique charm, reminds her of her old life and provides her with a sense of comfort. So, when she takes her test in the spring, she will feel better and more at ease as she remembers her old life in this new place. In the story, it is mentioned that she failed her test and then she bought a plant that brought back memories of her old life. The plant, with its familiar essence, brought back warm memories of her old life and that helped soothe her. The spring season reminds her of her old life because the flowers in the garden are in full bloom, the geese return to their usual spots, and the snow has melted away. With the comfort of her memories of her old life, Saeng feels like she can successfully adapt to her new surroundings.

The author chose this paragraph because it fits perfectly, just like a well - crafted conclusion. For example, the word “again” in the paragraph has a significant meaning. It implies that you did something already and it's over, but you miss it so you retry what you miss. In this paragraph, it's talking about nature and how it seems to want to “test” itself again. The use of “again” makes the paragraph resonate with the idea of repetition and renewal in nature, making it an ideal choice for concluding the story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it clearly still shows how unwaveringly determined Saeng is to take the test again and pass it successfully this time. By ending this story with the paragraph, the author is creating suspense, which is probably intended for a sequel of another story, leaving the readers eager to find out what happens next.

In the short story "Winter Hibiscus," a young girl originally from Vietnam moves to @LOCATION1 and unfortunately fails the driver's test. Afterward, she decides to spend her money on a winter hibiscus to vividly remind her of her homeland. The ending paragraph, "When Troy comes back, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again," shows a deep - seated feeling towards nature. She feels that just as the geese are ready to return home and when the hibiscus is ready to bud, so will she be ready, and she will take the driver's test again with renewed determination.

She is talking about the flowers, and when she says "test," I think she means how she closely looks at and examines the flowers and watches the snow fall all over again. It sounds like the author is someone who greatly admires flowers a lot, or maybe just this one particular hibiscus and how it buds. Maybe she is just someone who likes to see the natural changes that occur in the world around her.

I believe the author adds this passage to the story to represent determination and @LOCATION1. While Saeng is not originally from @LOCATION2, she is determined and whole - heartedly willing to try and adapt to our @CAPS1. While the winter was cold and harsh in many difficult ways for her, the spring will bring forgiveness and relief from her @CAPS2. She will try to pass the driving test again to further integrate herself into American @CAPS1, while the blooming of the hibiscus will bring her a sense of @CAPS4 to home, making her feel more at ease.

The author probably concludes the story with that paragraph to clearly show that Saeng has finally realized she needs to be confident, and to also end the story on a positive and hopeful note. Also, the author artfully wraps things familiar to Saeng, and things native to her new home, into the last paragraph. At the beginning of the story, the girl seemed extremely upset and completely lost in this country, and she missed her home greatly. "A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her." But once she gets home and tells her mother she failed her driving test, she seems to start feeling better. Towards the end, after she planted the hibiscus, she sees geese and she feels as if they're "almost familiar". The paragraph that ends the selection does an excellent job of tying her past (the hibiscus), her present (the geese & the snow) and the drama of the story (failing the test) into one coherent and satisfying whole.

She was eager to learn and take on more things. She was completely captivated by the way the plants looked at the store. Her mother carefully selected the plant, then they went home. Once there, they started planting it together. The daughter cherished the plant deeply. And she said with determination that next year she'd grow a plant as wonderful as the one her mom was growing.

I think the author concludes this paragraph in this story to describe how much Saeng has grown up now since it no longer seems like she lives with her mom. To the author, it's likely that they want to emphasize to the reader the independence of Saeng. Now that she probably has left, as she doesn't live with her mom anymore, what has happened was just her past and will remain a memorable part of Saeng's life.

The author uses that passage to end the story to show that Saeng will try to adapt. When Saeng smells the Hibiscus, “The familiar fragrance filled her lungs and Saeng could almost feel the light touch of her grandmother’s long gray hair.” This indicates that Saeng was seeking things that were familiar to her and reminded her of her homeland. The fact that Saeng paid over nineteen dollars for a plant also demonstrates how much she missed her homeland. “She failed the test that Saeng paid for.” This shows the reader that she attempted to adapt to her new home but failed. At the end of the story, she said that “I will take the test again.” Seeing the familiar hibiscus and geese leave, knowing that they will return, gives Saeng hope. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to clearly show that despite the challenges, Saeng isn't going to give up and will keep striving forward.

With the hibiscus around her, Saeng will gain more courage and also have had more time to adjust to their new home. For Saeng, the hibiscus serves as a powerful motivation and it also vividly reminds her of her old homeland. The reason I think the author chose to end the story with this particular comment is to show that in the end, Saeng has found the courage and is fully ready to embrace her tasks in this foreign land.

The story concludes that paragraph because it tells you that there are changes in the weather and season, just as there are in your life. You have to sometimes deal with these changes in your life. The test might be one to see if she can understand herself. There are changes in the weather all the time, like in the spring and fall. You just have to get over them and move forward.

In the story “The Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the writer ends with a paragraph that concludes the story. One of the reasons she concluded with the last paragraph as she did is because it tells the reader that Saeng has not given up on her driver's test. “... Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This explains in more detail when she will take the test again. I believe that the author concludes the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” was a great way to end it because I think that she sees how much the hibiscus can endure, and then she realizes she can take just about anything, mainly the test. The writer adds this conclusion to the end of the story because he wants people to know that the seasons are changing and the flowers are going to be dying. The hibiscus flower is viewed as a symbol of hope and a reminder of their homeland. The author concludes the story with this paragraph, because it conveys the message that if you fail the first time, there is always a second chance. Just like the @CAPS1 plant that dies in the winter and comes back alive in the spring, one can always bounce back from failure.

The author leaves us at the end of the story saying “when the snow melts and geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The author does this because the girl Saeng failed the test but still found something that reminded her of her home. I think the author ends the story like this because of Saeng's deep respect for the plant. Not only does she see the plant as a symbol of her home but also as a symbol of good luck. The author includes that paragraph at the end of the story because it connects Saeng to the geese and plant with symbolism. For Saeng, the snow represents her troubles adjusting to @LOCATION1. The author chose to conclude the story like that because she’s saying that it isn’t over and she’s going to take the test again. In the story, Saeng says “I - I failed the test” so she’s determined to go back when the flower blooms again to get things right. I think what the author is trying to say is that she will take her driving test again in the lovely spring when the colorful flowers are in full bloom because the pleasant scenery will make her feel more relaxed. Because she is saying that when the beautiful @CAPS1 grow back vibrantly, she will be mentally and emotionally ready as @CAPS2 to take the test again. The return of @CAPS1 symbolizes a new beginning and a positive change, giving her the confidence and motivation to face the test once more.

In the story “winter hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author is concluding the story with this last sentence because it is clearly showing everyone that the season is over for the growing of the plants. However, when it comes time for the delicate flowers to start growing again in the gentle warmth of spring, she will be back with dedication to take care of the plants. Another reason I think the author ended it that way is that it is still snowing outside. She cares deeply about the plants, but she isn't going to worry about them until it is the right time again. In the story “the Winter Hibiscus”, I think the author uses the last paragraph to show that although the vivid memories of her old country would always be deeply ingrained with her, she will gradually and steadily adapt to her new one. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is going to retake the test over when all these wonderful things happen. In the spring, when nature undergoes a renewal, it is a clear indication that it is time to give the test another honest try. In conclusion, the paragraph is a strong indication that Saeng is never going to forget her dreams and the significance of the test, and she will always hold onto the hope of success.

The author concludes the story with the last paragraph of the story. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself that in the spring, when the snows gradually melt, the geese gracefully return, and this hibiscus is gently budding, she will take that test again.
I guess she felt that it was a good way to unite us all together in a meaningful way.

In “Winter Hibiscus”, the author concludes with Saeng saying “I will take that test, again”. When Saeng bought the hibiscus, she was certain that as soon as the winter passes with the gentle coming of spring, she is sure that taking the driver's test again will be easier to overcome the fear and the grieving times in this new place. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it vividly shows her determination. In the spring, it will be quite hard for the hibiscus to survive because it's a winter hibiscus and it also displays remarkable determination.

I believe the author used that statement to end the story because by the end Saeng was truly ready to bravely face her obstacles again. Also, it shows that she was sincerely appreciating her new environment. The plant that Saeng purchased, her mother stated that, “it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here”. It's clearly telling Saeng that if the plant can make it through the harsh conditions then just maybe she can make it through living in a new country. When Saeng realized that things had a repeating season upon season, she must have realized that she can do it too, and face the driving test again with newfound courage.

The author, MiNfoNg Ho, concluded the story with "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the Spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." This is because when the plant begins to blossom, she will feel more confident and comfortable. Throughout the story, one can see how she's trying to adapt to new surroundings. I believe that the hibiscus represents comfort at times of disappointment and a connection to her past experiences. Since the hibiscus offers this comfort during disappointing moments, it's the reason she went out and purchased the plant. So, when spring comes again and the hibiscus is fully bloomed, that's why she'll take the test again as she will feel more at ease in and with her surroundings. The past experiences of our lives often influence various aspects of our daily existence, whether we consciously recognize it or not. In this story, Saeng attempts to go to the flower shop and pass the test of not buying the certain flower that reminds her of her home. Unfortunately, she fails. She is grappling with the fact that she is no longer “at home,” where the familiar things and people that once grounded her are no longer present. However, there are new elements in her life that she is gradually getting used to. I think that the author ends the story with the paragraph he did to show that change is always possible. She is trying to push the things that trigger her longing further back in her mind. With time, perhaps even by next year, she can achieve this. It is always possible to accomplish something if one truly desires it, and the author is demonstrating that Saeng really wants to pass her own mental test so she can better adapt to the changes. When she does, her mother will be proud of her, highlighting the theme of growth and resilience in the face of change.

I think that she was expressing in that way to say, “Hey, I didn't overcome something this time, but I'll be back next year to take the test again.” Just like the hibiscus buds when the snow melts and the geese return the following year, she sees the cycle of nature as a symbol of renewal and second chances. This shows her determination and hope for a better outcome in the future. It's a powerful message of perseverance and the belief that setbacks are only temporary.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wanted the readers to know that Saeng was going to take the test over again. By ending the story this way, the author emphasizes Saeng's determination and resilience. It gives the readers a sense of hope that despite the current setback, Saeng is not giving up. Instead, she is ready to face the challenge once more, which also serves as an inspiration for the readers to persevere in their own lives when faced with difficulties.
The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wanted the readers to know that Saeng was going to take the test over again.

When Saeng said that she will go and take the test over next year, she specifically means trying to plant the plants all over again from scratch. When Saeng says “Here, let me help, mother,” right then you can clearly know that Saeng does genuinely want to help with the plants after all.

The author's choice of the last paragraph in the short story, “Winter Hibiscus,” vividly shows the hope for the future that Saeng feels. The speaker @MONTH1 concludes the story with that paragraph because the geese returning and the hibiscus budding @MONTH1 significantly help her boost her confidence. She sincerely wants to feel like she has the ability to do this test and succeed.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “when they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese returned and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” She realizes that she has another real chance to pass the test. Saeng finds deep comfort in memories of her homeland. When she took that test, everything around her was completely unfamiliar to her, so unfortunately, she failed. But on her way back, something familiar unexpectedly found her, the native plants of her home. “There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood - red blossom,” “floating in the bucket.” Saeng truly needs familiar things to comfort herself. The author of Winter Hibiscus ended the story with the paragraph, “when they came back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She did this because she bought the flower right after she failed the test. So, when the flower blooms, symbolizing new growth and a fresh start, she will take the test again, hoping for a better outcome.

I'll think the author tried to say that when it's coming to the time of snow melt, like in @MONTH1, then she will come back. The author will do so because in the spring season, at some point, she plans to write a new book, perhaps inspired by the renewal and fresh beginnings that spring represents.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” uses this paragraph to conclude her story because it is a powerful symbol of Saeng’s future. Winter Hibiscus is a symbol of Saeng for many reasons. For one, both Saeng and the plant are originally from Vietnam, and both have to struggle to survive and thrive in the new and unfamiliar world of the @ORGANIZATION1. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author most likely chose this as the last paragraph to help the reader better understand the underlying message. The message of this story is that no matter what happens or what challenges you face, never give up and always keep trying. By making this the last paragraph, the author encourages the reader to think deeply and ponder upon what this determination and perseverance truly mean in their own lives.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph for one key reason. That reason is because Saeng believes she failed because she got a fake plant instead of a real one. When she brought it home, she felt a deep sense of disappointment. For example, she said “I failed,” clearly referring to the plant. She also makes comparisons between where she is now and where she used to live. For instance, she said “it’s not like the one at home,” highlighting the differences and her longing for the familiarity of her past.
