“When they comeback, Saeng vowed to herself, in the gentle spring when the heavy snows gradually melt and the elegant geese gracefully return and this delicate hibiscus is just budding, then I will take that test again.” There are multiple connections of this statement with the story. First of all, she adores being in the charming garden, and, as the rules go, one is not allowed to be in the garden when it snows. Second of all, she has a deep - seated love for plants and all things similar to plants. That’s precisely why the author concluded the paragraph to the story. When spring arrives, Saeng is eager to purchase various plants and colorful flowers. Last of all, Saeng spots a familiar plant. Later, she heads to a well - stocked florist shop to check if it can be purchased. She gets extremely upset when something goes awry with them, but this doesn't dampen her spirit for the upcoming test.

In the text, when the mother tenderly said, “It’s flowers aren’t as showy, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold, harsh months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” This simple yet profound sentence clearly shows that Saeng is just like these resilient flowers. They are tough enough to endure the biting winter, and when spring arrives, they reveal their true beauty, being both very pretty and strong. This emphasizes that Saeng will also grow stronger and become more confident in the warmth of spring. That’s exactly why the author placed this statement at the end. It is a perfect reflection of the flower's journey, just as they display their charm and strength in spring, Saeng too will shine in her own way.

In the short story, “Winter Hibiscus,” by Minfong Ho, the author includes a poignant paragraph at the end, stating that the main character, Saeng, will take her driving test again. Ho includes this paragraph to vividly show that Saeng is determined to adapt. Saeng is newly arrived in the United States; she and her mother had left their homeland, Vietnam, and journeyed here. Throughout the story, she often slips into a state of reminiscence about her idyllic home life in Vietnam. She fondly remembers her kind - hearted grandmother and the vibrant flowers that bloomed there. “Where was me...hibiscus hedge?... Her gentle grandmother?” When at the bustling flower shop, Saeng's eyes light up as she finds an hibiscus, a flower they also cherished in Vietnam. She observes how it has adapted to survive the cold winter here. As she carefully plants the flower in her backyard, with dirt on her hands and hope in her heart, she makes a solemn promise to herself to pass the driving test next spring. She too, yearns to become well - adapted to the new environment and be able to live here without constantly missing home. This vow she made is included in the last paragraph. The author included it to show that Saeng, like the hibiscus, wants to adapt to her surroundings and finally pass the driving test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly illustrate the true meaning of the hibiscus. The hibiscus is symbolic to Saeng in numerous ways, but the most crucial one is that it represents change and growth and the remarkable ability to overcome obstacles. When she first sets her eyes on it, a flood of childhood memories and a wave of sentimentality wash over her. However, she realizes that if she wants to evolve as a person, she must adjust to her new home. She will persevere here, just as the hibiscus will weather through the long, cold winter. Also, Saeng firmly vows that “in the spring” when “this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She is resolutely determined to succeed, and the hibiscus itself is a powerful symbol of triumph over obstacles. It stands for survival and endurance through life’s many disappointments and challenges, from the setback of failing a driver’s test to the daunting task of starting a new life in a strange and foreign country. The author’s thoughtful choice to end the story with this paragraph clearly exhibits Saeng’s ultimate understanding of her inner strength through the powerful symbol of the hibiscus, leaving the readers with hope for her future.

I believe that the author concludes the paragraph like that because he/she wanted to convey an important message to the audience. The message that the author was striving to get across was that even though she didn't pass the test on this attempt, she was determined to try again next year. An excellent example of this unwavering determination is an exact quote: “in the spring when the snow slowly melts and the geese return in large flocks and the hibiscus is budding with new life, then I will take the test again.” The use of these vivid seasonal details not only sets a hopeful tone but also shows that Saeng is waiting for the right time to make a comeback. This is precisely why I think the author concludes the story in such an inspiring way, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism for Saeng's journey ahead.

The author includes the story with this paragraph because since Saeng failed her driver's test for the very first time when the hibiscus starts to bud, this budding hibiscus will represent a significant change in her life. Also, Saeng used to have beautiful hibiscus flowers at her old home in Vietnam. So, when the flower buds in her new environment, it could clearly show that she has established a new home. This connection between the hibiscus and her life events adds depth to the story.

The author finished the story with, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason for this conclusion is that it is extremely important for Saeng to feel truly at home. When the hibiscus buds, it will vividly remind her of her home in Vietnam and this will greatly comfort her. When she feels at peace and at home, she will perform better on the test, thus showing her growth and resilience.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to clearly show that she is not giving up on her new home nor forgetting her old one. She shows she is not giving up when she carefully brings home the flower to plant in her new place. That act also clearly shows she will not forget her old home in Vietnam. Also, when she says, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” That statement shows she is giving her new home another sincere shot and is not giving up easily. Another example is when it says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” Here she is gradually accepting the changes and giving her new home another fair chance. She is firmly not giving up on it, which is a positive sign of her adaptation.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph. She does so because she is fully ready to do the same enjoyable things next year. She truly likes spending quality time with her mom, she has a great fondness for plants, and she loves having a lot of fun with her mom. These are some of the clear - cut reasons why she concludes with that paragraph, as it reflects the positive experiences and relationships that are important to her.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the hibiscus provides deep - seated comfort. After Saeng failed her driving test and was new to a foreign place, she was extremely frustrated and was deeply missing her real home in Vietnam. The hibiscus, with its lovely fragrance, reminded her of her dear grandmother. She writes “she closed her eyes and breathed in deeply as the fragrance filled her lungs” after Saeng smelled the flower it vividly reminded her of “combing her grandmother’s long grey hair, freshly washed”. It brought her much - needed comfort in a time of great disappointment. Since she didn’t have her grandmother with her, the flower became a source of solace. Although she was disappointed, the hibiscus was “exquisite” and as she said the native word “dokor malik” meaning hibiscus, she “savored the feel of the word on her tongue”. The joy and comfort that the flower brings to Saeng are palpable. She will take the test again in the spring when “the snow melts and the hibiscus is budding”, thus effectively bringing joy, love, and comfort to the reader as they can truly feel what Saeng feels.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because it intricately relates the idea of the hibiscus to Saeng and her challenging situation in a new country. It clearly shows that Saeng is deeply using the hibiscus and its remarkable ability to adapt as a powerful source of inspiration. During the story, Saeng vividly describes how she had always fondly seen the hibiscus at home in her old country. Her mom gently describes to her that the hibiscus she bought is a bit different from the one back home. But she reassuringly says it’s because it’s strong and was able to bravely adapt to the cold, harsh winter environment of the United States. This is precisely what Saeng was able to use as inspiration. She might have unfortunately failed her license test, but she astutely used the hibiscus actions to set a clear goal for herself. The plant will patiently go through a cold, and snowy winter but it will surely grow and beautifully blossom in the spring. Saeng would use that time to diligently study and get fully ready, and she’ll be confidently prepared for the test. The paragraph that the author finishes on effectively shows the profound connection Saeng made with her own situation and the plant’s situation, highlighting her potential for growth and adaptation.

“If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again.” This well - known quote is commonly used by many caring parents trying to warmly encourage their children or by dedicated coaches to strongly motivate their team. The quote can also very aptly apply to Saeng’s situation in the short story, “Winter Hibiscus.” Saeng disappointingly fails her driver's test and, when slowly walking home after the test, she attentively notices a hibiscus flower which sweetly reminds her of her far - away homeland. Deep sadness completely encompasses her and she decides to purchase the plant to gently pacify her intense grief. She carefully brings it home and is at first mildly reprimanded by her mother but then sincerely thanked for buying it. While Saeng is tenderly planting the hibiscus, she clearly hears the honk of Canada geese which had gradually become familiar to her by then. The text says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, become familiar to her.” This quote effectively shows the difficult adaptation she had to face in coming to @LOCATION1. The author concludes the story with the paragraph to clearly show that like the hibiscus flower, she will bravely adapt to the tough terrain and toils of @LOCATION1. The hibiscus inspires her to firmly push forward and try again for her license as the plant valiantly pushed forward through the harsh winter.

The author ends the story this way because Saeng deeply feels a strong sense of comfort with the hibiscus flower. The flower vividly reminds her of her beloved homeland with her dear grandmother. According to the story “the familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost tenderly feel the light strands of her grandmother's long gray hair.” You can also clearly tell she misses her homeland but always keeps it close to her heart wherever she goes. The text states that, “it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers.” She seems to be very closely connected with nature and all of its wonderful and desirable traits. When she failed the test, she bought her “@CAPS1 Malik” flower as a kind of gentle sense of comfort. They both decided to lovingly plant it in their garden and while doing so, Saeng received a huge, uplifting boost of confidence to retake the test, showing how the flower's presence can bring about positive change.

She compares the paragraph to the story to draw a parallel with school. The test in this comparison represents the challenging tasks of making new friends and performing well on the test and in classes. In the paragraph, it clearly said “Then I will take that test again.” This is the exact reason she is comparing that paragraph to school. By making this comparison, she is expressing her determination to face the difficulties in school, just as the person in the paragraph is determined to retake the test, highlighting the importance of perseverance in academic and social aspects.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to strongly emphasize Saeng's unwavering determination to overcome the numerous obstacles of her past experience. For example, the story starts out with Saeng nervously taking a ‘test’. While reliving her precious memories in the greenhouse, she started to emotionally breakdown. “A wave of loss so deep and strong it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her.” She then sadly buys the plant and takes it home to her mother, tearfully telling her that she ‘failed’. The mother then becomes understanding and gently helps Saeng vow to retake the ‘test’. The narrator effectively emphasizes Saeng’s determination to overcome the troubles of her past and bravely go on with the future, showing that she has the strength to move forward despite her setbacks.

Because her school work, specifically a botany - related assignment, was the whole reason as to why she was studying flowers in a well - maintained green garden. And it is quite obvious she failed the test, perhaps due to insufficient knowledge about the local flora. So when spring starts to show its gentle signs, she will retake the test because the flowers will be in full bloom, and she can do more in - depth study to pass the test and not have to take it again. I get the feeling though she is also looking forward to the spring time coming back these days so she can enjoy the colorful flowers and the presence of nature while growing her knowledge through studying.

I think that the author concluded the story with that particular paragraph because she wanted us to see that Saeng, a determined young girl, was not giving up. Saeng was originally from Vietnam, a country full of rich culture and beautiful landscapes, but she moved to the United States, a place with a very different environment. She missed being home so much because nothing was the same, from the food to the scenery. “It’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. “I mean, not like the kind we had at - at...”. She found that she was still too shaky to say the words “at home”. But once Saeng finally realized that she was beginning to adapt to the life in the United States, with its new routines and customs, she decided that she was going to give the driver's test one more try. “When they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This shows her resilience and hope for a better future.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because she seems to feel more comfortable when she saw the geese flying gracefully in the winter sky and plants the hibiscus, a symbol of her homeland, in the winter and carefully keeps it from dying. In the story it said, “... their faint banks clear and - yes - familiar to Saeng now”. I think this is vividly explaining how she feels after seeing the geese fly overhead because she used to see that in Vietnam, a sight that brought back warm memories. Also, “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding”, she gains more confidence because she feels like she’s back in Vietnam, surrounded by the familiar signs of nature. All in all, that's why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, to show Saeng's emotional connection with nature and her journey of adaptation.

I think the reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to allow the reader to imaginatively picture what happens next once spring rolls around for Saeng. This allows the reader to use their creative imagination to deeply connect to the story on a personal level. Another reason why the author chose to conclude the story like that with that paragraph was to give a glimmer of hope to the reader that maybe she will pass the test next time, as she has shown growth and determination throughout the story. It was also a way to end the story on a positive and heart - warming note, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism about Saeng's future.

The author ended the story with that particular paragraph because like the geese that migrate and return, she will be back to try again. Just in case she didn't get to finish just about everything she wanted to do, such as passing the driver's test or fully adjusting to the new life. And the author wanted the reader to know the strong determination and unwavering ambition of the character in the story. Also to show the readers that the character's positive characteristics couldn't be beaten by one harsh winter and that she is going to keep going at it until she does what she has to do, which is a powerful message about perseverance.

The author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” most likely concludes it with the paragraph of Saeng vowing to retake the test to show that even in difficult times and new situations, a person can never give up and sink into despair, and that there are always things to comfort someone. In the story, glimpses of Saeng's home are given in her memories, and from them, the reader can clearly understand what a difficult day Saeng is having. The author is carefully describing these warm, comforting memories to create a sharp contrast with the cold, bitter day the girl is experiencing. “She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs.” Here, Saeng vividly recalls a memory of her grandmother, and it saddens her at the thought of her home and her loss. The author gradually builds up Saeng's despair and upset for the final paragraph. The author has this as the final paragraph because it shows hope. As Saeng says, “then I will take that test again,” you can truly feel her hope. Also, the author wants to express how there is still structure and stability in a changing world and that you can look to the simple things. Saeng says, “the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” and this shows how there are some reliable things that can give you security when you think you have none. The author uses this last paragraph to balance the feeling of despair in the story, to emphasize the need for hope, and to show that there are always things that can give you hope and security.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author would like to neatly finish the last sentence of the story. Also, at the end of the paragraph, Saeng is visualizing and devoting her effort to the hibiscus. Therefore, her thoughts are sincerely appreciated towards the plant. The author wanted to add more evidence to the story. For example, when it said, “in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” It includes the winter time for the plant. Also, as the winter passes and spring arrives, the plant comes back to life, which symbolizes that the character Saeng will regain her strength and visit it once again. In this way, the author uses this ending to convey a sense of renewal and hope.

The author made it seem like he did not like it, but in reality, he loved flowers and enjoyed working in the yard with the people. His mom is an important part of his life, and he liked to see her getting along well. He believed that things that had passed would come back because they truly liked the place. This shows that despite any initial appearances, there was a deep - seated affection for the environment and the people around him, and he had an optimistic view that positive things would return to this special place.

The author includes this at the end to show how much the character Saeng cares about the plant, and that the plant's scent has brought her back to her childhood. An example of her loving the plant is described as “that rich scent” (Paragraph Minfong Ho). Another example is “It felt smooth and cool” (paragraph Minfong Ho), which shows her close interaction with the plant. An example of the plant triggering childhood memories is that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten. When she comes back to the plant, it is as if she can relive those forgotten moments (paragraphs Minfong Ho). For these reasons, it is clear that the author adds this at the end to highlight the emotional connection between the character and the plant and the power of childhood memories.

I believe that the author left this as the last thing the reader will read so it will be a powerful message. In the story, this girl has now moved to a totally new environment and a new culture. The only thing she was familiar with was a flower that grew wild where she used to live. This little vow to herself was a clear message to not give up. She should keep on going, and if she opens her mind to new things, who knows what she can experience and learn. So this girl didn't just give up easily. Her plant was like a beautiful representation of a new beginning. When her plant starts to grow anew, she decides that she will also start afresh. Also, it can be a representation of her life itself. I say a new beginning because in the text, it says that change is inevitable but with hope, one can overcome difficulties and start anew. The girl's vow in relation to the plant serves as an inspiring reminder that there is always a chance for a fresh start in life, no matter how challenging the circumstances.

I think the author wrote that because maybe that's how she feels. In the winter, she could truly show people who she is. But when spring comes out, she's like a flower that has been dead all winter, unable to fully express her true self.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the paragraph before, they were specifically talking about the “winter hibiscus” and the geese. So, the author simply writes another concluding paragraph that neatly wraps the story up. As a result, the reader walks away with a feel - good feeling, having a sense of closure.

In the story “The Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, it vividly explains the numerous obstacles Saeng went through when coming to a different country. In this story, Saeng had just failed her driving test, and as she was looking at some tropical flowers, she was strongly reminded of her home. Moreover, the author writes at the end of the story referring to geese, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, it's the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This part of the story is very important because it carefully examines her growth and her hope for change, just as the geese will come back and the hibiscus will change into a beautiful blossomed flower. Furthermore, it clearly explains to the reader that she will not give up and that she will adapt to the environment just as the plant's life has changed and the geese come back to the changed environment. That part of the story is very important for the reader, as it concludes Saeng's thoughts and hopes for the future while she is adapting to her new environment.

The author could have concluded the story with this paragraph for many reasons. I think the author wanted to give an interesting fact about what happens to hibiscus when it snows. For example, the author explains in detail how the hibiscus grows and the essential things that are needed for it to grow, like an adequate amount of sunlight, sufficient water, fertile soil, and proper waste management. Maybe the author figured that by explaining that when it snows, the growth process begins all over again, it would add a meaningful touch to the story's conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng clearly said she failed the test. And she made a firm decision that when spring comes back, then she will take the test again. The last paragraph reads, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” However, she really does not tell us precisely what test she is supposed to be taking, leaving a bit of mystery for the reader.

The reason why she said she will wait until spring to take the test again is to see if she’s still preferring the bitter melon over the Big - Mac, which might reflect her long - term taste and lifestyle preferences.

The author concludes the end of this story with this paragraph because of this saying about taking the test again. What she means by this is that she will have to do the same thing next year, much like facing similar challenges and making necessary adjustments. She will have to adapt to life just like the hibiscus did, learning to thrive in different circumstances. She is also saying to do her best because everything in the world is about living to your fullest. So, it is indeed a good conclusion for the story as it ties in important life lessons.

I think that the reason the author concludes the story like that is that it has an awe - inspiring ending. It leaves a strong impression on the readers. Also, it makes it clear that the story has a sense of openness, suggesting that they could make more, perhaps sequels or related stories.

What the author concludes is that in the springtime when the snows melt and the flowers come back, it creates a sense of the risk and beauty of springtime at home. The changing of the season from the cold of winter to the warmth of spring brings a certain unpredictability. Which makes her relax as she can enjoy the new beginning. Also, springtime is a more pretty time because all the flowers are out, and the particular flower that reminds her of home blessings adds a touch of nostalgia and comfort.

Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. Saeng is going to wait to take the test when she knows that she will pass the test so she can get her license. Having a license is important to Saeng as she wants to drive anywhere she wants to go. So, she doesn't have to get her mom to take her everywhere she wants to go; she can take herself anywhere she desires. But she has to wait till the snows have melted before she takes her test again as she believes that the springtime will bring her the right state of mind and conditions for success.

The paragraph clearly shows that Saeng has a deep - seated and profound range of feelings for her plants. She genuinely takes pleasure in the presence of plants and whole - heartedly loves taking the time to be in the company of the plants, nurturing them and observing their growth. What she means in that last paragraph is that she is extremely eager for winter to pass so that her plants will start budding. Once that happens, she can once again fully enjoy the beauty and tranquility that her plants bring.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it effectively ties all the loose ends together, creating a cohesive narrative. I think that the author also uses it to convey the idea that in the spring, she will pass the test. I really like the part when she says "Öin the spring, when the snows meltÖ." I like that because it clearly explains what she desires and how she is determined, putting her whole mind into achieving her goal.

The author most likely uses this paragraph to show her setting a clear goal for the cycle to start over anew. She skillfully uses geese as a well - known symbol for spring. When spring arrives, she would start preparing for this “test” once again with renewed vigor. The hibiscus budding in this paragraph serves as a powerful symbol of hope. It is, once again, a start of a new cycle as well as an object that brings back fond reminiscences in the story. In conclusion, this concluding paragraph uses several symbols and literary devices in order to effectively convey hope, evoke good memories, and signify a fresh start.

She would carefully grow some beautiful flowers in her garden and eagerly await the time when the geese come back to her pond. As the geese return, it would bring a sense of life and activity to the otherwise quiet pond area, creating a harmonious and peaceful scene.

THE AUTHOR CONCLUDES THE STORY WITH THAT PARAGRAPH FOR MANY REASONS. ONE PRIMARY REASON BEING THAT THE AUTHOR WANTED TO really bring out and emphasize the true meaning of the flower. ANOTHER IMPORTANT REASON IS TO EXPRESS THE THEME IN A CLEAR AND CONCISE MANNER. FOR EXAMPLE, AT THE END OF THAT PARAGRAPH IT SAYS “THEN I WILL TAKE THAT TEST AGAIN.”, IT'S SMARTLY RELATING THAT SMALL TOPIC OF THE DRIVING TEST TO THE LARGER TOPIC OF THE FLOWER. WHICH THEN EFFICIENTLY RELATES IT TO THE THEME OF ADJUSTING AND KEEPING TRYING TILL YOU ADJUST. THAT LAST PARAGRAPH WAS QUITE VITAL TO THE THEME AND MEANING OF THE STORY, HELPING READERS FULLY GRASP THE UNDERLYING MESSAGE.

I believe the author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus”, written by Minfong Ho, with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”, because she is trying to show how past memories can be transformed into hope and determination. After failing her driving test, Saeng is disheartened. Then she finds the Hibiscus, and the memories of her homeland and her dear grandmother completely consume her. She decides to buy the plant and carefully puts it in the vegetable garden. After she is done planting, Saeng looks up and sees a flock of Canada geese gracefully fly overhead. Using her vivid memory of her old home and her loving family, and applying those warm feelings to her new surroundings, Saeng firmly vows to re - take the test, to give it another try. The author ends the story “Winter Hibiscus” with that paragraph to show that Saeng will not give up and will face challenges with renewed strength.

The author concludes with this story to show how Saeng is ready to whole - heartedly accept her new life. Once the geese return and the hibiscus starts to bloom, she feels as if she's truly at home. When she has that comforting feeling of being at home, she will be mentally and emotionally ready to take the test again. The text states “when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. Clearly, the sight of the geese and the beautiful hibiscus vividly remind her of her home. Once she feels at home, she will feel completely at ease, free from the stress and anxiety. That's precisely why the author concluded with this passage, to emphasize Saeng's journey towards acceptance and self - confidence.

Why the author concluded with this paragraph was because it effectively restated the main idea of the story. By using this concluding paragraph, the key themes and messages of the story were clearly highlighted, allowing the readers to fully understand what the story was about. The author wrapped up the narrative in a way that tied all the loose ends together and made the story's essence crystal clear. That is why the author concluded the story with that paragraph, as it was a perfect way to end the tale and leave a lasting impression on the readers.

The author explains that she has failed the test. It is still the cold winter season, and the hibiscus is struggling to grow its lovely petals back. The plant looks a bit frail in the harsh winter weather. As she tells her mother, with a determined look in her eyes, “that she will not take the test again, until the hibiscus starts budding and spring is back”. This shows her connection between the growth of the hibiscus and her own readiness to face the test once more.

Yes, I do think that this concludes the story because after all of the events in the story and all the valuable lessons she learned about gardening from her mother, she clearly remembers what her mother had said about the hibiscus and its budding. The memory of her mother's words is like a guiding light. And what she means by this ending sentence is that when the pleasant spring time comes, with its warm sunshine and gentle breeze, then she is going to take that test again. The test will be a crucial moment that determines whether or not she has learned enough about gardening from her mother over the past time. This ending neatly wraps up the story, showing her growth and the connection between nature and her personal development.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because I guess her grandma passed away while the geese were in flight. Or perhaps that's precisely when the flowers start to gracefully bloom, creating a bittersweet connection to the loss.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” included the last paragraph to convey to readers that she will be moving on, but still remembering her old country with fondness. Before finding the flower, the author terribly missed her old country, yearning for the familiar sights and sounds. “It’s - it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. “I mean not like the kind we had at - at …” she found that she was still too shaky to say the words “at home,” and last, she burst into tears again. She missed her home in the other country and was having trouble getting past that deep sense of longing. The author could not accept her new country as home yet. For Saeng, the hibiscus flower brought back vivid memories of her old country, making it even more difficult to move on. “One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine - toothed buffalo - horn comb.” The flower was too much of a precious memory. She finally had something from home that she could hold in her hands. “Gently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold onto.” The author now had a solid thing to remind her of home. This was the first step to finally moving on. Now Saeng needed some time to get used to her new country. “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many things that she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now.” Saeng needed just a little more time, almost like a hibernation. She decided once the hibiscus came out of hibernation, and was ready to bloom, she would be ready to whole - heartedly accept her new country and move on. Saeng decided the time between fall and spring would be long enough to adjust to her new life. By taking the test, Saeng will be moving on. The author included this last paragraph so that readers can infer that Saeng will take the last steps towards acceptance of her new country and move on by taking the test, although she will look back on her old country through the winter hibiscus with a mix of nostalgia and gratitude.

The story includes this paragraph because at the very beginning of the story the girl failed the test. When she told her mother, she clearly saw that her mother was upset with the result. So after they planted the plant, she decided to take the test over, knowing that her mother would think the best of her effort. Also, it's in there because the story started out with her telling her mother that she failed the test. And if you kept it out, people who read it would be like, “ok, so her mother just let her fail the test and didn't do anything about it.” Plus, when the reader reads that the girl failed the test, they are going to be wanting to know if she took it again, and why she took it again if she did, as it adds an element of resolution and character development to the story.

The author ended the story with an unconcluded ending. What I mean is the author wrote in such a way that he could keep readers deeply interested so that they would be eager to read his other books. Also, with an ending of that sort, it kind of leaves room for further improvement and room for a sequel, allowing the readers' imaginations to continue the story in their own minds and creating an anticipation for more from the author.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is not going to give up until she successfully passes the task her mother gives her. Saeng fails the test because, though she buys a beautiful plant, it is much too expensive. “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn't cost that much!” Saeng becomes very upset and realizes with a heavy heart that she has failed her mother. However, Saeng still plants the winter hibiscus in the ground. “Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it.” This shows that even though she had failed, she wasn't going to give up on the hibiscus because it represented her home in a very profound way. It was very special to her, and she was determined to nurture it and see it thrive, just as she hoped to thrive in her new situation.

The Author concludes the paragraph because she wants to convey a specific message within the narrative. Throughout the text, certain themes and ideas have been presented, and by concluding with this paragraph, she ties up loose ends and summarizes the key points. This helps the reader to fully understand the overall meaning and purpose of the piece.

I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph because it clearly shows that the character in the story, Saeng, is starting to adapt to her new country. In the beginning of the story, Saeng is deeply feeling homesick and has not yet adapted to her new surroundings. She is on her way home from her driver’s test, which she just failed. During this journey, she spots a hibiscus in a flower shop. The hibiscus is incredibly special to her because it vividly reminds her of her home country of Vietnam. For Saeng, the hibiscus represents comfort in a time of disappointment, a strong connection to her past experiences, and the ability to overcome obstacles. Saeng has not adjusted well to this change in her life, and it has affected her negatively. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because he wanted to show the reader that there will always be changes and obstacles in your life, but there will always be something or someone that will help you overcome them. The author shows this by concluding the story with this paragraph and demonstrating to the reader that Saeng sees the hibiscus as her way of overcoming difficulties, and when she is ready and has adjusted, she will take her driving test again, determined to succeed.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he’s saying that once the cold winter and the rejuvenating spring are over and the hibiscus is budding beautifully, then Saeng will start over again and bravely try once more. The author is indicating that Saeng can hardly wait till spring so she can plant her own little garden full of hope and new beginnings. This is precisely why I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph, as it leaves the reader with a sense of optimism and the promise of a fresh start.

This paragraph represents an action that Saeng is going to undertake over a time period of a year. She is going to gradually build up and transform herself in time for the retake of the test; it's like a symbolic rebirth in a way. The girl sincerely wants to be a whole new person when the test comes up again. Her mom seems to be constantly bothered by every action or choice of her daughter. Saeng suddenly realizes the significance of the hibiscus and why it goes through its cycle of dying and rebirth. "... thought the quiet repetition of season upon season." She closely relates the flower and the geese to herself. Over the year, the flower goes through distinct phases, dying and then being reborn. Saeng wants to get better once she goes through a similar phase like the flower. Just like the flower that opens up to be beautiful again, Saeng hopes to emerge stronger and more capable after her own period of growth and change.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is that when Saeng comes back from taking the driver's test on the way home, she sees a winter hibiscus that is so strikingly beautiful. Then she goes to the store and buys that flower, and it costs a significant amount of money. When she gets home, her mom is busy planting vegetables, and her mom asks her what that is. So she tells the truth, and when her mom knows that the flower costs a lot of money, she gets very mad at Saeng's extravagance. How could she do that? Saeng makes a big decision that she is going to keep the flower even though her mom is mad. I guess she loves that flower because it vividly reminds her of her time in Vietnam. The author puts this paragraph, I think, because when the geese return and the flowers are in full growth, she will take the test again. When she bought the flower, no blossoms had come out yet, so when it finally blooms, she will go again. This is to let her know that you need to see the first signs of progress and wait until it fully develops before you can take on a challenge again. In my opinion, that is a good ending, and it also poses a thought - provoking question too.

The author concludes the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself...," because it offers the reader a fitting conclusion. That passage means that once Saeng has properly adjusted to her new life in a new country, she will try taking her driver's test again. Once she can find a sense of familiarity in her new surroundings, she will feel more at home. Throughout the story, her detachment from Vietnam makes her feel isolated. The hibiscus plant is what first offers her a sense of comfort, as described by "It felt smooth and cool... just as she had known it would feel." The ending paragraph shows that Saeng will find more sources of comfort in @LOCATION2 than just a plant and a couple of geese, indicating her gradual adaptation to the new environment.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when the “snow does melt and the Geese return,” it will be an ideal time to plant and work in the garden even more intensively. This is because with snow covering the ground, planting is not possible. The return of the geese signals the appropriate time of the year to plant the seeds and aim for a more bountiful harvest. The test mentioned is to see if she can achieve a better grade than in the previous year and the year before that, demonstrating her desire for improvement and growth.

The author concluded his story with that paragraph because that is the most suitable way for it to end. The chosen ending aligns well with the overall narrative and themes presented in the story. It provides a natural and satisfying conclusion, which is why the author decided to end it in such a manner.

The author concludes the story with “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She does this to show that now Saeng is adapting and making decisions in her new country just as she did in her homeland. In Vietnam, Saeng used to engage in a heart - warming tradition of brushing her grandmother's hair, helping put it into a bun, and placing a hibiscus in it. Another instance was when she used to get water from the well, and sometimes a hibiscus would come up with the bucket. These experiences made the hibiscus a significant comfort object for her. Now, as she is in the states, she is trying to put it to good use while also taking into account the natural cycles that repeat in the states. She notices that the geese come back in the spring and leave in the winter, and plants start to grow in the spring. By her taking the test again in the spring, it is symbolizing that she is ready to start anew, just like the hibiscus that is going to bloom. The plant being potted in her garden and Saeng's own movement both signify change, but also a remembrance of old traditions, and create a space for new beginnings.

The author put that sentence in the story because she believes that setting the time as described will give her enough time to thoroughly prepare and get the test right. Additionally, she has a fondness for geese. The presence of the geese in the sentence not only adds a natural and seasonal element but also reflects her positive feelings towards these creatures, which may contribute to her motivation and sense of calm when thinking about taking the test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly show the final determination and inner strength that Saeng has been given. It’s almost as though it’s taken this special plant to inspire her to get back up and bravely pass the Test. The plant becomes a comforting item that constantly reminds her of her beloved homeland. She returned with the plant to show her mother but found herself too emotionally shaky to even utter the words “at home”. This clearly shows how deeply she misses home. But she is gradually able to realize that this is her new home and everything is slowly becoming more familiar to her, marking her growth and adaptation.

She ends it with this sentence because it's a clear sign of new life. Just as the harsh winter that killed the plants and ended their life cycle, the gentle spring will surely come and start everything anew. This is precisely how Saeng feels because she left her country and all the precious memories were left behind. She feels out of place, much like the winter hibiscus struggling in the cold. But as the spring arrives, she'll feel like a brand - new person, fully ready and able to take on challenges. As she said here, “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now”. She describes that with a new season comes new changes, and upon those changes, she will go on to take the drivers test again with renewed confidence.

The author ends with that paragraph for several well - thought - out reasons. One important reason is to show that although she has failed this time, numerous more opportunities will come later. Also, it clearly shows that even though difficult times befall her at present, good times are still on the horizon. For these valid reasons, it was a powerful and efficient way to end the story, leaving a lasting impression on the readers.

The author uses symbolism to convey a different and profound message. Saeng said in the spring, when the snows gradually melt and the geese gracefully return and this hibiscus is budding, and then she will take that test again. The author uses the hibiscus to symbolize that as Saeng gets older, just like the hibiscus going through its growth cycle, she will then be fully ready to take that test again. By using symbolism, the author can convey more of the story's essence and depth to the readers.

She wrote that response to tell everyone that she will be truly ready by the time when spring comes. Spring represents a time of renewal and growth for her. Then she will take the test with determination and pass it, achieving her goal and moving forward in her new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng, whose life is deeply intertwined with the cycle of planting, wants to start planting again. I know this because Saeng's entire life revolves around planting and the natural rhythms of the seasons. Saeng and her mother rely on what they plant for their food. So, throughout the growing season, they spend most of their time in the garden, carefully growing crops both to sell and to save. They save the produce for the harsh winter months and sell the surplus to acquire the equipment needed to continue their way of life. The part she's talking about in the paragraph that says “when they come back” is referring to the geese. She adores the sight of the geese flying over her head and gracefully landing in the yard on a beautiful day. When the snow melts, she yearns to get back down on her hands and knees in the soil to start planting again. Once the hibiscus starts budding, it's a sign that everything else will start growing. Saeng's life truly revolves around the planting season. The author put this paragraph in the story because this is what Saeng wants to do more than anything, and it encapsulates the essence of her connection to the land and nature.

In the conclusion of the “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng notes how she will retake her driving test in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return. The spring season is when these natural events occur, along with the annual budding of the winter hibiscus. Her family had moved from Vietnam to a new location, [LOCATION2], and she had bought a winter hibiscus plant to remind her of her childhood in Vietnam. When the hibiscus blooms, she will retake her driving test because the blooming of the hibiscus will bring her the hope of a new beginning in her life, and as a citizen in [LOCATION2], it represents a fresh start and a step forward in her journey of adaptation and integration.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” a young girl named Saeng moves away from her familiar home environment. This short story depicts how the girl is trying to adapt to the new lifestyle and the numerous changes that come with moving to a new place. She has to adjust to different customs, a new climate, and new social dynamics. Despite the challenges, she is gradually learning to find her footing in this unfamiliar world, showing her resilience and determination to make this new place her home.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants the reader to clearly see that Saeng will not stop until she passes her driver's test, much like the geese won't stop their long - distance migration until they reach the warm south for the winter. The author uses this comparison to emphasize Saeng's tenacity and determination. Through this, the author is trying to show the beauty of perseverance, of trying again and again, and of facing and overcoming the obstacles that stand in the way of achieving one's goal. In the end, it's a powerful message about the strength of the human spirit and the importance of not giving up.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by [CAPS1] Ho, the author leaves the story off with a powerful ending. The ending was “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will try the test again”. Basically, the author concluded the story with that because it vividly shows that she's powerful, that she has the inner strength and determination to try and make herself stronger. It demonstrates that she's willing to face her fears and try again, and that she has the self - awareness to want to help herself grow and adapt. Text examples to prove this would be, “then I will take the hibiscus test again,” which clearly shows her resolve. “Almost Reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become...” This shows her growing acceptance and adaptation. And “There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply.” This line indicates her ability to appreciate the beauty in the new and unfamiliar. All those statements help backup why the author might leave such a powerful paragraph for last, as it sums up Saeng's character development and her hopeful outlook for the future.

The author, in the story "Winter Hibiscus", concludes the story with the paragraph to vividly show how often Saeng gets tested by her memories. Saeng was "tested" earlier in the story when she stepped into a florist. As soon as she entered, memories came rushing back to her like a flood. She tried hard to feel the same as she did long ago when her grandmother was by her side. However, she soon realized that the things in her memories were long gone, and overwhelmed by the sadness, she wept. Saeng reported to her mother that she had failed the test and then bought the plant to try and comfort herself. Her mother, being very understanding, simply accepted it. Saeng planted the hibiscus and at the end says that "In the spring when the snow melts, this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". Saeng is well - aware that seeing the flower again will make her cry and bring her memories back, and she will be retested, yet she still bravely awaits that moment.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, a girl named Saeng failed her driver's test that day. Frustrated but determined, she vowed that she would retake it from the spring. She ends with this statement to clearly say that it is a new season and a brand - new beginning for her as she steps into her new life. This archetype of the changing from the harsh cold winter to the nice warm spring time symbolically shows that the troubles between her mother and Saeng would gradually get better. Just as the hard and troublesome winter gives way to a calm and warm new beginning in spring, Saeng firmly believes in this transformation. She knows this and is confident that she is going to pass the test when the time comes.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for various well - thought - out reasons. For example, throughout the whole passage, it is evident that the hibiscus flower provides Saeng with the remarkable ability to overcome obstacles and offers her comfort in a time of disappointment. This ending paragraph shows that “in the spring, when the hibiscus is budding,” and the world around her is once again beautiful, then Saeng will take her test again. She is certain that with the help of the hibiscus plant, she will pass the test. It clearly shows that her hope and trust to pass the test stem from the hibiscus flower. The plant with “waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers” will surely provide her the strength, determination, courage, and will - power to pass the test in the spring, giving her the edge she needs to succeed.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends with the statement, “...then I'll take the test again.” This clearly shows that Saeng is willing to make an earnest attempt to adapt to this new place she lives in. What she refers to when she says “test” is her struggle to fit into the new environment. For example, in the story she said, “I - I failed the test,” when her mother asked her what was wrong. She spent a significant amount of money on that plant, hoping to find a sense of home in her mind. But the reality was too much for her to handle at that time. She ends with the positive statement because it effectively sends the message that she looks forward to a bright future in her new home, ready to face whatever challenges come her way.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with that paragraph for many valid reasons. She skillfully puts in examples from the story that can help us find these reasons. One reason is that we can clearly know she won't give up. In the story, she says “Then I will take the test again.” This simple yet powerful statement tells us that she will keep trying and is highly determined to achieve her goal. Another reason is that she's trying to tell us that there is a promising future for the hibiscus. When she says “...and this hibiscus is budding,” it implies that the hibiscus has a chance to change and get used to its surroundings, just like the girl in the story will be doing. The last reason is that it tells us that she is and will be doing her best. When she says “she realized that many of the things that she had thought were strange…, almost familiar to her now,” she is in the process of trying to get used to her surroundings and now realizes that she can. In the story, there are indeed many reasons to suspect why she ended the story with that paragraph. She gives examples in the story that make many readers draw various insights.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with a firm determination. After the long, harsh winter finally ends and the hibiscus flower begins budding, she decides to pass the test. This shows a clear connection between the plant and the narrator, highlighting the hardships they both endure. The winter acts as a significant obstacle for the flower, yet it will persevere to thrive come spring. This gives the author the confidence that she too can overcome her hardships and flourish. Another shared hardship that she and the hibiscus both face is being "root bound." The author deeply misses her home of Vietnam. However, both of them must and will adapt to their new environments, finding a way to grow and be at peace in unfamiliar surroundings.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as it clearly shows that her longing for her home had a negative impact on her driving test. In her home country, the climate was warm, and she had cherished all her family memories in that comforting environment. In contrast, the new country she now resides in is cold and snowy, a climate she isn't accustomed to. The text states that she will take the test again when all those favorable conditions occur because it will then feel like her home country. This familiarity will allow her to be more focused on the test rather than being distracted by what she misses, increasing her chances of success.

The author Minfong Ho concluded the story “Winter Hibiscus” with that specific paragraph to vividly show that Saeng is a tenacious person who would not give up easily. She is determined to pass the driving test and, in a sense, gradually get used to her new home. It serves as a powerful motivation, as Saeng says, “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The hibiscus flower acts as a source of motivation, bringing back memories of good - hearted people that made her happy and instilled self - belief in her. Minfong also concluded the story this way to convey that by next year, Saeng will start afresh. She will learn to become happy with her new life and not let her past hold her back. When Saeng says, “.. in the spring...”, it symbolizes the beginning of a new year, a time to start over and rejoice. This was truly a great way to end the story as it sets a positive and inspiring vibe. It makes the readers understand that Saeng is a strong - willed individual who can remember the past but bravely move on to a new day and life. And I think the author is trying to emphasize that everyone should possess the strength to do the same.

She ended it with that paragraph because she wanted to firmly prove that even though she deeply misses the “old century,” she has the resilience to adapt and survive. The longing for the past is strong, but she realizes that life in the new place must go on. She understands that adapting is not an easy process, yet she is determined to face the challenges that come with it. By stating her resolve in the paragraph, she shows that she will find a way to make a new life for herself, leaving behind the sadness of the old while still cherishing the memories. In this way, she can build a future that is full of hope and possibility in the new environment.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it exudes a strong sense of hopefulness. Initially, she was having a hard time adapting to her new home, which made her feel utterly hopeless. Saeng's failure in the driving test only added to her woes, making the situation seem even bleaker. To lift her spirits, she bought a hibiscus plant that instantly reminded her of her old home. She found great comfort in the plant, and it helped her get through the tough times. In the last paragraph, Saeng is eagerly looking forward to the arrival of spring. She plans to retake the test, hoping to pass it this time. This outlook provides a palpable feeling of hopefulness, which is precisely why the author concluded the story in this manner, leaving the readers with a positive and optimistic impression.

The author concludes the story with this well - crafted paragraph to clearly show that Saeng, a resilient character, will not give up easily and that there is still a glimmer of hope on the horizon. It is also a gentle yet powerful lesson for the reader to hold onto hope and exercise patience, understanding that good things take time to come to fruition. Saeng initially failed the test of not succumbing to the sorrows and misery of missing her homeland. She reflects, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This internal thought shows that she is gradually adjusting to her new environment. So, by ending the story with this and drawing a comparison to the geese, it vividly portrays that she is growing stronger with each passing day. She will undoubtedly take the test again because giving up is not in her nature, and she is determined to succeed.

Clearly, from reading the story “Winter @CAPS1”, the author strategically includes this poignant phrase “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” in the story. This is because the passage has a deep - seated connection to the title of the story “Winter @CAPS1”. The mention of spring, snow melting, geese returning, and the hibiscus budding after the winter alludes to the cycle of seasons and renewal, which ties in with the overall theme and mood of the story. It shows that despite the challenges faced in the “winter” of her life, Saeng is looking forward to a new beginning, much like the arrival of spring after winter.

The reason the author concludes the story with that paragraph is quite evident. Even though Saeng didn't perform well on her last test, she has a burning determination within her. Saeng is resolute to go back and take the test again so that she can finally achieve a passing grade. The author skillfully showcases Saeng's unwavering determination to not only pass the test but also to do significantly better the next time around. This conclusion serves as an inspiration, highlighting that setbacks are only temporary and with perseverance, one can overcome them.

I think the author ends the story with that paragraph because it is cleverly linking the plant, which stands for many positive attributes, to the character who failed the test that she really wanted to pass. Both the character and the plant are shining examples of perseverance. The plant endures the harsh winter, showing remarkable resilience as it battles through the cold and snow. Similarly, the main character is not giving up on the test she desires to pass. The author is trying to send a powerful message to the reader: never abandon your goals and dreams. No matter how difficult the journey may seem, one should keep pushing forward. The plant acts as an emblem of hope and perseverance, and by associating it with the character, the author drives home the point that with determination, one can overcome any obstacle.

At the end of the story, the author says “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that again.” The author concludes the story with this because the character felt that she didn't give her best effort in the test and thus failed. The imagery of spring, with melting snows, returning geese, and a budding hibiscus, represents a new beginning and a fresh start. When the spring comes again, she is going to retry with renewed vigor and determination. Hopefully, this time around, she will be able to pass the test, as the new season symbolizes a chance for her to overcome her previous failure and achieve success.
The author concludes the story with this paragraph. Because she deeply desires to come back and conduct a smell test once again when the snow melts away and the geese gracefully return.

The @ORGANIZATION1 is about a girl named Saeng. She is a young teenager, and her family has just moved to the United States from Vietnam. Saeng unfortunately failed her driving test. On the walk home, she discovers this incredibly beautiful plant named Hibiscus and immediately falls in love with it. Saeng's mother has a lovely garden where she is always busy planting things and uses the plants and veggies from her garden for dinner. The author concludes a paragraph that says when the Hibiscus plants are budding in the spring, Saeng will take the test again. I think Saeng says this because she eagerly wants to see the beautiful plants when she passes the test, and she believes that seeing the Hibiscus will help her pass the driving test.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because she is giving herself a glimmer of hope on passing her test. The hibiscus will have started sprouting, and it will give her the inner strength to take the test again and hopefully pass it, all because the winter hibiscus vividly reminded her of home.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph of "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because this paragraph can clearly show that the hibiscus is the main reason why Saeng wants to try the test again. If the hibiscus is budding after the snow melts and the geese return, then she can, just like the hibiscus, be strong and won't give up on her test.

The author concludes the story with this to show that Saeng won't give up. It is indeed possible to adapt and try to love what's around you. Saeng struggled to get out "I - I failed the test" and couldn't say "at home", which clearly shows her insecurity and loneliness in the new world around her. By saying she will try again in the spring, it gives the reader hope that she will adapt and love her surroundings. She goes through an experience today, comparing her old life to the one she is living in now, and they have some similarities. Because she will try again in the spring, it means she has decided to give this new place a real chance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she says “Then I Will take that test again”. She firmly believes in the Flowers. Both she and the Flowers adapt to their circumstances. They are both determined to thrive in challenging places. They both manage to overcome various obstacles. Maybe she wants to see what lies ahead on her journey. She hopes she is right about the Flowers. Perhaps, she has a deep - seated fondness for the renewal and beauty that spring brings.

I actually like the way the author concludes the story with this paragraph. It effectively and concisely summarizes the story, distilling its essence into just a few words. These words are so thought - provoking that they make you wonder what happened next and if there is a sequel to this engaging tale. This is a very good story that I personally can relate to in many aspects of my own life.

The reason why the author concludes this type of scenario is simply because the author has a pain to endure and cross over, or is in a particular situation. In this case, you might initially be confused, but if you look at it clearly, you'll open your eyes and see that it's your time to shine. You might as well seize this opportunity before you lose your chance. You only get one day to prove you are worthy to the people around you, so make it count.

The author concludes with this sentence because he is vividly showing the girl's confidence in herself. It also allows her sufficient time to thoroughly prepare for the next test. Moreover, she is certain that she will be fully ready when her flower begins to bud, which symbolizes her own growth and readiness for the challenges ahead.

Why did the author conclude the story with this paragraph? It is so he can write another story. He has vowed silently and will write the story in the spring when the natural world comes back to life, bringing with it new inspiration and possibilities for his next narrative.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she was firmly stating that if it is indeed possible for these seemingly unlikely things to happen, then surely she should possess the ability to take the test and ultimately pass it. She was consciously comparing elements together that she clearly knew do not typically go together. For instance, she specifically said that in the springtime, when the snow gradually melts and the geese gracefully return and this particular hibiscus starts budding, then she would resolutely take the test over. What she truly meant was that if the thing she likes the most manages to overcome its significant obstacle, then she would have the courage to do what hurt her the most over again. She is uncertain that if she takes the test over, she might keep trying repeatedly over and over until she finally passes it. In the story, she struggles to know how to fit in. All she is familiar with is what she learned in her home country. All she has to do is exert a bit more effort and she maybe will be able to successfully pass this test.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because when she tearfully told her mom that she had failed her test, the emotions were far more profound than just the disappointment of the failure. I strongly believe that she missed her home so intensely that it severely affected her ability to concentrate. She felt the need to cry about something because she didn't want to let her mom become aware that she deeply misses home, as she might not want to worry her mother.

When they come back, Saeng silently and determinedly vowed to herself that in the spring, when the snows slowly melt away and the geese steadily return in their characteristic formation and this specific hibiscus begins to show delicate buds, then she will bravely take that test again. The author concludes the story as if oblivious to the biting cold, her mother was still patiently out in the vegetable garden, carefully digging up the last of the onions with a well - worn, rusty trowel, perhaps symbolizing the perseverance and routine in the face of changing circumstances.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is vividly showing that the hibiscus deeply inspires her and offers a sense of comfort that no person could ever attempt to replicate. For example, after Saeng disappointedly failed her driver's test, she was extremely dejected. On her way back home, she unexpectedly saw a hibiscus and immediately went to a nearby florist shop to try and purchase it. Saeng gently took a single petal from the plant and tightly held it in her hand while she softly closed her eyes. The plant vividly reminded her of her real, beloved home in Vietnam. The hibiscus became a precious form of comfort for Saeng right after she had just failed her driver's test, even though the plant was not exactly the same as the ones at home. By the author ending the story with Saeng saying she will patiently wait until the hibiscus starts budding to take the test again, it clearly shows that the hibiscus helps her to bravely overcome obstacles in life and it effectively helps her to endure the hardships she faces.

What Saeng means at the end of the paragraph is that when it is the appropriate season for those specific plants, she will confidently take the test again. The test is designed to assess her understanding to begin to appreciate aspects like the plot. It involves getting to know the unique features and endearing characters about these plants. Also, it includes learning about the rich history related to these plants. By taking the test at the right time, she hopes to gain a deeper connection and knowledge about them.

She is firmly demanding to not take the test again if the winter hibiscus don't come back. She was extremely upset that she had failed the test. She spent most of her day intently looking at the hibiscus, but she was still disheartened that they weren't the real ones back at home. Her mother gently said they are strong enough to make it through the winter. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows gradually melt and the geese gracefully return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it symbolizes the hope that things will gradually get better. The author ends with hope because the flower vividly symbolizes the girl, and the girl saying that if the flower can survive the year, so can she. This symbolizes hope because the girl is slowly realizing that it is going to take some time before she can fully adapt to her new country, but eventually she will. This is meaningful because the girl considers the day that she had to be truly horrible, and that this statement ends the day on a genuinely good note. The girl spends the entire day longingly wishing that she were back in her own country and deeply missing her grandmother and friends. But this paragraph is the girl firmly vowing a promise to herself that she will bravely withstand the winter until spring, and it will get better when she can take the test again. The entire story builds up to this significant turning point when Saeng realizes that she will make it through this struggle just like this flower will make it through the winter. Saeng realizes that it is going to take time for her to adapt to this new and rather strange country and the new lifestyle that she must adopt.

The author concludes this story with this sentence because it clearly shows hope for the future. This sentence effectively lets readers know that times are tough now, but in due time things will surely get better. Saeng might have unfortunately failed this test, but she's not giving up hope on passing it. She firmly believes she will pass that test in the spring, when the time is just right. Saeng might deeply miss her home, but she won't let that interfere with her future. That is why the author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows gradually melt and the geese gracefully return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.”

What the author is talking about is that the snow was slowly melting and the spring is gently coming. I guess what they mean is that flowers, trees, and grass are going back to being beautifully vibrant. Also, he was clearly letting us know that spring is here and that it is no longer winter. That's why she starts to carefully plant plants in the winter so that in the spring they can grow out to be nice and stunningly beautiful for the spring. That's what I think the author meant. Also, that's the reason why he put that in the paragraph. He should have added more details like how the plants and such were growing so magnificently beautiful. He should add more details to clearly let us know what he was talking about in this paragraph.

The author chose to end the story in this way because it effectively and seamlessly ties in different aspects and principles of the story. The author concludes the story with the paragraph they because it clearly shows Saeng's strong determination and her remarkable ability to overcome the obstacles of being new in a country. With the support Saeng has, she will definitely pass the test the next time, showing her growth and strength in the new environment.

In the story “winter Hibiscus,” the author Minfong Ho ends with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She ends with this to vividly show her determination to do well in her new country and to illustrate that the memories of her grandmother help her to strive for the best in her new home. In the beginning of the story, Saeng is at a flower shop and sees all the familiar flowers of her home country growing in pots. At the sight of these flowers, a flood of memories comes back to her, memories that bring a mix of joy and sadness. Then when she returns home, she tells her mother that she failed the test. You can clearly tell from her actions that she is deeply disappointed. “I - I failed the test. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.” After a while, she carefully planted the flower in the vegetable garden. The act of buying and planting the flower shows that Saeng wants to hold onto the memories of her grandmother and home. Thinking about her grandmother helps her to persevere and makes her want to succeed in her new home. Memories of her grandmother make her sad but also, in a way, bring her a sense of comfort and happiness, which fuels her determination to do better.

The author concludes the story this way with a quote that says she will get another try at something. Many authors end stories in a different way because it creates a sense of anticipation that makes the reader eager to go on to a sequel or the next story, and it really adds an interesting twist to the ending. Another reason an author would end like that is because they want the reader to engage their imagination and picture what happens next. Using this technique is effective because the reader already knows what has happened in the story so far, and it makes the reader wonder whether she fails or succeeds the next time around. This kind of ending leaves a lasting impression on the reader, making the story more memorable and thought - provoking.

The author closes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is willing to try again. You know how much we… what happened?” Saeng clearly feels that she has disappointed her mother. But then, Mrs. Panouvong expresses that she is glad Saeng got it, after hearing that she had failed. Sensing her mother's slight inkling of disappointment, Saeng is even more motivated to try again. This shows her emotional growth and her strong desire to make her mother proud in the new environment.

Most likely the author concludes this story with that paragraph because the author wanted to clearly show that Saeng was a very determined person. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it allows you to gain a clear view of what she is saying. Moreover, it enables you to understand it from the situation she was in while growing up. For example, she mentioned certain things that provided context to her perspective.

The author concludes the story with the sentence "when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because he is making a poignant point about immigration.
