In the story “Winter @CAPS1”, the author was trying to convey that Saeng was from somewhere other than where she is now. The author concludes this story with that paragraph because it shows clear signs of hope, knowing that spring will come again. For the family, this means that everything will be okay. In “Winter Hibiscus”, Saeng took her driver’s test and unfortunately failed it. She wants to try and take it again in the spring. Also, the geese will be back, which makes her feel more at home. That way, she will feel comforted and be able to take the test and pass, as it will strongly remind her of being home and give her the confidence she needs.

In the end of the story, they clearly state that she will take the test over again. Specifically, it will be in the spring when the geese return from their winter flight. What they imply is that she will make a truly fresh start in the spring when the geese come back. So, she'll be starting all over again, a brand - new start to a new year. Her mom was in total disbelief when she found out that her daughter failed the test. But her mom gently said to her that it will be okay and she can take it over again in this new, promising season. With this new chance, she has the opportunity to prove herself and succeed.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as she is deeply thinking about what it will be like when all of this unfolds. The author of the story concludes the text with that paragraph to end on a truly good note and vividly show hope for the future. Whether it be your school, tests or home, with a bit of hard work and faith, you can achieve your goals and find success.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to clearly show that she will do this once she has fully gotten used to the change of her new country. My detail about Saeng is that she vowed silently to herself because she had great difficulty making new friends. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” decided to end the story with this paragraph because it's like a new beginning for Saeng. In the story, Saeng moves to a new place and unfortunately fails the test. The winter hibiscus, a precious reminder, comforts her from the memories of where she used to live. It gives her a glimmer of hope, even though in the winter it may not be as vibrant as it would be in the spring. Authors sometimes conclude a story with a certain paragraph describing an action that will take place in the future. In the story “Winter Hibiscus”, the author concludes the paragraph by saying “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” One reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to help show that significant things will change come spring. For example, in the story the girl said “I - I failed the test.” By her saying this and talking about how she failed her driving test, come spring she has the opportunity to change. She can work hard, practice more, and get better, so that this time she will pass. Also, “The 'winter hibiscus' was in the ground now, and she tamped down the soil around it.” This quote helps show that the hibiscus is being planted now, but come spring it will have transformed, changing color and blooming beautifully. In conclusion, authors end stories with a paragraph like this to clearly help show the positive changes that could happen in the future.

The author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. The “budding hibiscus” symbolizes comfort for her. The reason why the author wanted to put that last paragraph down is because they want to keep the reader deeply interested in the story. The author concludes the story with the quote, “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show that she is strongly encouraged by the memories of her homeland. The author concludes the story with the main character vowing to take the drivers test again to symbolize moving forward. “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.” As she was stumbling to a florist shop, the main character saw a flower that reminded her vividly of her homeland, Vietnam. “Here, let me help, mother.” In relieving her mother of the task of planting the seed that she had bought, she began to mature gradually. I think the author concludes the story with that statement simply because, maybe he is trying to send out some sort of profound message to people and capture their full attention. The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with the paragraph "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take the test again" because it is sympathizing with Saeng's remarkable ability to overcome her sorrow and give the test another earnest chance. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it clearly shows that the narrator wants to retake the test and is patiently waiting for a better, more opportune time. The author concluded the last paragraph in the story "Winter Hibiscus" to specifically say that the narrator "Saeng" hasn't given up on her driving test, showing her persistent spirit in the face of challenges.

At the end of the story, "Winter Hibiscus", the author's concluding paragraph neatly shows many of the key aspects of the story in a well - crafted summary. The author Minfong Ho concludes the story with this paragraph to effectively evoke hope within the reader towards the characters in the story. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it sounds much better and it makes the story flow a bit more smoothly when the author places that paragraph at the end. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he is trying to explain to us that this plant is going to bring good luck. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize the theme that changes in life are hard to adjust to. Saeng has moved to @LOCATION1 and deeply longs for her home. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because the author is showing how she feels more comfortable with her old home. The winter hibiscus is specifically related to her new home. I believe that the author concluded the story “Winter @CAPS1” with the paragraph that she did in order to clearly imply that Saeng will not give up easily. In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by @CAPS1 Ho, the author concludes the story with, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph because in the story, the author says “through the quiet repetition of season upon season,” which implies that seasons will come and seasons will go. The author is probably trying to say that in the spring, when the seasons change, the snow melts, the geese return from their long migration, and the hibiscus starts budding, he will take the test again. The author concludes that failing the test is not the worst thing. She realizes that as time progresses, circumstances change, and you can always get another opportunity. The author concludes the story with her saying that in the spring, a season of renewal when the snows gradually melt, the geese gracefully return, and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take that test again. The author concludes the story with this paragraph @CAPS1. It conveys so many aspects about her in just one concise sentence. The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. Saeng was deeply disappointed for failing her driving test. The author concludes the story with this well - chosen paragraph or quote to leave the readers with something substantial to ponder upon at the end of their reading experience. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I firmly think the author concludes the story with this particular paragraph because it vividly shows Saeng's unwavering determination. Saeng is facing significant problems with both adjusting and adapting to the numerous changes in her new life. A clear example of this can be seen when Saeng comes home with her flower. As the text states, “she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again.” We can clearly understand that Saeng bought the flower because it gave her a deep sense of security. It was a precious thing from her home that felt extremely familiar to her. I strongly believe that's why the author included this story with this paragraph, as next year she will have a comforting sense of security and familiarity when taking the test because the experience she had will be repeated. This repetition of experience can potentially give her the confidence she needs.

The author concludes with this well - crafted paragraph to clearly show that Saeng is not going to give up easily. She also concludes with this paragraph to strongly tell people that they should never give up in the face of difficulties and that they should keep on trying with perseverance. Even if they have to take a short break to study more effectively or carefully rethink the plan, they should not lose hope. This message is an important lesson that the author wants to convey through the story.

When they came back, Saeng silently vowed to herself that in the beautiful spring, when the thick snow melts away and the geese gracefully return, and this lovely hibiscus is starting to bud, then she will bravely take that test again. In the story, the author put this significant paragraph in the story to clearly show what the determined girl was planning to do to improve on her grades. This shows her long - term goal and her hope for a better outcome.

He ends the paragraph with this specific statement because he is clearly meaning to say that he would much rather take the test again when the outside world is beautiful and inviting. The pleasant environment might bring a positive mindset and better performance. In conclusion, this is the clear reason why I think the author ends it with this sentence, as it ties together the character's preference and the overall mood of the story.

At the end of the short story, “Winter Hibiscus,” the writer Minfong Ho includes a somewhat inspirational concluding sentence: “When they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think this sentence was added in order to create a strong sense of hope for the future. This hope stands in stark contrast to the deeply depressing nature of the story, thus crafting a somewhat happy ending. Throughout the essay, Saeng is extremely depressed as she had to leave her homeland so abruptly, losing her cherished childhood and beloved grandmother. “A blink, a changed switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone,” as Saeng narrates in more poignant detail. Also contributing significantly to the feelings of sorrow in the story is how often Saeng cries while remembering her tragic past. Whether in the greenhouse, recalling tender events with her grandmother such as when she says, “Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s grey hair. Saeng would help knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it,” or in the garden when she talks to her mother and plants the flower. After all this sorrow, by inserting a hopeful ending, the writer has successfully instilled a sense of hope for the future, leaving the reader with a glimmer of optimism.

She says that come the spring, she will take the test again because she knows that if she fails the test again, her mother will be deeply disappointed in her. Her mother might think that she isn't trying hard enough, or perhaps they will never be as close again. The mother believes that just because she keeps failing the test, it's due to her connection to her past experiences, her affection for her new country, and her ability to overcome obstacles. Finally, I think she finds comfort in the memories of her homeland, which give her the strength to face the test once more and strive for a better outcome.

The author concludes the story with that quote for one main and significant reason. That reason is that it clearly shows that the girl has a glimmer of hope. In a story, one of the most appealing qualities a character can possess is hope. This is because hope makes the reader genuinely interested in the character's journey and helps provide a positive and uplifting morale for the story. By ending with such a quote, the author not only engages the reader but also leaves them with a sense of optimism. That is precisely why the author concludes the story with that quote, to leave a lasting and positive impression on the readers.

The author of this story created the last paragraph so that it finishes the story with a truly great and inspiring ending. The underlying message is the powerful concept of never giving up and trying again and again. The author said, “I will take the test again.” In the story, Saeng said, “I failed the test,” but now she has shown remarkable determination by not giving up. This last paragraph makes a great deal of sense and is absolutely needed to make this story complete. Just as others in @LOCATION1 persevere and don't give up, Saeng is doing the same. She is bravely retaking the test, embodying the spirit of resilience and determination, which adds a powerful and relatable element to the story.

The author concludes the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” because he wants to vividly express to the readers that she is whole - heartedly determined for what she has to do to achieve what she previously failed. Since she failed the test the first time, she is eager to overcome her failure and succeed in it. The author wants her to appear resolute and unwavering in the end, leaving the readers with the impression that with determination, one can conquer their setbacks and move forward towards their goals.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it effectively extends the story's length and imparts a satisfying ending. However, I'm completely at a loss as to what that paragraph actually means. Thus, it's the author's responsibility to explain its meaning, not mine.

The plant was extremely important to Saeng because it originated from her homeland. Saeng firmly stated that she would take her driver's test again when her plant bloomed. The plant served as a vivid reminder of her homeland and her roots. For Saeng, the plant was a source of confidence. Saeng endured difficult times, and the plant was very close to her heart because it came from her homeland, offering her a sense of connection and comfort.

I believe the author ended the story with that paragraph specifically to create a strong sense of wonder. I think this because when you carefully put the word “test” into context, it could have multiple interpretations. For example, it could mean the test to overcome the deep - seated sadness of her difficult situation. Also, it could signify the test to smoothly adjust to her new home when the spring arrives. That is precisely why I think the author attempted to create a sense of wonder with the final paragraph.

The story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho is fundamentally about overcoming adversity. She concludes the story by writing “when they come back [the geese] then I will take that test” (NUM1). The main character, Saeng, had been facing numerous difficulties at school. On her way home, she unexpectedly saw an array of flowers that were native to her homeland. “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense it was almost” (NUM2). The sight of those flowers, especially the hibiscus, vividly reminded her of what she had lost and offered much - needed comfort in the face of those memories. The winter hibiscus could still thrive even though it was not in the land where it naturally belonged. Her mother states “It’s flowers aren’t as pretty but it’s strong enough. That’s what” (NUM3). After hearing this, Saeng resolutely decides that she could be strong, too, and would make a sincere effort to do her best in school. She would adapt just like the resilient winter hibiscus.

She said that because she was far more interested in the beauty and intricacies of flowers than in the pressure and stress of a test. This preference clearly influenced her statement, highlighting her passion for the natural world over academic evaluations.

I believe that the author concludes with this paragraph because it clearly shows the ending of one chapter and the beginning of a new one. After she experiences a wave of upset and spends time thinking about home, she gradually realizes that something new is on the horizon, and she needs to gracefully accept it. So, just as the flowers blossom vibrantly in the spring, she is going to embark on a fresh start.

The author ends the story with this particular paragraph because he aims to convey the key point that the character is cautious and doesn't want to rush headlong into things. She firmly believes in doing things the right way and is determined not to take the easy or quick way out. This approach emphasizes her values and the importance of making well - thought - out decisions.

It vividly shows the great importance of the Hibiscus to Saeng and her unwavering dedication to this beautiful flower. It is also explicitly stating that she is patiently going to wait for next spring to once again admire the delicate beauty of the flower, cherishing the moment and the connection she has with it.

The author ends this story with this paragraph because she is carefully explaining her innermost thoughts and the reasons behind her decision to take that test. She is looking forward and explaining that next year she will finally find out if this place truly feels like home to her, a sense of belonging that she has been seeking.

When the author concluded the narrative by stating “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again”, it powerfully demonstrates the ability to overcome obstacles, finding comfort in a time of disappointment, and her deep connection to her past experiences. First, it demonstrates the ability to overcome obstacles because obstacles are an inevitable part of everyone's lives, and one has no choice but to conquer them as they seem unlimited. So, the hibiscus flower symbolically represents the obstacles, and the weather represents time because the harsh weather conditions are temporarily stopping the flower from blooming and blossoming. Secondly, it also represents the finding of comfort in a time of disappointment because when one is going through an obstacle, disappointment often lingers nearby. However, she knows that the hibiscus will be coming back, and she has the awareness that the obstacles will also return. Finally, it asserts her connection to her past experience because she is trapped in a world that she is not familiar with, which makes her feel like an outsider. She captures the sense of being out of place, as one can relate that the hibiscus flower would be like her because she is unique and different from the rest of the people in her environment. She is trying to adapt her way of living and survive in this new world, much like when she was in her own country. This shows her resilience and the hope she holds for a better future.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because this paragraph represents Saeng's determination and the situation she is in now. She has just come to the new country and has not yet adjusted herself to this unfamiliar environment. She was disappointed, described as “a shaft of the war afternoon starlight.” The word “war” showed that Saeng was extremely upset. After she met the flower, she thought of her old country, her beloved homeland that she missed deeply. She felt that life was full of hope again. She knew she should adjust herself to the new situation, yet she was still too shaky to express her feelings at home. Finally, she burst into tears again as she missed her homeland very much. “Snows” symbolized the difficult situation she was facing now. But she believed she could overcome it and that life was full of hope. “Spring” symbolized the hope for the new life. Saeng thought things would get better in the spring and she would succeed. She had the determination to succeed, so the author uses that paragraph at the conclusion as it symbolizes hope.

The author included this because she felt that since Saeng failed the test, perhaps she should be given a second chance as she had tried so hard before. When Saeng says “Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it,” it made her mom upset because she had spent a large amount of money on one plant just to feel at home again, as she had one when she was in her old home. Eventually, her mom said, “It’s a beautiful plant” to make her feel better as she felt bad about how she had acted towards her daughter. After all the difficulties Saeng had to go through, this is the reason the author added the last passage into the story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, indicating that Saeng will not quit until she passes that test. She will try and try, persevering until the end. The author is referring back to the story's core theme of Saeng's tenacity. By using this paragraph as the conclusion, it emphasizes Saeng's unwavering determination to achieve success in the test.

The author's purpose of this conclusion is that every year when the snow melts and the geese return, she will have to once again take care of the plant. This is clear because taking a test is a significant responsibility, and similarly, taking care of that plant is also a huge task, which is being compared to taking the test again. The conclusion implies that just as the cycle of the seasons brings new responsibilities for the plant, Saeng will face the test repeatedly. This is what the purpose of the concluding sentence meant.

Because planting flowers and spending time in the garden is @CAPS1's hobby. And without this hobby, she cannot think clearly or be creative. Therefore, waiting until they are back will make her happier, and she will also be able to focus on her work. The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several well - thought - out reasons. One is that she implies when everything gets back to the normal state of affairs, that's precisely when she is going to take the test once again. Second, if the situation is not back to the way she desired it to be, there would be nothing more meaningful to say. For instance, if you were in the process of building a house and a blizzard suddenly arrived, you would immediately stop. You'd firmly state that you would not continue construction until there was nice, favorable weather again. In conclusion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph for many valid reasons.

The author of Winter Hibiscus, Minfong Ho, ended the story in this way to clearly show the theme of starting over. Her mother adds to this powerful theme of starting over by saying, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty but it’s strong enough to make it through the winter. That’s what matters.” Her words serve as a perfect metaphor for the family starting their lives anew in @LOCATION1. It suggests that @LOCATION1 might not be as visually appealing as their previous home, but it has the resilience to survive, which is of utmost importance. Her words effectively soothe her daughter's worries about starting afresh. Also, the budding hibiscus can be aptly considered a symbol of rebirth, since it experiences the cycle of dying and growing with the changing seasons. The family is transitioning from a @CAPS1 family to being a @CAPS2 which was an @CAPS3 family. However, even though they “died” as a @CAPS1 family, that does not mean that they have lost their precious heritage. This is why the author ends the story talking about a flower that is both @CAPS1 and @CAPS3, just like Saeng, tying together the themes of heritage and new beginnings.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly show that Saeng will persevere through the harsh winter and make a sincere attempt to adapt to her new lifestyle. Moving to a new country and embracing a different culture is an extremely arduous task, and Saeng is having a tough time, but she doesn't give up on creating a new life in @LOCATION1. The concluding sentence, “in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test,” is filled with determination and hope. Throughout the entire story, Saeng was struggling with adapting, and her memories of her homeland give her a sense of much - needed security. The sentence effectively wraps up her complex emotions and shows how strong she is. Many @CAPS1 people could easily give up on their driving test, but she won't. It is a happy ending for what is somewhat of a sad story. Moreover, the sentence further shows Saeng's connection to her plant. This hibiscus will survive, and so will Saeng. When the hibiscus blooms in the spring, so will Saeng. She will try as hard as she can to fit in and enjoy her new life. That plant will help her through it by reminding her of Vietnam as well as giving her a companion throughout the long winter. The author could not have chosen a better conclusion for this story. The conclusion offers a new hope to persevere and succeed. As a result, the reader is left with a sense of pleasure and a positive feeling towards the story. This conclusion shows how Saeng is adapting to changes with hope and is looking forward to enjoying her new life in @LOCATION1.

The story was about a girl walking home after failing her driving test and completely breaking down about her “home” where she no longer lived. After she had an emotional breakdown, bought the plant, and finally learned to truly accept the fact that she no longer lived in Vietnam and that she had failed her driving test, she came to the realization that she just has to learn to like her new situation. She also understood that her time will come and she will one day be driving with confidence. The reason why the author concluded the story with this paragraph is because this is the natural conclusion of the story. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with a statement where Saeng silently vows to herself. The author used that well - crafted paragraph in order to create vivid imagery. The author concludes the story with the paragraph to specifically tell you the time when Saeng was going to take the test again. Also, it is to show her intention to reunite with the plant again. The author ends the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to clearly show a comparison. When she was tenderly looking at the petals of the flower, it said, “Gently she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least she could hold on to.” This powerfully shows that she really deeply missed her home, and she had almost nothing to give her the needed confidence. The flower is the precious piece of confidence she needs to feel at home and even successfully pass her driver's test. Saeng felt completely out of place in her new environment. The flower hibiscus, gave her strong motivation. It gave her a great chance to connect with a part from her old home, in her new home. Saeng thinks, “And that rich sweet scent - that was familiar too”. This clearly shows that this flower was of sentimental importance, which she truly needed. In “Winter Hibiscus,” Minfong Ho ends the story the way she does to clearly show a sign of hope. Saeng is going to start over when the world starts over anew. Spring is the beautiful time when animals come out of their winter holes, when trees blossom with colorful flowers, and when the snow gradually melts. It is a time of renewal. To show how extremely absent she feels without them by her side, you can clearly see this when the @ORGANIZATION1 says “when they come back”. I think *Winter Hibiscus* by Minfong Ho was a good enough read. Throughout the story, you feel somewhat happy and somewhat sad, but always calm. You feel happy when they are talking about all the beautiful plants and when her mother graciously accepts the plants she bought. At first, when you think the mom is going to yell at her for buying the plants after she failed her test, you feel bad for her. Yet, there's still a calm mood, showing that the girl doesn't want to give up but just needs to take her time. This gentle mix of emotions makes the story quite engaging and relatable.

I believe the author concludes the story with the paragraph saying that she's going to take the test again, to clearly show us that this time she's going to pass the test and she won't feel the same way she felt when she didn't pass. It tells us in “spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding” because that's precisely when she is going to take the test. Saeng vowed silently to herself and to her mother too. Saeng decided to bravely tell her mother what she had done, “she failed the test”. Probably her mom would get upset with her, but then she'd talk to her again. Saeng's mother asked her about the plant that she had with her. Saeng said that she bought the plant with some money. She was sad because she failed the test, and when she bought the plant, it probably made her feel a bit better. I think the author probably concludes the story with this paragraph because it brings some kind of hope to her, and she probably will pass the test. When she said “then I will take that test again”, it might be the plant that makes her decide to take it again. This shows the plant's symbolic importance in her journey.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wants to clearly show the readers that Saeng will be determined to pass her driver license test. The first example shows that she was sad that she failed the test. At the conclusion, the author put this statement in the story to show readers that Saeng will pass the driver license test later on, highlighting her resilience.

In the story *Winter Hibiscus* by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with Saeng saying “when they come back in the spring. When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author chose to end the story this way to give it a positive and hopeful ending. The rest of the story is rather sad because Saeng deeply misses her home in Vietnam. “It’s – it’s not a real one. I mean, it’s not like the kind we had at – at –” she found that she was still too shaky to say the words “at home”, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the ones we had before.” The end sends a powerful message that even though things are different than before, she won't give up trying to make a good life in the United States and won't let this change negatively affect her. This ending leaves the reader with a sense of optimism for Saeng's future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants us to know that she will regain her confidence when the "hibiscus is budding" and take another shot at the driving test. He doesn't want to simply leave us hanging with the girl watching the geese fly away into the far - off distance. The girl felt extremely bad about failing the test, which makes the reader feel sad. To cheer up the reader, he ended the story in this way. Saeng is reminded of home when "the geese return and this hibiscus is budding". So, the author ends the story having Saeng have a sense of renewed confidence and the reader feeling happy, leaving a positive and hopeful impression.

The author concludes the story with that because she is determined to succeed in @LOCATION1. She misses her homeland and everything there: the beautiful gardens filled with colorful flowers, her kind - hearted grandparents, and the familiar way of life. For example, when she walked into the flower shop, she smelled the flowers just like she used to back home. She then smelled a flower that vividly reminded her of her grandmother's “long gray hair, freshly washed …”. But by saying that last sentence, she indicated that when the hibiscus budded next winter, she will take the test that she failed again, showing her unwavering resolve.

The author concludes the story with "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again." because the girl is willing to try again and to not give up no matter what. The girl is upset because she doesn't have the real flower her mom had. The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with that paragraph because he wants to get across to the reader that Saeng will not give up. Saeng and her family moved from Vietnam, and it has been quite hard for her to adjust to the numerous changes. Saeng really misses her homeland and the flowers that she saw in her old life. I think he uses it because she wants to get another one next year to see what it's like to like something so much and get to look after it for a while. The author concludes this story with the paragraph she did because it vividly shows how Saeng is gradually adapting with the change she is going through in @LOCATION1. Once the flower finally blooms, it will clearly symbolize strength, effectively helping Saeng overcome this obstacle. Her mother said the flower was not as pretty but will survive. The purpose for the ending the Author @CAPS1 is to clearly show how the hibiscus gives Saeng a strong sense of comfort, in sharp contrast to how she was at the very beginning of the story. @PERSON1 starts the journey and steadily go to the top of the hill. Once reaching the top, they then carefully make their way over the hill, finally completing the short but eventful passage.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a couple of different and significant reasons. The author wants to show with deep meaning, that the budding of the hibiscus plant will be highly symbolic. Ho states, “Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.” This shows meaning because it is currently a crucial point in time where Saeng has to bravely overcome negative circumstances, and with the plant dead, it clearly shows symbolically the meaning of the plant. At another important point in the story, Saeng realizes that there is much more profound meaning to the seasons. Ho states, “Through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” She is realizing that come spring time when the plant will be healthy and budding, she will be able to successfully succeed and become somehow like a new and stronger person.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he or she feels like the audience should truly know what Saeng is deeply feeling. This paragraph ending clearly shows that Saeng will keep persistently trying every spring to grow back her flowers. This consistent effort shows that Saeng has a great deal of potential to make her vow to herself to be successful a reality.

This story is all about overcoming hardships and disappointments as well as accepting and adapting to the things life throws at people. Given this central theme, it is quite appropriate that the story is ended with a goal and a determined attitude. Throughout the entire reading, Saeng, in the face of various difficulties, sought comfort in the things most familiar to her, such as the delicate beauty of flowers and the unique taste of bitter melon. She was deeply hurting and disappointed, and those familiar things were the only sources that gave her a sense of peace. It was these things that saved the courage she needed to retake her driver’s test in the spring. So, it seems fitting that she end the story with the mention of the hibiscus. The end paragraph also clearly shows that Saeng is adapting well to her new country. She says, “when they come back... in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return...” At first, the sounds of geese were completely alien to her, but now she has calmly accepted their honking as a normal sound. This implies that she is gradually learning to accept her new country, which is indeed the perfect way to end the story as it reflects her growth and adaptation.

The author concludes the story this way because in the winter time, she won't be able to see the hibiscus that she is so accustomed to. She has a deep - seated habit of going outside in the garden and seeing her beautiful hibiscus plant, which brings her a lot of comfort and a sense of familiarity. In conclusion, the author concludes the story that way because in the winter time, the cold and snow will cover the garden, and she won't be able to see her beloved plant, so it becomes a significant factor in how the story is wrapped up.

In the story, Saeng is earnestly trying to be okay with her new home. The new environment is full of unfamiliar things, but she is making efforts to fit in. I think the author put that in the story to show that she has not given up. Despite the challenges, she is going to keep trying to adjust to her new home. The author concludes the story with that line to leave the reader guessing. The “she” in the story means that she is determined to live up to her past experiences and get through the difficulties she has faced. The author describes the snow melting and geese coming back as a symbol of change, which is exactly what she hopes to achieve. This open - ended conclusion makes the story more thought - provoking and allows the readers to imagine her future journey of growth and change.

The author used the conclusion “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She writes that because when her flower starts budding, it represents a new beginning and a sign of hope. She is like a flower, needing the right time and conditions to bloom and show her strength. The author uses this conclusion because when the flower is going to bud and the geese come back, these natural phenomena will bring a sense of familiarity and comfort to her. She will think that she is back home in a way, as these are the scenes and feelings she associates with her past. That's why I think the author used the conclusion “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”, as it perfectly captures her emotions and her hope for a new start.

In winter hibiscus, the young teenage girl Saeng fails her driver’s test. Disheartened, she then runs into a winter hibiscus and through this encounter, comes in touch with her memories. The author concludes the story with the idea of re - trying the test when the geese return and the hibiscus buds, a symbol that shows comfort and a sense of familiarity. When the speaker says “almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become”, this example clearly shows that she had lost touch with the realness of nature, and it is this re - connection with nature that was going to get her to pass the test. The author sets an impatient mood for the reader because it took her until winter to discover this. Winter is when it seems too late, as the geese have left and the flower has closed. But when spring comes, both the natural world and she will be open to new opportunities with the familiarity around her. This ending leaves the reader hopeful for Saeng's future test attempt.

I think she concluded with this statement because she is unsure if she will pass the driver's test, but she is determined and not giving up. I think she concluded with this paragraph because it leaves the reader with the powerful idea that one should not give up when times are hard and instead keep trying. This message is both inspiring and relatable, making the story's ending impactful.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a few well - thought - out reasons. The author concludes the story like this because when the snow is slowly melting, the plant is starting to bud, and the geese are coming back, then she will take the test again. In “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author’s purpose in concluding the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” was to show how the hibiscus and the other plants in the store symbolized Saeng. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” includes “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because it shows that she can adapt to change and still can think about her old country too. There could be many reasons why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. There could be many different meanings of this paragraph that could have great importance to the story. It is included at the end to show how Saeng is trying to forget about how she failed the test. She is using this time now to prepare for the next time she is going to take the driving test. She thinks that once she forgets all of the bad things she went through the previous year, she can move on and be able to pass the driving test the next time around. The author concluded the story with the paragraph to show how Saeng plans to solve her problems. The way you interpret the paragraph gives you different ideas about what it is trying to say. I think that it is showing a new beginning that she will have to go through the next year, full of potential and hope.

I think the author concludes the story with the phrase “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. By using this phrase, the author is saying that Saeng will be ready for whatever challenges come her way the next time they return.

The author ended the story “Winter Hibiscus” with Saeng vowing to retake the test. He ended it this way to effectively show the themes of this story. One prominent theme of the story is to never give up. The winter hibiscus has to endure the long and harsh winter, but it does manage to survive. This resilience of the hibiscus inspires Saeng to keep trying. Another significant theme is to overcome your obstacles. The flower faces many dangers throughout the winter, but still manages to blossom. Saeng, seeing the flower's ability to overcome, wants to overcome her own obstacles and pass the test. Therefore, the ending of the story effectively displays these important themes.

The author concludes this part of the story because it made the story stand out a little. For example, when Saeng said that she meant when the plants came back, it added a layer of meaning. It also gave the ending a little something to hang on to, rather than simply continuing to talk about the plants or geese which could potentially get the reader off - topic. Last, she also meant when the geese came back, which further ties into the seasonal and symbolic elements of the story.

I think the author finishes the story with that part where the girl sees this plant as a symbol of strength and faith. So, she decides that she will take the test next year when the plant comes back. She truly has a fondness for the plant, and she hopes that it will bring her luck as she attempts the test again.

I think the author ended the story with that specific phrase to clearly show that the girl won't give up. No matter how difficult the situation is, she keeps trying. In the story, the girl says “I failed the test,” and then at the end of the story, she states “I will take that test again”. This shows that she is not willing to accept failure forever. I also think the author ended the story with that paragraph to pique the reader's curiosity and make you wonder if she will ever pass the test, leaving an open - ended and thought - provoking conclusion.

I think the author writes this because whatever test she has to take, she wasn't fully prepared for it before. Maybe she lacked the necessary knowledge or skills. But now, whenever the geese return and the hibiscus blossoms reappear, she will be ready to take the test. Perhaps in the past, she wasn't mentally in the right state. So, in conclusion, I think when she says the geese and the hibiscus return, she will take the test. It's likely that she wasn't physically and mentally well - prepared for it earlier, but now she's looking forward to a better attempt.

Authors carefully choose their closing paragraphs. The author chose to end their story with this particular paragraph because all of the elements the actor mentions in the last paragraph hold something special in the characters' eyes. There are specific reasons the author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph. The author's choice of the ending paragraph is extremely important. The character says “this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. The hibiscus she mentions represents the ability to overcome obstacles. In the story, it details the girl overcoming a failed test and getting ready to retake it. That is precisely why the author concludes with that. The author also writes, “when the snow melts and the geese return”. This, to the character, represents new beginnings and chances. It gives the character the strong sense that next time around, she will pass the test. The author adds that paragraph at the end to symbolize new beginnings, chances, and the ability to overcome obstacles. Authors choose their last paragraph for specific reasons, and this author did so to symbolize important concepts related to hope and perseverance.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because of a saying that when it's cold and silent, she keeps to herself and is perhaps a bit withdrawn, but when the snow melts and spring arrives, she becomes more lively and does lots of fun things. Spring brings a change in her mood and behavior, and the author uses this contrast to end the story, showing how the change of seasons can also bring a change in a person's state of mind and actions.

I believe the author concluded the story with that paragraph because the geese that fly down south in a beautiful V - shaped formation, fly down every season like clockwork. So she tells herself, firmly, she will take the test again when the geese return and the hibiscus plant is budding. For example, she thinks to herself, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” As she looks up at the geese, she is almost vividly reminded of an experience she went through that was somewhat similar. This connection to the seasons and the geese gives her the motivation and the sense that it's a natural cycle for her to try again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" to emphasize that you can overcome a defeat or failure by waiting until the “season” comes again for you to re - endure. Basically, the hibiscus (a plant) meant a great deal to the narrator and her mother. The hibiscus was dying, and they dug up a hole to help it grow. So when it grows again, it proves that it will be thriving better. When Saeng relates this to the test, it means she will have the opportunity to pass the test. The story with this paragraph symbolizes a new beginning about to take place. This actually means a situation that will come around again, which will help you get what you missed out on before. The story and the paragraph emphasize that life is about a budding cycle of hope, renewal, and the chance to overcome setbacks.

She canít wait till the colorful flowers start to come back when the thick snow melts and the outside temperature rises so it isnít very cold anymore, allowing them to grow. She is going to take the important test that she has unfortunately failed when the geese return and the flowers bloom.

The author concludes with this paragraph to clearly show that Saeng, much like the geese that migrate and the hibiscus that blossoms, will return again and hold onto hope. Saeng is a little deeply depressed in the story because she has recently moved to a new country and just failed her crucial driving test. The hibiscus plant in the florist shop brings back vivid and painful emotional memories for her, but at the same time, it is very comforting. Later in the story, she carefully plants the hibiscus outside in the garden with her mother. As her mother slowly goes inside, Saeng watches the geese gracefully fly overhead. ìAlmost reluctantly, (Saeng) realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her. Like the geese.î Saeng knew the geese would return in the spring, just like she would to her driving test. The hibiscus would be in full bloom again too to provide her with much - needed hope. This is precisely what the final paragraph in the story ìwinter hibiscusî means.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly show Saengís everlasting determination. This idea of her unwavering determination to succeed can be closely connected to the plant she brings home. The plant she clearly knew grew wild where she used to live, but she found it potted in the United States which is severely limiting its growth, just like Saengís new country seems extremely unordinary, and she feels completely out of place.

The author concludes the story with Saeng firmly telling herself sheíll take the test again because it effectively draws together the overall theme and major actions of the story. The theme of the story is that you can gradually get used to a new environment by carefully finding beauty in it and obvious similarities to your old home. Saeng says that ìmany of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now like the geese.î And when sheís in the greenhouse, the lush plants draw her back into warm memories of Vietnam and her dear grandmother. Saeng was having a really hard time adjusting to new things after moving to @LOCATION2, but she was determined to overcome the difficulties just like she had overcome the differences between the @LOCATION3 and Vietnam. I think the author concluded the story by talking about the geese and the hibiscus and re - taking the test because it clearly demonstrates all the ways that Saeng is adjusting to her new life and shows her and the reader that she can overcome new things. She vows to herself that she can do it, and foreshadows her future success and adaptation to an @CAPS1 lifestyle.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph that she did because it was the end and the start of a brand - new beginning. The author uses the senses in her story. The cold winter is the current season and the warm spring is on its way. Although Saeng failed her test in the harsh winter when most things die, she is eagerly looking forward to spring to start again on her test. The geese will return and the hibiscus will bud to show spring is here with new life. Saeng will also have new life in her test to pass it this time and drive. The spring season will come and new life will be provided to all, bringing a fresh start and renewed hope.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph is like a concise summary that conveys most of the story's essence in a small and shorter way, neatly wrapping up the key elements.

This paragraph is a good way to end the story because it directly relates to the test. The narrator, with determination, says she will try again in the spring, leaving a sense of hope and future possibility in the story's conclusion.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it precisely captures what the story is all about. It simply explains what happened in the end, as if what occurred through the story was akin to the growth and living cycle of a flower, symbolizing the journey and development within the narrative.

The story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho. The author concludes the story in what seems like an incomplete paragraph. The girl Saeng vows to take her driver test over when the spring comes. When Saeng was holding the plant, she felt cold and helpless, much like how the plant appeared. “Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind.” By Saeng's mother reassuring her that she was okay with her choice, it made Saeng grow as a person. “I'm glad you got it.” Saeng's mother also says, “look how root - bound it is, poor thing.” That in a way describes Saeng clinging to stay connected with her country. Saeng’s mother also tells her that now the plant will surely survive. When the spring comes, the plant will be just as strong, and so will Saeng. This is precisely why the author leaves off where she did, leaving a message of hope and growth.

The author concludes the story by showing the girl’s deep connection to the plant and the symbolism of the geese. The “Winter hibiscus” serves as her strong connection to her homeland. She said she’ll retake her driving test when her plant buds and shows bravery, and so she will muster the same courage. The geese flying south symbolize her journey as a person because she will take the test when the geese come back from their journey, just as she returns from her own personal journey of self - discovery and growth.

The author wrote the ending paragraph the way she did for many reasons. The main reason for this is because she wanted to end the story on a lighter note. All throughout the story, there was a depressing, nostalgic tone that made the reader yearn for the past. The author wanted to put an emphasis on being strong even though you may not enjoy where you are at. Also, the author wanted to show the strength of the main character, Saeng. Even though she has just failed a test in a new, strange world, she still wishes to continue pushing forward. This adds more dimension to the character and makes her less static and more dynamic. This is a very good story to read if you are homesick and need something to inspire you to keep going.

The author concludes with that statement because it shows she needs time. She needs time to adjust to her new home, much like the hibiscus needs time to get some roots in the new soil she is on. When she is at the orchard, she sees the hibiscus and has vivid memories of her old home, which makes her cry but yet feel a sense of comfort at the same time. This connection between her and the hibiscus highlights the process of adaptation and the longing for familiarity.

I believe the author concludes that passage in the story to show patience. Saeng was told to wait for spring, maybe it will then feel more like her hometown again. She likes the spring better than the winter because of the vibrant life it brings. She enjoys how the birds, especially the geese, return in spring. They go away in winter, leaving the landscape feeling empty. That is why I believe the author concludes that passage, to convey the hope and renewal associated with the changing seasons.

“When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author has left her home and moved to another country. She is now in an unfamiliar place. Everything that now surrounds her is new and mostly unknown. By ending the story with this quote, it suggests that the author still has hope of adapting to her new home. When she left her home, she did not just leave a building behind. She left her home, the people she loved deeply, and an endless list of precious memories. At times, she may have felt out of place because she was no longer in her comfort zone. She is now “out of the box,” and in a whole new world. When she saw the hibiscus, the exotic plant took her back to her memories and to the love of her old home. Then she came back to reality and broke apart with sadness and “failed her test.” The ending sentence shows that the author is willing to try to survive in this new place and that she is still determined to pass her own test of adapting, which is a powerful message of resilience.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This means that she will take the test and hopes she passes so she could make her mother happy and gain her support. She chose spring because spring is the rebirth of nature, and Saeng would like to retake the test with a clear and clean mind, unburdened by the weight of her previous failure. I think that the reason why the author chose to put this paragraph at the end of the story is to show the character's growth and determination, leaving the reader with a sense of hope for her future.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for several significant reasons. Throughout the story, Saeng constantly struggles with her past, which includes the loss of her grandmother and homeland, and tries hard to overcome it. The paragraph helps bring a clear sense of closure to the story. When Saeng returns home with the hibiscus, she tearfully tells her mother she couldn't help it and was unable to overcome her past. Saeng said, “I - I failed the test.” When she says “the test,” she specifically means the ability to cope with the loss of her grandmother and homeland, and overcome it. In the concluding paragraph, Saeng shows determination as she says she will retake the test. She said, “When the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” In conclusion, the author uses the concluding paragraph to bring closure to the story and the emotional obstacles Saeng faces, leaving a sense of hope for her future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to end the story with a glimmer of hope. For example, since she has moved to the United States, she often feels deeply homesick. To make matters worse, she failed the driver’s test, which added to her disappointment. “She found she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again.” This quote vividly helps add to the image of the homesick girl. She concludes with this paragraph to show that when spring comes, bringing with it warmth and new beginnings, she’ll start out fresh and re - live her life in @LOCATION2, leaving behind the sadness and setbacks.

The author concluded this story with the paragraph because, Saeng is explaining to the readers that she will take the test again when the time is truly right. When things in her life seem to be gradually getting better, such as when she has more peace of mind and is more confident, she will retake the test. This shows her perseverance and hope. That is why the author used that paragraph to conclude her story, as it leaves the readers with a sense of Saeng's determination for a better future.

In the story Winter Hibiscus written by @CAPS1 Ho, the narrator goes to a greenhouse filled with many colorful flowers, but one in particular catches her eye. A “winter” Hibiscus plant stands out. This plant powerfully reminds her of her homeland and all the happy events that used to take place there. This plant also vividly reminds her of her grandmother's long, silky gray hair and how she used to watch her dry it in the gentle sun and then help her knot it up into a bun with a bud of this plant in it. The author ends the story with this because it counters her statement when she says “I - I failed the test.” And the end of this passage says “..., then I will take the test again,” showing a shift from defeat to hope.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" the girl Saeng fails the drivers test. “I - I failed the test,” said Saeng with a disappointed tone. She had bought a hibiscus because the flower strongly reminded her of some of the precious memories from home and the hibiscus she had at her house. At the end, she says that she will retake the test when the geese come back, the snow has completely melted, and the hibiscus is budding. She does this, I think, because she needs time to calmly think things through, to just remember the good old days back home and to make a beautiful hibiscus garden. The hibiscus in this story is just like Saeng. They both did something wrong or faced a setback. Saeng failed the test, and the hibiscus was confined to a pot. But they both are going to change the bad situation and move towards a better future.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the paragraph in such a way to convey the determination and the newly - found motivation that Saeng discovered by purchasing the familiar plant. Despite failing her test, coming across a plant that brought back memories of her home and her grandmother filled her with the drive to retake the test. She was resolute to make her new life in this new country turn out for the better, regardless of the challenges. “She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive ‘u’ was etched against the evening sky ...” The author included details about the geese to symbolize moving on. Just like the geese that leave and return, Saeng too had a set - back when she failed the test the first time, but getting the plant and observing the birds inspired her to give it another shot. “Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become ...familiar to her.” Among the things that had become familiar to her in her new home were the geese. Concluding the stay with a mention of the geese conveys to the reader that she is gradually learning to adapt to her unfamiliar new home. Finding the plant was a great help as it was already a part of her past. “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral. ‘@CAPS1,’ Saeng said.” After failing her driver’s test, stepping into the florist’s shop and finding that plant offered her comfort. It made this new place feel more like home than it did initially. The geese had become a common sight over time, and finding the plant was simply a source of solace. Concluding the story in this manner shows the reader that she is adapting and learning to cope with a difficult situation in a comforting way, which ultimately gives hope for her future in the new country.

In the story "WiNter Hibiscus" by MiNFOnG HO, the author concludes the story with "when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the sprinG, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is buddiNG, then I will take that test again". The author concluded the story with that @CAPS1 because she is clearly saying that when the year starts anew and begins afresh, she will also start over. She is making a connection between the natural cycle of the geese returning, the snow melting, and the hibiscus starting to bud. All these natural phenomena signify a new beginning. When the geese fly back, the snow melts away, and the Hibiscus starts to show buds, they all mark the start of a new phase. So, when she goes to take the test, it will be a brand - new year, a year filled with new opportunities and a chance for her to succeed where she previously failed. This conclusion emphasizes the idea of renewal and the hope for a better outcome.

The author of Winter Hibiscus ended her story with words related to the fact that @CAPS1 failed her driving test. When Saeng noticed her past through the flower, she couldn't hold back her tears. The act of buying dok malik seeds also shows the significance of the story's ending. As the seasons change, the seeds will grow, just as Saeng will grow from this experience. The end of the story is set up in this way to suggest that next season, Saeng will have a new chance. The flower and the seeds are symbols of hope and renewal, indicating that despite the setback of failing the driving test, there is a bright future ahead. This ending leaves the reader with a sense of optimism about Saeng's journey in the new environment.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly show that saeng is extremely determined. She clearly states that she is going to take the test again, which is a strong indication of her unwavering resolve. Even though saeng failed her driver's test, she refuses to let this setback defeat her. She is not one to give up easily. This determination is a key trait that will likely help her succeed in the future. By ending the story with this message, the author wants the reader to understand that Saeng has the strength and the will to overcome obstacles and achieve her goals. It gives a positive outlook on her future attempts at the driving test and her life in general.

The author used that sentence because the snow is gradually melting, and the geese are starting to come back. The flowers are also budding up, which is a clear sign of the changing season. These natural phenomena are all interconnected and represent new beginnings. The melting snow symbolizes the end of a cold and difficult period, while the returning geese and budding flowers signify the arrival of warmth and growth. I think the author used that sentence to draw a parallel between these natural changes and the character's journey. Just as nature is renewing itself, the character is also getting a chance for a fresh start. This conclusion ties the story to the cycle of life and gives a sense of hope and optimism. Scribed by @ORGANIZATION1.

I believe that this was a truly good ending to the story. When Saeng says “When they come back,” she is clearly talking about the flowers. Specifically, she means when the flowers come back alive. “In the spring” explicitly shows the time when the flowers will come back. When she says “When the snows melt and the geese return,” she is indicating that after winter (when the snows melt) and when the geese return (which is in spring). “And this Hibiscus is budding” – she is stating when the flowers bloom again in the spring. “Then I will take the test again,” she is saying that after all these natural events happen, she will retake the test (in the spring). This shows that Saeng will be intently watching all these things happening and counting down until spring arrives again, so she can retake the test. She is eagerly ready for spring to be here, so that she can study hard, pass the test, and work at the flower @CAPS1. This will be her clear - cut goal for the winter, until spring finally comes!

The author concluded the story with that ending because in the spring, when everything in nature blossoms beautifully. During winter, when there is snow covering the ground, she wouldn't be able to focus properly. So, when the hibiscus is budding, which is a sign of the vibrant spring, that's precisely when she will be able to take her test again. I think the author wrote that ending because the arrival of spring and the blooming of flowers mean something significant to her. It represents a fresh start and a time of new opportunities for her to succeed in the test.

This conclusion of the story provides a strong sense of hope for the future. The girl is understandably upset that she failed the test, but she still holds firm hope for what will happen next. In the story, the narrator says, “She lifted her head.” This simple yet powerful quote is clearly showing that she is not going to quit and give up easily. Instead, she will keep trying until she finally succeeds. The conclusion of the story leaves readers to eagerly wonder if she will try harder and pass the test for the second time. When she says, “when the snow melts and the geese return,” this shows us that she is like the geese because they are both embarking on a hard - fought journey. Also, when she says, “and this hibiscus budding,” she is saying that when everything in nature comes to life and is at its highest peak, she will take the test because she will have the most confidence. The author concludes the story to show that there is definite hope for the future and that she is not going to give up. Although she is upset about failing the test, she will certainly be well - prepared and ready to pass it in the spring.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a couple of well - thought - out reasons. These reasons are likely related to the overall theme and message the author wants to convey to the readers. By ending the story with this specific paragraph, the author might be trying to leave a lasting impression, evoke certain emotions, or tie up loose ends in a meaningful way. It could also be a way to provide closure to the characters' arcs and the events of the story.

Saeng is @CAPS1 that it will be a long time before she will worry about school work again. This is because perhaps the current situation is too overwhelming or the time isn't right for her to focus on studies. That's why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. By doing so, the author is highlighting Saeng's current state of mind and how it relates to the overall flow and message of the story. It gives the readers an insight into Saeng's perspective and the reasons behind her thoughts about school work.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph, because he wants to emphasize that the girl is not completely dissatisfied with leaving her home. She may have some mixed feelings, but there's a glimmer of acceptance in her. He ended with that because he wanted to show that there is hope for her to learn to love her new home as time goes by.

The author ends the story with this sentence because Saeng, who has been under a lot of pressure from the test, needs a break before she takes the test again. Saeng is comparing two seemingly indifferent things: flowers and taking a test. This comparison is significant as it reveals her unique perspective. That's why the author ends the story with this sentence to let readers understand Saeng's state of mind.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to show that the girl is going to be like the hibiscus. Just as the hibiscus goes through a cycle and blooms beautifully, the next time it blooms, the girl will be ready for the test. She will take it again with full - fledged preparation and will pass. The author wants to show that the girl will not give up easily and will try again to make sure she passes. The author involves the hibiscus to show that the girl and the hibiscus will bloom at the same time, and when that happens, she will pass the test successfully.

Well, I think the author concludes the story with that sentence because maybe Saeng likes the spring. The fresh air and the vibrant colors of spring make her feel at ease. She can concentrate better with her favorite flower around, as she thinks the flower relates to her life in many ways. It could symbolize her growth and resilience, which helps her focus on her goals.

The author ends the story like that to show the theme of working hard. The story has various elements that represent this theme. Some other examples of working hard are the “winter hibiscus”. Despite the harsh winter conditions, it perseveres and tries to bloom. Another example is her vow to pass the test. She is determined to put in the effort. So, that is why the author ends the story that way to drive home the importance of hard work.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it's about the same thing that they opened the story with. To introduce the story, the author tells about Saeng failing her driver's test, and then seeing a familiar plant that she has an immediate urge to buy. The middle of the story is about how she is having a tough time adapting to her new home. So to conclude the story, the author puts that Saeng will take her driver's test again, once the flowers start budding and the geese come out. The flower and the geese remind her of home, so this tells you that thinking of her home, and the objects that make her feel at home, comfort her and help her overcome obstacles, showing the power of nostalgia and familiarity in difficult times.

Authors use many techniques to improve their stories. Without these techniques, a story might seem bland, average, or unattractive. Author Minfong Ho conveys the fact that Saeng will try to take the test again. Instead of simply stating the fact that she will retake the test, he has her make a solemn promise on the geese that she will. The author ended the story like this to show how strongly she felt about the test, emphasizing her determination and the significance of this goal in her life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it connects the hibiscus back to the trials and triumphs of Saeng. Just as Saeng can't give up and must go back to retake the test, the winter hibiscus must make it through the hard, harsh winter and come back strong. The hibiscus are a symbol of hope, and Saeng thinks of them as her beacon of hope. Throughout the story, the hibiscus are comforting to Saeng because they vividly remind her of home. The author includes this because many people can relate to this and find hope in things. For Saeng, knowing that each year the hibiscus will come back in those tough conditions, reassures her that she'll be okay there as well, highlighting the universal nature of finding strength in symbols.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph to show a new beginning. The geese are coming back to restart their life there, the hibiscus will be blooming vibrantly, and she will re - take the test. At the beginning, Saeng was deeply depressed about having to leave her old country and beloved grandmother. Saeng began to feel “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her”. She remembered how some of these plants grew wild in bushes or between cracks in the sidewalk. Saeng saying what she did in the last paragraph is her showing that she found comfort and confidence in the hibiscus. Memories of the past showed her the way forward, and now she is going to retake her driver's test, ready to embrace this new chapter with newfound determination.

I think the author concludes this story with this ending paragraph because the story is all about how she feels comforted in the plants. She wants to wait until the weather breaks and the geese come back to take her test. I think she wants to wait that way she will be more at ease with her surroundings and can clear her mind. By waiting for these natural signs, she can create a more positive and familiar environment, allowing her to do her best on the test, as she believes in the power of these natural elements to boost her confidence and performance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it vividly shows that Saeng deeply desires to take the test again. However, she wishes to retake the test precisely when all the good and happy elements return, just like the revival of the plant and the return of the geese. This is clearly true as Saeng explicitly says "When they (geese) come back… and this hibiscus is budding I will take the test." This statement not only showcases her maturity but also her profound sense of happiness. She is willing to undertake something difficult and perhaps not very enjoyable when everything around her has returned to a state of happiness. Just as she arrived in a state of sadness, when the geese return and the plant thrives, she wants to assist them through this and bring happiness to them as well. In this way, they can all experience happiness simultaneously, creating a harmonious and fulfilling atmosphere.

The short story “Winter Hibiscus” as written by author Minfong Ho, ends with the main character Saeng, firmly promising herself that in the spring, when the geese gracefully return and the winter hibiscus begins to delicately bud, she would re - take her failed driver's test. Minfong Ho skillfully writes this story, incorporating heavy imagery and symbolism. The hibiscus found in the floral shop represents a deep - seated connection for Saeng to her homeland. The bittermelon, which is loved by Saeng but unbearable to the people in @LOCATION1, represents Saeng's arduous time in connecting with the people there.
