The story says, “It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet towards the center – just as she had known it would feel” (Ho). The feel of the hibiscus @MONTH1 reminds Saeng of distant memories, like helping her grandmother with her hair. All of these things will only make Saeng stronger so that the next time she takes the test, there is no chance of her failing.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the spring, when the snow has completely melted away and the environment becomes more favorable, she will take the test again. This reflects a sense of renewal and a new beginning, where she is ready to face the test with a fresh mindset after the cold and dormant winter.

In the quote above, it is clearly telling that Saeng is genuinely glad to be back. She has a sense of relief and contentment upon her return. Saeng also states firmly that she would be ready to do it all again if she had to. This shows her determination and resilience, indicating that she is not afraid of challenges and is willing to face them head - on.

I think the reason the author concluded the story like that is because it was extremely cold outside. The cold weather might have influenced the overall mood and the decisions within the story. I also think that what the author is trying to say is that when she wrote this letter, the biting cold was present, and she wouldn't take the test until it was warm again due to the harsh cold conditions. “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this is when the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test over again.” This clearly shows the connection between the weather and her decision.

There are many reasons the author says “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows completely melt and the geese return in flocks and this hibiscus is budding beautifully, then I will take that test again.” Evidently, the author said this because the girl left everything, her familiar surroundings and all her memories, just to come to this foreign country and she simply cannot afford to fail. The girl said “That at last, she could hold on to. But where was the fine - toothed comb? the hibiscus hedge?” She also said this because the hedge was all she had from her old home besides her mother. When the “hibiscus is budding,” it means it is starting a new life and is gradually starting to grow leaves, and similarly, the girl is starting to grow and move on with her life in this new land.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because if the author tries it again, it might work out a lot better as now they have a clear understanding of what they are doing. They have learned from their previous attempts and can avoid the mistakes. Also, if they try it again, and if it yields enough results, they can sell the product and make a decent amount of money. This way, they will be motivated to keep doing it for years to come, establishing a sustainable and profitable venture.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with a resolution of Saeng in order to vividly show how Saeng will not give up easily and how she is highly determined. The reference to the spring blossoms in the story shows how Saeng will fight tenaciously to survive through the hardships, which are symbolically represented by winter. Just like the hibiscus that struggles to adapt to a new home environment, Saeng is struggling to adapt to a new country. The final paragraph provides a clear resolution to the internal conflict of Saeng throughout the story by suggesting that with her determination, Saeng will succeed in taking the test. In conclusion, the final paragraph in the story “Winter Hibiscus” effectively provides a resolution to the conflict in the story, and clearly shows the reader Saeng’s unwavering determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows exactly what Saeng will be doing and whether she will go to school. Saeng didn't want to go to school because she would patiently wait for the snow to completely melt and the geese to return in large numbers and for this hibiscus to be budding vibrantly. She prefers gardening to school as the garden reminds her so much about her homeland. For instance, Saeng dug out a deep hole and carefully lowered the winter hibiscus into it with great care. The thing that made her think about her homeland was the rhythmic beating of eggs against a bowl, the sharp sizzle of hot oil in the pan, and the pungent smell of bitter melon that wafted out. Another example is when she went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground with such focus, which shows she deeply cares about the garden and the connection it has to her past.

The author concludes her story with the quote, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This is because the author is showing that nature and the plant are highly valuable to her. Saeng, the one who says the quote, firmly believes that the hibiscus will assist her in passing the test. Earlier on in the story, it vividly shows that when she gets in trouble, she gently rubs the plant leaves in her hands to help her overcome the problem. The author is making the idea clear and effectively portraying the thought that the plant helps Saeng with obstacles, which further emphasizes the connection between Saeng and nature in her journey.

In the end of the story, the young girl Saeng silently vows to herself that she will take the driver's test next year. One reason she might have vowed to herself to do that is to prove to herself and others that she can successfully pass the test. Also, after she bought the flower and carefully planted it, and as she remembered all the wonderful and precious times she had in Vietnam, it bestowed upon her the confidence to go out and strive for what she truly wanted. This new - found confidence is what propels her to look forward to taking the test next year.

The author includes this in the paragraph to simply be sarcastic, aiming for you to know that it is almost an impossible feat for Saeng to take the test afresh. I say this because she was being very clearly sarcastic, which strongly implies that she isn't going to take the test. For example, if someone were to tell me to take a test and I said, “whenever @LOCATION1 is president again, then I'll take the test,” that would be a very obvious form of sarcasm. It means that it won't happen and I'm not taking the test, instead of just straightforwardly saying “No.” The author included that just to let you clearly understand that the chances of her taking the test are extremely low. This use of sarcasm effectively conveys the unlikelihood of the event.

The author includes this paragraph in order to show a proper end to the story and to clearly show that Saeng has not given up. He wanted to vividly illustrate how the plant and the geese represented the continuation of Saeng's life in the United States. The geese will gracefully come back, and the Hibiscus will beautifully bud and flower. Similarly, Saeng will retake and hopefully successfully pass her driving test. This paragraph is not just a simple closing but a new and promising beginning of life for the geese, a Winter Hibiscus, and Saeng, symbolizing fresh starts and hope.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show @CAPS1's remarkable strength and the much - needed encouragement. When she is both willing and fully able, she will take the test again with significantly more confidence. Saeng says this to herself as a source of motivation to help her persevere until she can drive. She's looking forward and saying that by next spring, she'll take her test. By next spring, she'll be able to drive independently. By next spring, she'll have fully adjusted to her new home. This paragraph conveys the important message that it takes time to achieve things; you don't always succeed right away, so it's essential to keep trying and stay persistent.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was deeply feeling down about not passing her driving test. However, when she saw those beautiful flowers, she realized that ever since she came to @CAPS1, she had gradually forgotten all about her hometown. So, she decided to get back in touch with her nature side and hold off taking her test until the spring instead of rushing things. This way, she could approach the test with a more relaxed and prepared mindset.

I believe that the author concludes the story with that particular paragraph to indicate that she still has hope of finding a sense of home and being truly happy. The hibiscus plant in her mind is a powerful symbol of home and the happy memories she shared with her grandmother. So, when the plant buds, she will feel as if she is at home again and is filled with happiness. That is precisely when she will take the driving test. Also, that paragraph clearly shows that she is slowly getting accustomed to the new home and lifestyle. “A flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now, like these geese.” Through these vivid examples, I believe that the narrator put that last paragraph there to show Saeng's assimilation into her new lifestyle and her acceptance of her situation. This acceptance is a crucial step in her journey towards finding contentment in her new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to clearly show that Saeng did not give up on the test. For example, she firmly says, “I will take the test again.” It shows that she has a strong desire to take the test and successfully pass it. Saeng is patiently going to wait until spring comes and when the snow completely melts to take the test. In the beginning in the box above, it talks about her initial attempt at taking the test. Then it ends with her resolutely going to take the test again, demonstrating her perseverance and determination.

At the end of "Winter Hibiscus," the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story through stating, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The author ends the story in such a thoughtful way in order to reveal the hope that lies in Saeng's future. After failing her driver's test, Saeng returns home with a heavy heart full of disappointment and sadness. This last paragraph, however, shows that soon enough Saeng's luck is bound to change. The reader is left with a strong hint that Saeng will retake her test and pass it with flying colors. Also, this ending paragraph reflects upon Saeng's determined personality to overcome many obstacles she is facing in @CAPS1. This paragraph proves she will not give up even after she was forced to live in the United States instead of her home. Her success in fitting in with her new life is clearly shown when through the quote, "Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become... almost familiar." Truly Saeng is a determined character who will surely achieve her goals.

The reason the author concludes this story with the paragraph is significant. The story is all about the girl deeply missing her home country. This paragraph subtly implies that the girl will adapt to her new country by the next @DATE1. The story and the paragraph vividly show the girl's remarkable strength to overcome the challenges of leaving her homeland and adjusting to a new environment. This is precisely why the author ended the story with this paragraph, to highlight the girl's resilience and the hope for a brighter future in her new home.

The author is letting us, the readers, know that the girl plans to do the same thing again next year when the show is all over, when the geese return, and when the weather is warm enough for the hibiscus flower to bud and bloom again! In the month of @MONTH1, the author is also concluding the sentence to show that this is the life the little girl chose, and she will continue with her gardening until the next spring.

Saeng concluded the story with that paragraph because it shows what she has just been through and she feels she could go through it again. If she fails the driving test again, then she will use the plants to overcome her problems. In the month of @MONTH1, she actually passed the test this time. The unique plants show that she is stronger than she thinks and now believes that she feels comfortable with the plants that bring back memories of her childhood, which gives her the strength to face challenges.

She shows that she loves her grandmother and she loves the activities they do together, like gardening and other similar things. Her mother cares about her, but she is really strict with her. This difference in relationships adds complexity to her life, yet she still finds comfort in her bond with her grandmother.

The author concluded the story in such a way that the reader's eyes are opened. It shows the reader that despite what might happen in the month of @MONTH1, no matter how bad things seem and how hopeless you feel, there is always a way to make it better. Saeng failed her test, was in a new land, and had lost her grandmother, but still planned to try again. Like the waves on the shore that always try to wash away the sand by coming back again, Saeng is willing to try again, and so should we all, as we can learn from her perseverance.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because that season is over and a new season is starting. This conclusion marks the transition from one phase to another, suggesting that there are new beginnings and opportunities ahead, bringing a sense of hope and renewal to the story.

The author concludes the story with  "when they comes back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt & the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". This poignant quote implies that once the flower buds, she will take the test over again. Saeng will have mustered the courage and the will to do it, firmly believing she will pass. The flower represents something deeply personal to her, a source that gives her the motivation and determination to persevere. Everyone has something that motivates them in life to keep going, and for Saeng, it's her plant. The author subtly gives you a direction and an idea of where the story is going, especially when the flower buds, hinting at a positive turn for Saeng.

Saeng is not only just disappointed from failing her driver's test; she is also deeply upset and longing for her home of Vietnam. As she is walking home, she spots a little piece of Vietnam right there in the United States. Intrigued, she buys the beautiful winter hibiscus, or saebba, to serve as a tangible reminder of her past. The end of this story masterfully combines the two different countries, cultures, and almost worlds that her life straddles. When she says, "when they come back", she is clearly referring to the geese. To her, the geese symbolize her life in the new place and how she has gradually become accustomed to it. The hibiscus is also a powerful symbol of her life. It represents her life and past in Vietnam, and buying that plant was like getting a precious little piece of home. When the "hibiscus is budding", it signals that she will attempt the test again. When this little piece of home flourishes and gets bigger, it means she will be more settled in the new culture while still having a firm grasp of her own. Then, she will be truly ready to face the challenge once more.

I believe that the Author ended the story with this paragraph because I think it is vividly showing that Saeng isn't a quitter. Saeng is eagerly waiting, can't hold back her anticipation until the Hibiscus comes back. When the Hibiscus finally makes its return, she'll retake the test with newfound determination. She is set on showing her mother that she can do it, proving her capabilities and resilience. This ending indicates that Saeng is ready to overcome the setback and move forward with confidence.

The reason why the author concluded the story with this paragraph is that when Saeng saw the geese, she had a clear realization. She knew that when spring comes back around, she would be ready to seek out different flowers. Also, she fondly thinks back to when she was in her homeland, where she could vividly see the flowers growing up from the ground. Although now that she is in the city, she optimistically thinks the flowers will blossom just like the ones back home, which she misses a great deal. Lastly, she describes the flowers as her friends, a connection that runs deep. She also remembers the “Madagascar periwinkle” growing wild, emerging from the cracks in brick walls or tiled roofs. Basically, the author conveys that she is eager and ready to look for other plants that she remembers from her homeland, rekindling a sense of connection to her roots.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with this paragraph to vividly depict a significant development in the character of Saeng. At the beginning of the story, Saeng is visibly dejected about failing her driver's test, feeling down and disheartened. However, this ending paragraph portrays the remarkable change that Saeng undergoes. In the text, Saeng initially proves to not adapt well to the change from Vietnam to @LOCATION2, struggling to fit in. She finds solace in a native flower of Vietnam, a winter hibiscus, which becomes a symbol of her past and comfort. By ending with the mention of the winter hibiscus in the concluding paragraph (“...and this hibiscus is budding...”), the author effectively depicts Saeng's change of attitude and her acceptance toward @LOCATION2. Saeng now feels that, like the hibiscus returning after winter is over, she will be able to return and pass the driver's test with renewed confidence. Also, the concluding paragraph depicts Saeng's new adaptation towards the creatures of @LOCATION2. Prior to her imagination of the @LOCATION4, Saeng had no prior exposure to Canada geese. In the concluding statement, Saeng's mentioning of the creatures displays her growing adaptation to @LOCATION2 (“...when the snow melts and the geese return...”). This shows Saeng's development and adaptation to her new surroundings. At first, Saeng proved to have a hard time leaving her native Vietnam behind and fully embracing @CAPS1 culture. However, this concluding paragraph summarizes the noticeable change that Saeng goes through, highlighting her growth and resilience. In this way, the author includes this paragraph to note the significant development in character that Saeng undergoes, leaving the reader with a sense of hope for her future.
They conclude the story with that because the harsh winter is finally over and the vibrant spring has arrived, and the world will be beautiful again with blooming flowers and chirping birds.

The author concludes the story with, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding. Then I will take that test again.” As time passes, she will become more familiar. For example, the author says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” That tells me that she feels that over some time, she will become more familiar with driving and then she will take the test again. Then she will surely pass it.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” decided to conclude the story in that way because she wanted to tie in the theme of new beginnings. Saeng is new to a foreign location and has had a rough time fitting in. She misses everything about her old home, from her beloved grandmother to the familiar old plants there. Saeng fails her driving test, so she feels that all is lost. But the hibiscus plant helped her realize she has another chance. The hibiscus can survive the cold winter and bloom in the colorful spring, and that is what Saeng realizes she must do. The last paragraph said “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Spring is the time for new beginnings: the geese return from the south, the flowers start to bloom beautifully, and Saeng can retake the driving test. In the last paragraph, Saeng realizes she wants a new beginning as well to be brought in the spring. In conclusion, the last paragraph ties the theme of new beginnings into the story. It shows Saeng's new realization and how the hibiscus inspired it.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng really wants to pass the test. You know this when it says “And in the warm, moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” This passage shows that she didn't want to fail. When Saeng got home, she had the white bud in the pot, and her mother saw that she was crying. Then her mother was going to put the plant in the ground, then Saeng took the shovel and did it herself. This made her realize she can take the test again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. First, when the hibiscus buds in the spring, that means that the plant is about to burst into full bloom. That also means that Saeng will be well - prepared in the spring to take the test again. Also, the last paragraph is at the end because if the plant can survive the tough winter and thrive, then the girl can pass her driver's test and be happy in both the success of the plant and her own achievement.

I think the author concludes the story with this particular paragraph because the author is stating that it's going to be a significant year, or some notable change is going to take place. He feels that they could have performed better than what they actually did and is determined to take that test again to achieve a better result.

The author concludes with this paragraph to emphasize the new beginning that Saeng is eagerly looking for. She was extremely disappointed when she failed her driver's test. The hibiscus was the very thing that could make her happy. She desperately needed a new beginning to start afresh in a new country. The flower, the snow, the geese, and the test all symbolize new beginnings and challenges to overcome. The geese and snow represent a change in season, the budding hibiscus represents new life, and the passing of the test represents a significant milestone in Saeng's life. Ending the story with this paragraph makes the reader expect something new and exciting to unfold in Saeng's life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to clearly explain to the reader that she isn't done with gardening. She'll definitely go back when the plants bloom once again. Also, she has no intention of stopping. In fact, she'd much rather spend her time gardening than going to school. This is precisely what the author concludes about the story with the last paragraph.

The author concludes this story with the few words “then I will take that test again.” because she strongly wanted us to know that she is not going to give up on something just because she failed once. She is firmly determined to keep going forward until she succeeds in passing “the test” and achieves her desired goal.

The author concludes the last paragraph of the story because she already clearly knew that she should not be afraid of trying a new life or new environment. For example, in the story, the mother says, “It’s flowers aren’t pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months. Here, this winter hibiscus.” It shows that the mother wants Saeng to learn that Saeng should be strong even in times of difficulty. Another example is, when the narrator says, “she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season…” It shows that Saeng realized that the new place that she's living in right now is almost the same as their old home. In conclusion, the last paragraph tells that Saeng should bravely face the new reality of the world. She should be strong and smoothly follow the flow of life.

The author concluded this story for an internal adjustment. Saeng's memories are vividly expressed through the one at the hibiscus. Spring, a season where everything is fresh and new, holds great significance. As spring arrives, Saeng's hope would be restored and start thriving, just like the budding hibiscus. And then, she will have the ability to try at the test again with more strength and inspiration, ready to face the challenges ahead.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with Saeng, the main character, firmly vowing to attempt the driving test in the spring when the hibiscus is in full bloom. This is a poignant way of showing the reader that even after this story ends, Saeng will not give up easily. The author adds the thought of the hibiscus in bloom because the hibiscus is a powerful symbol of strength for Saeng. The hibiscus flower is quite common in her home country, and the hibiscus she bought vividly reminds her of everything she left behind when she came to @LOCATION1 from Vietnam. Saeng is earnestly trying to accept her new lifestyle and uses the hibiscus as a valuable tool to help her through the tougher times. After Saeng buys the flower, she makes a firm vow to retake the failed driver's test after spring comes. Spring is a well - known symbol of a fresh start. Saeng also sincerely feels that if the hibiscus can make it through the harsh winter in @LOCATION1, so can she. The conclusion for this story uses a lot of vivid imagery that strongly suggests that Saeng will be strong and continue to build a life in @LOCATION1.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is that Saeng fails the test, and through this experience, she learns to appreciate nature a little better. This realization adds depth to the story, showing that setbacks can lead to personal growth and a newfound connection with the world around her.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng will return to the flowers again in the spring, perhaps to find the same source of inspiration and comfort. This return symbolizes her perseverance and the hope for a new beginning, suggesting that she will carry on and face future challenges with renewed strength.

The author states that idea because if you cannot do it once, do it again. First, if you take a test and can't pass it the first time, give it another try and you will likely be able to pass. For example, in the story, Saeng could not pass a test, and it would have been beneficial for them to let her take it again to see if she can pass it. Second, she could ask for help from others or use a book and study thoroughly. For instance, it will significantly help you pass a lot easier if you study hard enough. By persevering and seeking assistance, success becomes more attainable. That is what I think the statement means, highlighting the importance of determination and learning from failures.
The author concludes this story with this paragraph because it shows how each year will begin and end, symbolizing the cyclical nature of life and experiences.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph, because the author wants to express to the reader that Saeng has been genuinely comforted by the hibiscus and is whole - heartedly willing to give the driver's test another try. She is now much more open - minded about the entire situation. In the beginning of the story, Saeng was extremely upset and annoyed about failing her driver's test. For example, “the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. I - I failed the test,” Saeng said to her mother in a distraught voice. Obviously, she was deeply upset and disappointed in herself. The author didn't want to end the story with a sad, unsatisfying ending. Saeng changes her attitude about the test by the end of the story. For example, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” I believe that this attitude was because of the memories of her mother country that soothe her and also the loving support of her mother. In conclusion, the author ended the story with that to teach the reader a valuable lesson that one should let change occur and understand that time does heal emotional wounds.

The author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with the motivational paragraph because he/she wants to clearly show the reader that Saeng is firmly determined to adapt to her new life and home and bravely overcome common obstacles like a driver's test. Saeng had a really hard time coping with her problem, so she bought a hibiscus because it vividly reminded her of home. I think that the line “and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” from the last paragraph is a powerful symbol for growing up and successfully overcoming obstacles. The conclusion for the story is a heart - warming and satisfying ending that leaves a positive impression on the reader.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph, because when the snow melts and the geese return, she is going to have significantly higher confidence in taking and passing the test. After she failed the test later on in the story, the geese had flew away. So when the geese return, the sight and sound of the geese will vividly remind her of what had just now happened. When the snow melts and spring comes, the hibiscus flower will bloom once again, bringing with it a sense of renewal and hope for her test - taking endeavor.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” when spring comes back, it brings new hopes, comfort, and belief. As she said in the story, “in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” When she hears that the hibiscus comes back, it brings new hopes to her life for taking that test. Here, the hibiscus means hope. Second of all, when she said “the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” she means that it is a source of comfort for her. This comfort is stronger than hope, and it is even more powerful when her mom helps boost her belief in herself because it is not easy to do it without her mom's comfort. Lastly, she said “Canada geese flew by, their faint honks dear and yes familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetitions of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” She means that as the season is coming and the hibiscus grows, she will regain the belief and the strength that she needs to take the test. The hibiscus means a great deal to her as it represents new hopes, comfort, and belief, which are essential for her to face the test with courage.

Coming back from failing her driving test, Saeng, feeling dejected, is comforted by finding the hibiscus flower. It brings back cherished memories about Saeng's homeland, because it is very similar to the beautiful flowers that grew by her old home, with their bright colors and gentle fragrance. The author concluded the story by saying "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to compare Saeng to the hibiscus. Like Saeng, who has to adjust to a new environment, the hibiscus must try to adapt to new surroundings. The author shows that Saeng recognizes this connection and is inspired by it. In Saeng's mind, if the hibiscus can survive being moved, then so can she, and she will surely succeed next time.

The story of “Winter Hibiscus” is a prolonged metaphor for both connections to a comforting past as well as expectance and the future. Saeng misses her homeland deeply but she must learn to adapt to her circumstances, such as the new culture and daily life here, and pass her driver's test to gain more independence. The story is nicely concluded with Saeng's promise to herself that come spring, when the world is full of new life, she will take the test again. The hibiscus flower itself generates this promise as it gives her some closure and alleviates some home - sickness, making her feel a bit closer to her homeland. Saeng’s promise indicates that she is coming to terms with her situation. When she sees the Canada geese flying in the sky, forming beautiful patterns, she has somewhat of an epiphany about the seasons. “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become.. - Almost familiar to her now.” I feel that was a landmark for Saeng and the conclusion illustrates that she is allowing herself to change and embrace the new life.

In “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, Saeng has a deep emotional connection to the memories and flashbacks that the Hibiscus brings back to her. At one point in the story, she cries out of mourning for her grandmother because the hibiscus plants bring back vivid memories of the happy times they spent together. The sight and smell of the hibiscus make her acutely aware of the loss. Later on in the story, she carefully takes the plant to her mother. At first, her mother is upset as she might not understand Saeng's strong attachment at that moment, but then she becomes understanding of her daughter’s actions and feelings, realizing how much the hibiscus means to Saeng. Saeng is upset that she didn't pass her test and her mother understands that. I think the author ends the story this way because she wants the reader to see that because the hibiscus is so important to Saeng and reminds her of her past, it will give her a reason and motivation to continue and reach her goal of passing the test.

Since it is getting close to winter, the weather is getting colder and the geese are going south in search of warmer places. The plants are losing their leaves, looking a bit bare and lifeless. Saeng says that she will take the test again. It seems that when the geese return in a lively flock and the hibiscus buds, with its delicate petals starting to unfurl, it will give her hope and confidence. Especially the hibiscus because it reminds her of her homeland and her grandmother. When she first saw it and gently held the leaf, it brought a tear to her eye, as a flood of memories rushed back. And when it comes back next year, blooming beautifully, it will rejuvenate her spirit and give her the strength to face the test again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she thinks that it will explain what happened to Saeng very well. This paragraph neatly summarizes Saeng's emotional journey throughout the story. It shows her struggles, her connection to the hibiscus, and her new - found determination. By ending with this, the author allows the readers to understand Saeng's growth and her readiness to move forward, making the whole story complete and leaving a lasting impression on the readers.

The author concludes her story with that last paragraph because it clearly shows the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscuses, and how deeply one can feel just by seeing it. It also shows that the hibiscus motivates her because it vividly reminds her of her homeland that she loves so dearly, and it's like having a physical memory of her cherished homeland. In the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng decides to retake her failed driver’s test in the spring. She makes this decision because she finds comfort in the moderate weather of the spring. Its gentle warmth and pleasant breeze remind her of home, and Saeng is deeply and very closely attached to her home. This feeling of nostalgia makes her long for the familiarity and security it represents. It reminds me of all the places I've been and how, even after all this time, I still vividly remember my favorite one. Like Saeng, I have a habit of buying objects that remind me of my old home. Saeng’s strong commitment to her old home makes me feel less alone when I miss my old home, as it shows that the longing for a familiar place is a shared human experience.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng is determined to start over and do better the second time around. She has a strong sense of self - respect and does not want to disappoint herself with another failure. Knowing that she has the potential to succeed, she is ready to face the challenge again. That is precisely why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, as it showcases Saeng's resilience and determination.

I think that the author concludes the story like this because it clearly shows a new beginning. When the spring arrives, the world undergoes a remarkable transformation. Everything comes back to life in a vibrant display of nature's renewal. Plants that were once dormant grow back with fresh green leaves and colorful blossoms. Animals that had hidden away during the cold winter are seen again, scurrying about or singing in the trees. The sun shines bright, spreading warmth and light across the land. This is a new beginning for them, and it can be seen in the same light for Saeng. She could try again because the arrival of spring gives her another chance at success. Another reason the author ended the story like this is because Saeng has a deep love for nature. Maybe when nature is back around her, with its beauty and vitality, it will infuse her with hope and confidence to pass her test.

The last paragraph of the story was: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think the author concluded the story with that paragraph to show that she is adapting and that she is starting to accept the change. I think that because throughout the story, she is visibly upset and not really fond of the change. “And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept,” the text says. This shows her initial struggle with the new situation. However, this last paragraph seems optimistic, talking about the flower blooming and the geese returning, which seems like she is starting to accept the change. In my opinion, the author added that paragraph to finish the story on a positive note, to show that Saeng is starting to accept the change and be optimistic about her future.

Saeng told her mother that she failed the test. She felt really bad about it and wanted to make up for it. So, she decided to help out in the garden. The Author concludes that, when the geese come back in the spring, she will take the test because she believes she will be more fully prepared for the test. She feels extremely bad as if she let her mother down by failing it. “I just stared at the hibiscus,” this shows that she felt so ashamed that she couldn't even look at her mother. So next spring, she is determined to make her mom happy and pass the test because she will be truly ready.

She understood that she had to change herself and work harder to achieve what she desired, and this self - awareness would guide her towards better adaptation.

The author uses this conclusion for a well - thought - out reason. The reason the author uses this cliff - hanger of a conclusion is to effectively keep the reader interested and constantly wanting more. By saying, “I will take that test again”, the author makes the reader deeply question if Saeng will pass the test next time. Moreover, the reader will also wonder what “the test” actually is. There was a specific reason as to why the author concluded the story with that quote. The author wanted to clearly show how the plant gave Saeng a new sense of determination. So she now was determined to battle the odds as well and retake the test she failed. This shows that even in the face of failure, one can find motivation and the will to try again.
